title: THE GOSPEL (PROTO-LUKE)
description: A forensic reconstruction of the Jamesian Protograph, commonly identified as Proto-Luke or the Marcionite Evangelion. This reconstruction excises canonical chapters 1 and 2, recognized as later Pastoral additions designed to anchor the narrative in Davidic biology and Temple piety. In this Jamesian core, the narrative begins not with a birth, but with a sudden descent of the Spirit into the historical timeframe of the Roman Empire.

verses.english: In the fifteenth year of the governance of Tiberius Caesar, when Pontius Pilate was governor of Judea, and Herod was tetrarch of Galilee, and his brother Philip was tetrarch of the region of Ituraea and Trachonitis, and Lysanias was tetrarch of Abilene,
verses.greek: Ἐν ἔτει δὲ πεντεκαιδεκάτῳ τῆς ἡγεμονίας Τιβερίου Καίσαρος, ἡγεμονεύοντος Ποντίου Πιλάτου τῆς Ἰουδαίας, καὶ τετρααρχοῦντος τῆς Γαλιλαίας Ἡρῴδου, Φιλίππου δὲ τοῦ ἀδελφοῦ αὐτοῦ τετρααρχοῦντος τῆς Ἰτουραίας καὶ Τραχωνίτιδος χώρας, καὶ Λυσανίου τῆς Ἀβιληνῆς τετρααρχοῦντος,

verses.english: he came down to Capernaum, a city of Galilee, and was teaching them on the Sabbaths;
verses.greek: κατῆλθεν εἰς Καφαρναοὺμ πόλιν τῆς Γαλιλαίας. καὶ ἦν διδάσκων αὐτοὺς ἐν τοῖς σάββασιν·

verses.english: and they were astonished at his teaching, because his word was with authority.
verses.greek: καὶ ἐξεπλήσσοντο ἐπὶ τῇ διδαχῇ αὐτοῦ, ὅτι ἐν ἐξουσίᾳ ἦν ὁ λόγος αὐτοῦ.

verses.english: And he came to Nazareth, where he had been brought up; and as was his custom, he entered the assembly on the Sabbath day and stood up to read.
verses.greek: Καὶ ἦλθεν εἰς Ναζαρά, οὗ ἦν τεθραμμένος, καὶ εἰσῆλθεν κατὰ τὸ εἰωθὸς αὐτῷ ἐν τῇ ἡμέρᾳ τῶν σαββάτων εἰς τὴν συναγωγήν, καὶ ἀνέστη ἀναγνῶναι.

verses.english: And all were bearing witness to him and were wondering at the words of grace proceeding out of his mouth.
verses.greek: καὶ πάντες ἐμαρτύρουν αὐτῷ καὶ ἐθαύμαζον ἐπὶ τοῖς λόγοις τῆς χάριτος τοῖς ἐκπορευομένοις ἐκ τοῦ στόματος αὐτοῦ.

verses.english: And he said to them, "Doubtless you will say to me this proverb: 'Healer, heal yourself'; whatever we heard happened in Capernaum, do also here in your fatherland."
verses.greek: καὶ εἶπεν πρὸς αὐτούς· Πάντως ἐρεῖτέ μοι τὴν παραβολὴν ταύτην· Ἰατρέ, θεράπευσον σεαυτόν· ὅσα ἠκούσαμεν γενόμενα εἰς τὴν Καφαρναοὺμ ποίησον καὶ ὧδε ἐν τῇ πατρίδι σου.

notes.explanation: The Greek term is rendered here as "governance" rather than "reign" to reflect the administrative office held by Tiberius as a dry historical fact, avoiding the royal connotations of later ecclesiastical translations.

In the canonical context, this implies moving geographically from the hills of Nazareth down to the sea-level of Capernaum. However, in the Proto-Luke reconstruction, where the Nazareth rejection (4:16-30) is relocated to follow the Capernaum ministry, this verb marks a "vertical" Christology—the descent of the Divine Human directly into the Ultimates of history without the mediation of a biological birth.
Used here in its literal sense of a gathering place, stripped of later specialized religious baggage.
The spelling follows the primitive uncial consensus (א, B, D, Z) over the later smoothed "Capernaum".
This form is often found in the earliest strata (P70, א, B) and is preferred here as the more primitive designation of the town.

Internal evidence reveals "editorial fatigue" in the canonical text, where the crowd in Nazareth mentions miracles in Capernaum before Jesus has actually visited Capernaum. In the Proto-Luke source, narrative logic is restored by placing the Capernaum ministry first, proving that the canonical editor "front-loaded" the rejection story for thematic purposes.

The phrase "Is this not Joseph's son?" (οὐχὶ υἱός ἐστιν Ἰωσὴφ οὗτος;) is absent from the earliest Marcionite/Jamesian witnesses. Its removal aligns with the Adoptionist view that Jesus was the Son of God by power and Spirit, not by fleshly descent.

The Baptism of John and the Temptation in the Wilderness are absent in this earliest stratum. This preserves a Christology where the Savior requires no validation from the prophets of the old aeon, appearing as a fully empowered agent of the Divine.
The narrative of John's baptism and the genealogy are entirely absent. The "word of God" (ῥῆμα θεοῦ) in verse 2 is treated as an interpolation to link the Messenger to the old prophetic modulo.

chapters.title: Proto-Luke Chapter 2
chapters.preamble: Following the rejection at Nazareth, the narrative shifts to the clinical manifestations of the Spirit's power in Capernaum and the subsequent formation of the core community.

verses.english: And in the assembly was a man having a spirit of an unclean daimon, and he cried out with a loud voice: "What is to us and to you, Jesus? Have you come to destroy us? I know you, who you are—the holy one of God."
verses.greek: Καὶ ἐν τῇ συναγωγῇ ἦν ἄνθρωπος ἔχων πνεῦμα δαιμονίου ἀκαθάρτου, καὶ ἀνέκραξεν φωνῇ μεγάλῃ· Ἔα, τί ἡμῖν καὶ σοί, Ἰησοῦ; ἦλθες ἀπολέσαι ἡμᾶς; οἶδά σε τίς εἶ, ὁ ἅγιος τοῦ θεοῦ

verses.english: And Jesus rebuked him.
verses.greek: καὶ ἐπετίμησεν αὐτῷ ὁ Ἰησοῦς λέγων· Φιμώθητι καὶ ἔξελθε ἀπ᾿ αὐτοῦ. καὶ ῥῖψαν αὐτὸν τὸ δαιμόνιον εἰς τὸ μέσον ἐξῆλθεν ἀπ᾿ αὐτοῦ μηδὲν βλάψαν αὐτόν

verses.english: And when the sun was setting, all who had any sick with various diseases brought them to him; and he laid hands on each of them and healed them.
verses.greek: Δύνοντος δὲ τοῦ ἡλίου ἅπαντες ὅσοι εἶχον ἀσθενοῦντας νόσοις ποικίλαις ἤγαγον αὐτοὺς πρὸς αὐτόν· ὁ δὲ ἑνὶ ἑκάστῳ αὐτῶν τὰς χεῖρας ἐπιτιθεὶς ἐθεράπευεν αὐτούς

verses.english: And daimons also were coming out from many, crying out and saying: "You are the son of God." And rebuking them, he did not allow them to speak.
verses.greek: ἐξήρχετο δὲ καὶ δαιμόνια ἀπὸ πολλῶν, κράζοντα καὶ λέγοντα ὅτι σὺ εἶ ὁ υἱός τοῦ θεοῦ. καὶ ἐπιτιμῶν οὐκ εἴα αὐτὰ λαλεῖν

verses.english: And he said to them: "I must also announce the kingdom of God to the other cities, because for this I was sent."
verses.greek: ὁ δὲ εἶπεν πρὸς αὐτοὺς ὅτι καὶ ταῖς ἑτέραις πόλεσιν εὐαγγελίσασθαί με δεῖ τὴν βασιλείαν τοῦ θεοῦ, ὅτι ἐπὶ τοῦτο ἀπεστάλην

verses.english: And it happened, while the crowd pressed upon him to hear the word of God, he was standing by the lake of Gennesaret.
verses.greek: Ἐγένετο δὲ ἐν τῷ τὸν ὄχλον ἐπικεῖσθαι αὐτῷ καὶ ἀκούειν τὸν λόγον τοῦ θεοῦ, καὶ αὐτὸς ἦν ἑστὼς παρὰ τὴν λίμνην Γεννησαρέτ.

verses.english: And he saw two boats standing by the lake; but the fishermen had gone out of them and were washing their nets.
verses.greek: καὶ εἶδεν δύο πλοῖα ἑστῶτα παρὰ τὴν λίμνην· οἱ δὲ ἁλιεῖς ἀπ᾿ αὐτῶν ἀποβάντες ἔπλυνον τὰ δίκτυα.

verses.english: And entering into one of the boats, which was Simon's, he asked him to put out a little from the land. And sitting down, he was teaching the crowds from the boat.
verses.greek: ἐμβὰς δὲ εἰς ἓν τῶν πλοίων, ὃ ἦν Σίμωνος, ἠρώτησεν αὐτὸν ἀπὸ τῆς γῆς ἐπαναγαγεῖν ὀλίγον· καθίσας δὲ ἐκ τοῦ πλοίου ἐδίδασκεν τοὺς ὄχλους.

verses.english: And when he ceased speaking, he said to Simon: "Put out into the deep and let down your nets for a catch."
verses.greek: Ὡς δὲ ἐπαύσατο λαλῶν, εἶπεν πρὸς τὸν Σίμωνα· Ἐπανάγαγε εἰς τὸ βάθος καὶ χαλάσατε τὰ δίκτυα ὑμῶν εἰς ἄγραν.

verses.english: And Simon answering said: "Master, through the whole night we toiled and took nothing; but at your word I will let down the net."
verses.greek: καὶ ἀποκριθεὶς Σίμων εἶπεν· Ἐπιστάτα, δι᾽ ὅλης νυκτὸς κοπιάσαντες οὐδὲν ἐλάβομεν, ἐπὶ δὲ τῷ ῥήματί σου χαλάσω τὰ δίκτυα.

verses.english: And having done this, they enclosed a great multitude of fishes; and their nets were breaking.
verses.greek: καὶ τοῦτο ποιήσαντες συνέκλεισαν πλῆθος ἰχθύων πολύ, διερρήσσετο δὲ τὰ δίκτυα αὐτῶν.

verses.english: But Simon Peter, seeing it, fell down at the knees of Jesus, saying: "Depart from me, for I am a sinful man, Lord."
verses.greek: ἰδὼν δὲ Σίμων Πέτρος προσέπεσεν τοῖς γόνασιν Ἰησοῦ λέγων· Ἔξελθε ἀπ᾿ ἐμοῦ, ὅτι ἀνὴρ ἁμαρτωλός εἰμι, κύριε.

verses.english: And Jesus said to Simon: "Fear not; from now on you shall be catching men."
verses.greek: εἶπεν δὲ πρὸς τὸν Σίμωνα ὁ Ἰησοῦς· Μὴ φοβοῦ· ἀπὸ τοῦ νῦν ἀνθρώπους ἔσῃ ζωγρῶν

verses.english: And having brought the boats to the land, they left all and followed him.
verses.greek: καὶ καταγαγόντες τὰ πλοῖα ἐπὶ τὴν γῆν ἀφέντες πάντα ἠκολούθησαν αὐτῷ

verses.english: And it happened, while he was in one of the cities, behold, a man full of leprosy. And seeing Jesus, he fell on his face and begged him, saying: "Lord, if you will, you are able to cleanse me."
verses.greek: Καὶ ἐγένετο ἐν τῷ εἶναι αὐτὸν ἐν μιᾷ τῶν πόλεων καὶ ἰδοὺ ἀνὴρ πλήρης λέπρας· εἰδὼν δὲ τὸν Ἰησοῦν, πεσὼν ἐπὶ πρόσωπον ἐδεήθη αὐτοῦ λέγων· Κύριε, ἐὰν θέλῃς δύνασαί με καθαρίσαι

verses.english: And stretching out his hand, he touched him, saying: "I will; be cleansed." And immediately the leprosy departed from him.
verses.greek: καὶ ἐκτείνας τὴν χεῖρα ἥψατο αὐτοῦ λέγων· Θέλω, καθαρίσθητι· καὶ εὐθέως ἡ λέπρα ἀπῆλθεν ἀπ᾿ αὐτοῦ

verses.english: And he commanded him to tell no one: "But go, show yourself to the priest and offer for your cleansing according as Moses commanded, for a testimony to them."
verses.greek: καὶ αὐτὸς παρήγγειλεν αὐτῷ μηδενὶ εἰπεῖν, ἀλλὰ ἀπελθὼν δεῖξον σεαυτὸν τῷ ἱερεῖ καὶ προσένεγκε περὶ τοῦ καθαρισμοῦ σου καθὼς προσέταξεν Μωϋσῆς, εἰς μαρτύριον αὐτοῖς

notes.term: What is to us and to you (τί ἡμῖν καὶ σοί - ti hēmin kai soi)
notes.explanation: This is a literal translation of a Hebraic idiom denoting a disconnect in purpose or authority. The term "Nazarene" is excluded here, as it is absent in the earliest Marcionite/Jamesian witnesses, likely to decouple the Savior from a specific geographical/biological origin.

Transliterated as 'daimon' to preserve the distinction from divine messengers (angeloi). In the Essene/Zoroastrian dualistic framework, this is an adversarial spirit-entity—a manifestation of the Spirit of Darkness that the Divine Human must forcefully subdue. The daimon recognizes the Savior's identity through pneumatic authority.

notes.term: ὁ ἅγιος τοῦ θεοῦ (ho hagios tou theou)
notes.explanation: The confession of the spirit is clinical; it recognizes the quality of holiness—the set-apart nature—of the Messenger.

The term "Nazarene" is omitted in verse 34, following the earliest Marcionite and Jamesian witnesses. This decoupling serves to present the Messenger as a purely pneumatic figure rather than one defined by a specific geographical or biological origin.

notes.term: Kingdom of God (τὴν βασιλείαν τοῦ θεοῦ - tēn basileian tou theou)
notes.explanation: This phrase is a hallmark of the Lukan/Proto-Lukan layer. It identifies the "Actual Jesus" not as a personal savior, but as the herald of a new spiritual order. The "Kingdom of God" is the central thematic marker of the Jamesian Protograph, denoting the internal spiritual order that supersedes the physical administration of the world.
The Greek identifies the Messenger's primary function as an announcer or herald of a new governance.

notes.term: Catching Men (ἀνθρώπους ἔσῃ ζωγρῶν - anthrōpous esē zōgrōn)
notes.explanation: Literally "catching alive." The specific Lukan vocation narrative (5:1-11) is retained as a Jamesian original. Unlike the abrupt Markan calling, this emphasizes a "miraculous catch," establishing the dependence of the disciples on the Divine Influx rather than their own merit.
The "leaving of all" is a fundamental Ebionite requirement, establishing the socio-economic baseline of the community.
In the Jamesian layer, the cleansing of the leper is a forensic proof of the Spirit's power to restore the human "vessel" to its correct internal state.

notes.term: Moses Commanded (καθὼς προσέταξε Μωυσῆς - kathōs prosetaxe Mōysēs)
notes.explanation: The preservation of this reference (5:14) is critical. It shows the Jamesian Jesus upholding the Law as a "testimony," prioritizing the internal reality of cleansing while maintaining external continuity with the Torah.
The singular "priest" denotes the specific legal officer required for the validation of the cure.

additional_explanation.title: The Mechanics of Authority
additional_explanation.content: The transition from the Incipit to the calling of the disciples represents the "Historical Bricolage" stage of the movement. In this second chapter, we see the primary mission defined as a "direct spiritual battle against the forces of disorder."

points.title: The Rejection of Bio-History
points.explanation: By initiating the narrative with the Capernaum healings (4:31) and moving the Nazareth rejection to a secondary position, the Jamesian Protograph establishes Jesus's authority through deeds of power rather than Davidic genealogy.

points.title: The Fisher of the Poor
points.explanation: The choice of Simon, a manual laborer (Ebionite/Poor), identifies the movement's target demographic. The "multitude of fishes" serves as a physical manifestation of the boundless nature of divine providence, intended for a community struggling after the physical destruction of the Temple.

points.title: The Forensic Healing
points.explanation: The cleansing of the leper (5:12-14) is a paradigmatic example of the "Divine Human in Ultimates." Jesus does not merely speak; he touches the leper. This physical contact—forbidden by ritual law—shatters the corrupt external forms to restore the inner person.

additional_explanation.conclusion: This chapter solidifies the Jamesian view that the Kingdom is entered not through a confession of faith in a "Cosmic Christ," but through active participation in the restoration of humanity through "Works of Love."

chapters.title: Proto-Luke Chapter 3
chapters.preamble: This stratum represents the foundational "Constitution" of the Jerusalem community, focusing on the economic and spiritual reversal characteristic of the Ebionite (Poor) ethos. The narrative bypasses the Judean institutional markers and moves directly to the mountain—the place of new law-giving—where the "Royal Law" is articulated.

verses.english: And it happened in those days, he went out to the mountain to pray, and he was spending the night in the prayer of God.
verses.greek: Ἐγένετο δὲ ἐν ταῖς ἡμέραις ταύταις ἐξελθεῖν αὐτὸν εἰς τὸ ὄρος προσεύξασθαι, καὶ ἦν διανυκτερεύων ἐν τῇ προσευχῇ τοῦ θεοῦ.

verses.english: And when it became day, he called his disciples, and choosing twelve from them, whom also he named emissaries.
verses.greek: καὶ ὅτε ἐγένετο ἡμέρα, προσεφώνησεν τοὺς μαθητὰς αὐτοῦ, καὶ ἐκλεξάμενος ἀπ᾿ αὐτῶν δώδεκα, οὓς καὶ ἀποστόλους ὠνόμασεν.

verses.english: And coming down with them, he stood on a level place, and a great crowd of his disciples, and a great multitude of the people from all Judea and Jerusalem and the coast of Tyre and Sidon, who came to hear him and to be healed from their diseases; and those troubled by unclean spirits were being healed. And all the crowd was seeking to touch him, because power was going out from him and healing all.
verses.greek: Καὶ καταβὰς μετ᾿ αὐτῶν ἔστη ἐπὶ τόπου πεδινοῦ, καὶ ὄχλος πολὺς μαθητῶν αὐτοῦ, καὶ πλῆθος πολὺ τοῦ λαοῦ ἀπὸ πάσης τῆς Ἰουδαίας καὶ Ἱερουσαλήμ καὶ τῆς παραλίου Τύρου καὶ Σιδῶνος, οἳ ἦλθον ἀκοῦσαι αὐτοῦ καὶ ἰαθῆναι ἀπὸ τῶν νόσων αὐτῶν· καὶ οἱ ἐνοχλούμενοι ἀπὸ πνευμάτων ἀκαθάρτων ἐθεραπεύοντο. καὶ πᾶς ὁ ὄχλος ἐζήτουν ἅπτεσθαι αὐτοῦ, ὅτι δύναμις παρ᾿ αὐτοῦ ἐξήρχετο καὶ ἰᾶτο πάντας.

verses.english: And he, lifting up his eyes upon his disciples, said: "Blessed are you, the poor, for yours is the kingdom of God."
verses.greek: Καὶ αὐτὸς ἐπάρας τοὺς ὀφθαλμοὺς αὐτοῦ εἰς τοὺς μαθητὰς αὐτοῦ ἔλεγεν· Μακάριοι οἱ πτωχοί, ὅτι ὑμετέρα ἐστὶν ἡ βασιλεία τοῦ θεοῦ.

verses.english: Blessed are you who hunger now, for you shall be satisfied. Blessed are you who weep now, for you shall laugh.
verses.greek: μακάριοι οἱ πεινῶντες νῦν, ὅτι χορτασθήσεσθε. μακάριοι οἱ κλαίοντες νῦν, ὅτι γελάσετε.

verses.english: Blessed are you when men hate you, and when they exclude you and reproach you and cast out your name as evil, on account of the son of man. Rejoice in that day and leap for joy, for behold, your reward is great in the heaven; for according to the same things their fathers did to the prophets.
verses.greek: μακάριοί ἐστε ὅταν μισήσωσιν ὑμᾶς οἱ ἄνθρωποι καὶ ὅταν ἀφορίσωσιν ὑμᾶς καὶ ὀνειδίσωσιν καὶ ἐκβάλωσιν τὸ ὄνομα ὑμῶν ὡς πονηρὸν ἕνεκα τοῦ υἱοῦ τοῦ ἀνθρώπου· χάρητε ἐν ἐκείνῃ τῇ ἡμέρᾳ καὶ σκιρτήσατε, ἰδοὺ γὰρ ὁ μισθὸς ὑμῶν πολὺς ἐν τῷ οὐρανῷ· κατὰ τὰ αὐτὰ γὰρ ἐποίουν τοῖς προφήταις οἱ πατέρες αὐτῶν.

verses.english: But woe to you, the rich, for you have received your consolation.
verses.greek: Πλὴν οὐαὶ ὑμῖν τοῖς πλουσίοις, ὅτι ἀπέχετε τὴν παράκλησιν ὑμῶν.

verses.english: Woe to you who are full now, for you shall hunger. Woe, those laughing now, for you shall mourn and weep. Woe when all men speak well of you.
verses.greek: οὐαὶ ὑμῖν, οἱ ἐμπεπλησμένοι νῦν, ὅτι πεινάσετε. οὐαὶ, οἱ γελῶντες νῦν, ὅτι πενθήσετε καὶ κλαύσετε. οὐαὶ ὅταν ὑμᾶς καλῶς εἴπωσιν πάντες οἱ ἄνθρωποι.

verses.english: But I say to you who listen: Love your enemies, bless those who hate you, and pray for those who mistreat you.
verses.greek: Ἀλλὰ ὑμῖν λέγω τοῖς ἀκούουσιν· ἀγαπᾶτε τοὺς ἐχθροὺς ὑμῶν, εὐλογεῖτε τοὺς μισοῦντας ὑμᾶς καὶ προσεύχεσθε περὶ τῶν ἐπηρεαζόντων ὑμᾶς.

verses.english: To the one striking you on the jaw, offer also the other; and from the one taking your outer-garment, do not withhold the tunic.
verses.greek: τῷ τύπτοντί σε ἐπὶ τὴν σιαγόνα πάρεχε καὶ τὴν ἄλλην, καὶ ἀπὸ τοῦ αἴροντός σου τὸ ἱμάτιον καὶ τὸν χιτῶνα μὴ κωλύσῃς.

verses.english: And as you wish that men should do to you, do likewise to them.
verses.greek: καὶ καθὼς θέλετε ἵνα ποιῶσιν ὑμῖν οἱ ἄνθρωποι, ποιεῖτε αὐτοῖς ὁμοίως.

verses.english: But love your enemies and do good and lend, despairing of nothing; and your reward will be great, and you will be sons of the Most High, for he is kind to the ungrateful and evil.
verses.greek: πλὴν ἀγαπᾶτε τοὺς ἐχθροὺς ὑμῶν καὶ ἀγαθοποιεῖτε καὶ δανίζετε μηδὲν ἀπελπίζοντες· καὶ ἔσται ὁ μισθὸς ὑμῶν πολύς, καὶ ἔσεσθε υἱοὶ ὑψίστου.

verses.english: And why do you call me 'Lord, Lord,' and do not do what I say?
verses.greek: Τί δέ με καλεῖτε· Κύριε κύριε, καὶ οὐ ποιεῖτε ἃ λέγω;

verses.english: Everyone coming to me and hearing my words and doing them—I will show you whom he is like.
verses.greek: πᾶς ὁ ἐρχόμενος πρός με καὶ ἀκούων μου τῶν λόγων καὶ ποιῶν αὐτούς, ὑποδείξω ὑμῖν τίνι ἐστὶν ὅμοιος.

verses.english: He is like a man building a house, who dug and deepened and laid a foundation upon the rock; and when a flood happened, the river broke against that house and was not strong enough to shake it, because it was built well.
verses.greek: ὅμοιός ἐστιν ἀνθρώπῳ οἰκοδομοῦντι οἰκίαν ὃς ἔσκαψεν καὶ ἐβάθυνεν καὶ ἔθηκεν θεμέλιον ἐπὶ τὴν πέτραν· πλημμύρης δὲ γενομένης προσέρηξεν ὁ ποταμὸς τῇ οἰκίᾳ ἐκείνῃ, καὶ οὐκ ἴσχυσεν σαλεῦσαι αὐτὴν διὰ τὸ καλῶς οἰκοδομῆσθαι αὐτήν.

verses.english: But the one hearing and not doing is like a man building a house upon the ground without a foundation, against which the river broke, and immediately it collapsed, and the crash of that house was great.
verses.greek: ὁ δὲ ἀκούσας καὶ μὴ ποιήσας ὅμοιός ἐστιν ἀνθρώπῳ οἰκοδομήσαντι οἰκίαν ἐπὶ τὴν γῆν χωρὶς θεμελίου, ᾗ προσέρηξεν ὁ ποταμός, καὶ εὐθὺς συνέπεσεν καὶ ἐγένετο τὸ ῥῆγμα τῆς οἰκίας ἐκείνης μέγα.

notes.explanation: The dry fact of the Greek is "sent ones" or "emissaries." This reconstruction avoids the later high-church "Apostle" to reflect the functional role of these men as agents of the Kingdom.
In the Jamesian framework, the mountain is the site of the new "Opposition Priesthood" law-giving, mirroring Sinai but internalizing the command.
Unlike the Matthean "poor in spirit," this stratum uses the literal term for material poverty. This aligns with the "Jamesian Layer" which identifies the followers as the Ebionim (The Poor).

This forensic "Woe" is unique to the Lukan/Proto-Lukan stratum and is a primary marker of Jamesian theology, which views wealth as a consolidation of the current corrupt age. The "Woes" are restored as an integral part of the "Charter of the Hebrews." They define the Kingdom by what it excludes—the material security and social status of the Roman-era elite.
Used here in its forensic sense of a legal "advocacy" or "comfort" that has already been exhausted by material wealth.
This refers to the inner garment. The command is to allow the total stripping of the external self to preserve the internal "Royal Law" of love.

notes.term: Despairing of nothing (μηδὲν ἀπελπίζοντες - mēden apelpizontes)
notes.explanation: A difficult Greek phrase. In the Jamesian context, it implies an absolute reliance on Divine Influx rather than a calculated "return" on a loan, shunning the commercial logic of the state.

This present participle denotes continuous, active loyalty. This is the cornerstone of the "Jamesian Layer"—that "Faith-Alone" (the Pauline Layer) is insufficient without the Ma'asim (Works of Love). The imperative "do" is the active verb governing the Golden Rule (6:31), which Jamesian theology regards as the "Law of Liberty."
In this stratum, the foundation is not a creed or a church hierarchy (Orthodoxy Layer), but the internal practice of the words of Christ in ultimates—actual ethical conduct.
The "Rock" in this stratum is not an institutional figure (Peter) but the "words" of the Messenger himself, providing the only stable foundation against the debris of the material age.
The reference to "their fathers" and the "prophets" is often viewed as a later addition to tether the "Poor" to the old national history; the Protograph focuses on the immediate pneumatic reward.

The reconstruction prioritizes 'those who hate you' over the canonical 'those who curse you' (καταρωμένους). This reflects the forensic reality of the Jamesian community facing active social and legal opposition from the established elite.
'Mistreat' captures the sense of malicious prosecution or active harassment. The command establishes the 'Royal Law of Liberty' as a non-resistant internal governor.

additional_explanation.title: The Charter of the Hebrews
additional_explanation.content: Chapter 3 of the Jamesian Protograph establishes the movement's radical separation from both the Pauline pneumatic autonomy and the later Roman state-stabilization.

points.title: Economic Reversal
points.explanation: By retaining the "Woes" (6:24-26), Proto-Luke defines the Kingdom as a physical and social reality where the hierarchy of the world is inverted. This is a direct attack on any "Orthodoxy" that seeks to make the movement compatible with Roman wealth or status.

points.title: The Golden Rule as Law
points.explanation: Verse 31 is presented not as a suggestion, but as the definition of the "Royal Law of Liberty." It functions as the internal governor of the "Opposition Priesthood," requiring the follower to act from the neighbor's perspective.

points.title: The Rejection of Lip-Service
points.explanation: The concluding parable of the two builders (6:46-49) serves as a forensic warning against the Pauline tendency to prioritize the "confession of the mouth" (Romans 10:9) over the "work of the hands." For the Jamesian Jesus, the house (the community) only stands if it is built on the ultimates of action.

chapters.title: Proto-Luke Chapter 4
chapters.preamble: This section moves from the establishment of the ethical constitution (the Sermon on the Plain) into the manifestation of the "Divine Human in Ultimates." Here, authority is validated through works of restoration and a direct confrontation with the suffering of the poor and marginalized.

verses.english: After he had ended all his words in the hearing of the people, he entered into Capernaum.
verses.greek: Ἐπεὶ δὲ ἐπλήρωσεν πάντα τὰ ῥήματα αὐτοῦ εἰς τὰς ἀκοὰς τοῦ λαοῦ, εἰσῆλθεν εἰς Καφαρναούμ.

verses.english: And a certain centurion's slave, who was dear to him, was sick and at the point of death.
verses.greek: Ἑκατοντάρχου δέ τινος δοῦλος κακῶς ἔχων ἤμελλεν τελευτᾶν, ὃς ἦν αὐτῷ ἔντιμος.

verses.english: And when he was now not far from the house, the centurion sent friends to him, saying to him: "Lord, trouble not yourself, for I am not worthy that you should enter under my roof. Therefore neither did I think myself worthy to come to you; but say in a word, and let my slave be healed."
verses.greek: ἤδη δὲ αὐτοῦ οὐ μακρὰν ἀπέχοντος ἀπὸ τῆς οἰκίας ἔπεμψεν φίλους ὁ ἑκατοντάρχης λέγων αὐτῷ· Κύριε, μὴ σκύλλου, οὐ γὰρ ἱκανός εἰμι ἵνα ὑπὸ τὴν στέγην μου εἰσέλθῃς· διὸ οὐδὲ ἐμαυτὸν ἠξίωσα πρὸς σὲ ἐλθεῖν· ἀλλὰ εἰπὲ λόγῳ, καὶ ἰαθήτω ὁ παῖς μου.

verses.english: And when Jesus heard these things, he wondered at him, and turned and said to the crowd following him, "I tell you, I have not found such faith, no, not in Israel."
verses.greek: ἀκούσας δὲ ταῦτα ὁ Ἰησοῦς ἐθαύμασεν αὐτόν, καὶ στραφεὶς τῷ ἀκολουθοῦντι αὐτῷ ὄχλῳ εἶπεν· Λέγω ὑμῖν, οὐδὲ ἐν τῷ Ἰσραὴλ τοσαύτην πίστιν εὗρον.

verses.english: And they that were sent, returning to the house, found the slave whole.
verses.greek: Καὶ ὑποστρέψαντες εἰς τὸν οἶκον οἱ πεμφθέντες εὗρον τὸν δοῦλον ὑγιαίνοντα.

verses.english: And it came to pass the day after, that he went into a city called Nain; and many of his disciples went with him, and a great crowd.
verses.greek: Καὶ ἐγένετο ἐν τῇ ἑξῆς ἐπορεύθη εἰς πόλιν καλουμένην Ναΐν, καὶ συνεπορεύοντο αὐτῷ οἱ μαθηταὶ αὐτοῦ καὶ ὄχλος πολύς.

verses.english: Now when he came near to the gate of the city, behold, there was a dead man carried out, the only son of his mother, and she was a widow.
verses.greek: ὡς δὲ ἤγγισεν τῇ πύλῃ τῆς πόλεως, καὶ ἰδοὺ ἐξεκομίζετο τεθνηκώς, υἱὸς μονογενὴς τῇ μητρὶ αὐτοῦ, καὶ αὐτὴ ἦν χήρα, καὶ ὄχλος τῆς πόλεως ἱκανὸς ἦν σὺν αὐτῇ.

verses.english: And when the Lord saw her, he had compassion on her and said to her: "Do not weep."
verses.greek: καὶ ἰδὼν αὐτὴν ὁ κύριος ἐσπλαγχνίσθη ἐπ᾿ αὐτῇ καὶ εἶπεν αὐτῇ· Μὴ κλαῖε.

verses.english: And he came and touched the bier, and they that bore him stood still. And he said, "Young man, I say to you, arise."
verses.greek: καὶ προσελθὼν ἥψατο τῆς σοροῦ, οἱ δὲ βαστάζοντες ἔστησαν, καὶ εἶπεν· Νεανίσκε, σοὶ λέγω, ἐγέρθητι.

verses.english: And he that was dead sat up and began to speak. And he delivered him to his mother.
verses.greek: καὶ ἀνεκάθισεν ὁ νεκρὸς καὶ ἤρξατο λαλεῖν, καὶ ἔδωκεν αὐτὸν τῇ μητρὶ αὐτοῦ.

verses.english: And fear took hold of all, and they glorified God, saying, "A great prophet has appeared among us," and, "God has visited his people."
verses.greek: ἔλαβεν δὲ φόβος πάντας καὶ ἐδόξαζον τὸν θεὸν λέγοντες ὅτι Προφήτης μέγας ἠγέρθη ἐν ἡμῖν, καὶ ὅτι ἐπεσκέψατο ὁ θεὸς τὸν λαὸν αὐτοῦ.

verses.english: And John, calling to him two of his disciples, sent them to Jesus, saying, "Are you the one coming, or do we look for another?"
verses.greek: Καὶ ἀπήγγειλαν Ἰωάννῃ οἱ μαθηταὶ αὐτοῦ περὶ πάντων τούτων. καὶ προσκαλεσάμενος δύο τινὰς τῶν μαθητῶν αὐτοῦ ὁ Ἰωάννης ἔπεμψεν πρὸς τὸν κύριον λέγων· Σὺ εἶ ὁ ἐρχόμενος ἢ ἄλλον προσδοκῶμεν;

verses.english: Then Jesus answering said to them, "Go your way, and tell John what things you have seen and heard; how that the blind see, the lame walk, the lepers are cleansed, the deaf hear, the dead are raised, and to the poor the good news is announced."
verses.greek: καὶ ἀποκριθεὶς εἶπεν αὐτοῖς· Πορευθέντες ἀπαγγείλατε Ἰωάννῃ ἃ εἴδετε καὶ ἠκούσατε· τυφλοὶ ἀναβλέπουσιν, χωλοὶ περιπατοῦσιν, λεπροὶ καθαρίζονται καὶ κωφοὶ ἀκούουσιν, νεκροὶ ἐγείρονται, πτωχοὶ εὐαγγελίζονται·

verses.english: And blessed is he, whoever shall not be offended in me.
verses.greek: καὶ μακάριός ἐστιν ὃς ἐὰν μὴ σκανδαλισθῇ ἐν ἐμοί.

verses.english: "This is he, of whom it is written: 'Behold, I send my messenger before your face, who shall prepare your way before you.'"
verses.greek: οὗτός ἐστιν περὶ οὗ γέγραπται· Ἰδοὺ ἀποστέλλω τὸν ἄγγελόν μου πρὸ προσώπου σου, ὃς κατασκευάσει τὴν ὁδόν σου ἔμπροσθέν σου.

verses.english: "For I say to you, among those that are born of women there is not a greater prophet than John the Baptist; but he that is least in the kingdom of God is greater than he."
verses.greek: λέγω ὑμῖν, μείζων ἐν γεννητοῖς γυναικῶν Ἰωάννου οὐδείς ἐστιν· ὁ δὲ μικρότερος ἐν τῇ βασιλείᾳ τοῦ θεοῦ μείζων αὐτοῦ ἐστιν.

verses.english: And, behold, a woman in the city, who was a sinner, when she knew that Jesus sat at meat in the Pharisee's house, brought an alabaster box of ointment.
verses.greek: Καὶ ἰδοὺ γυνὴ ἥτις ἦν ἐν τῇ πόλει ἁμαρτωλός, καὶ ἐπιγνοῦσα ὅτι κατάκειται ἐν τῇ οἰκίᾳ τοῦ Φαρισαίου, κομίσασα ἀλάβαστρον μύρου.

verses.english: And she stood at his feet behind him weeping, and began to wash his feet with tears, and did wipe them with the hairs of her head, and kissed his feet, and anointed them with the ointment.
verses.greek: καὶ στᾶσα ὀπίσω παρὰ τοὺς πόδας αὐτοῦ κλαίουσα τοῖς δάκρυσιν ἤρξατο βρέχειν τοὺς πόδας αὐτοῦ καὶ ταῖς θριξὶν τῆς κεφαλῆς αὐτῆς ἐξέμασσεν καὶ κατεφίλει τοὺς πόδας αὐτοῦ καὶ ἤλειφεν τῷ μύρῳ.

verses.english: "Wherefore I say to you, her sins, which are many, are forgiven; for she loved much."
verses.greek: οὗ χάριν λέγω σοι, ἀφέωνται αἱ ἁμαρτίαι αὐτῆς αἱ πολλαί, ὅτι ἠγάπησεν πολύ.

verses.english: And he said to her, "Your sins are forgiven."
verses.greek: εἶπεν δὲ αὐτῇ· Ἀφέωνταί σου αἱ ἁμαρτίαι.

verses.english: And he said to the woman, "Your faith has saved you; go in peace."
verses.greek: εἶπεν δὲ πρὸς τὴν γυναῖκα· ἡ πίστις σου σέσωκέν σε· πορεύου εἰς εἰρήνην.

notes.explanation: Strictly maintained as "slave." This is a clinical socioeconomic fact of the Roman military hierarchy; softening it to "servant" obscures the power dynamic inherent in the centurion's confession of authority.
Passive imperative: "let him be healed." The centurion recognizes that the Savior's word operates as a forensic command over physical Ultimates.
Tertullian and Epiphanius both preserve this word order, which places the emphasis on the lack of internal spiritual loyalty within the established religious center.
The narrative of the Judean elders interceding for the centurion is absent in the earliest Marcionite witnesses. Its removal emphasizes the direct, unmediated faith of the Gentile officer.
Passive: "be awakened" or "be raised." This term denotes the restoration of the pneumatic force to the biological shell.

Tertullian's Latin (prodiit) suggests Marcion's text may have used a verb meaning "appeared" or "came forth" rather than the canonical "arisen" (ἠγέρθη), possibly to avoid a specific physicalist resurrection theology at this early stage.

The identification of Jesus as a prophet is a hallmark of the Jamesian layer, grounding him in the historical prophetic tradition of Israel rather than the later "Cosmic Christ" of Paul. The crowd's recognition of a "Great Prophet" identifies the Messenger within the context of the promised "Prophet like Moses," reinforcing the Jamesian community's continuity with the high prophetic tradition.

The good news is specifically announced to the materially poor, reinforcing the Ebionite "Theology of Reversal" found in the previous chapter. The literal "poor" receive the formal announcement of the new governance. In the Jamesian Protograph, this is the clinical objective of the mission, proving the arrival of the new age through the reversal of material lack.

Within the Jamesian matrix, these "works" serve as forensic proof of divine authority to remit sins and restore the "internal state" of humanity. In the Jerusalem matrix, these works are forensic evidence of the Divine Human's authority over the material "Ultimates" of death and disease.
While canonical Luke includes a lengthy discourse on John the Baptist, the Protograph focuses on the direct "Works of Love" as the sole validator of the mission.
Translated as "messenger" to denote the functional role of the figure (John), avoiding the supernatural baggage of "angel."
Tertullian and the Adamantius Dialogue confirm this wording for Marcion's text, which tethers the movement to the "Old Testament" prophetic modulo while asserting Jesus as the fulfillment.
The inclusion of the "sinful woman" highlights the Jamesian focus on proactive reconciliation over ritual purity.
This confirms the "Works of Love" layer—that forgiveness and salvation are the result of the internal reality of love manifested in action (Ma'asim).

notes.term: Your faith has saved you (ἡ πίστις σου σέσωκέν σε)
notes.explanation: In this context, "faith" is not the Pauline intellectual assent, but a "Faith-Loyalty" that compels the woman to act with devotion.

additional_explanation.title: The Mechanics of Restoration
additional_explanation.content: This chapter of the Protograph consolidates the authority of Jesus through the restoration of the marginalized. In each instance, Jesus bypasses the established religious hierarchy to deal directly with "The Poor" and the "Outcast."

points.title: The Centurion's Slave
points.explanation: The focus is on Distance and Faith. Jesus does not need to be physically present; his authority resides in his "Word." This aligns with the pneumatic view that divine authority flows from the "Spirit" regardless of biological or material proximity.

points.title: The Widow's Son
points.explanation: By touching the bier, Jesus shatters the Sadducean laws of ritual pollution. He asserts that Love is the "Royal Law" that supersedes the "debris" of external ritual.

points.title: The Baptist's Inquiry
points.explanation: Jesus defines his identity through function, not genealogy. He tells John's messengers to report the "Ultimates"—the physical changes in the poor and sick—which serve as the "fingerprint" of the Divine Influx.

points.title: The Woman who Loved
points.explanation: This is the primary polemic against the "State Stabilization" (Orthodoxy) of the Pharisees. While the host focuses on the "rules" of hospitality, the woman focuses on the "inner reality" of love. Jesus rewards the latter, establishing that the "Kingdom" is entered through the internal fulfillment of the Law.

chapters.title: Proto-Luke Chapter 5
chapters.preamble: This section transitions from the public ethical teaching in Galilee into the internal definition of the "New Community"—a family defined not by biological descent (flesh and blood), but by active loyalty to the Word. In this stratum, the narrative rejects the authority of the biological family of the messenger, aligning with the Jamesian focus on Ma'asim (Works of Love) as the sole marker of the "Hebrew" identity.

verses.english: And it happened afterward, that he made his way through city and village, announcing and telling the good news of the kingdom of God; and the twelve were with him,
verses.greek: Καὶ ἐγένετο ἐν τῷ καθεξῆς καὶ αὐτὸς διώδευεν κατὰ πόλιν καὶ κώμην κηρύσσων καὶ εὐαγγελιζόμενος τὴν βασιλείαν τοῦ θεοῦ, καὶ οἱ δώδεκα σὺν αὐτῷ,

verses.english: And certain women who had been healed from evil spirits and infirmities, who were ministering to him from their possessions.
verses.greek: Καὶ γυναῖκές τινες αἵτινες ἦσαν τεθεραπευμέναι ἀπὸ πνευμάτων πονηρῶν καὶ ἀσθενειῶν, αἵτινες καὶ διηκόνουν αὐτῷ ἀπὸ τῶν ὑπαρχόντων αὐταῖς.

verses.english: "No one having lit a lamp covers it with a vessel or puts it under a bed, but puts it on a lampstand, so that those entering may see the light."
verses.greek: Οὐδεὶς δὲ λύχνον ἅψας καλύπτει αὐτὸν σκεύει ἢ ὑποκάτω κλίνης τίθησιν, ἀλλ᾽ ἐπὶ λυχνίας τίθησιν, ἵνα οἱ εἰσπορευόμενοι βλέπωσιν τὸ φῶς.

verses.english: "For there is nothing hidden which will not become manifest..."
verses.greek: οὐ γάρ ἐστιν κρυπτὸν ὃ οὐ φανερὸν γενήσεται, οὐδὲ ἀπόκρυφον ὃ οὐ μὴ γνωσθῇ.

verses.english: "Look then how you hear; for whoever has, to him shall be given; and whoever has not, even what he thinks he has shall be taken from him."
verses.greek: βλέπετε οὖν πῶς ἀκούετε· ὃς ἂν γὰρ ἔχῃ, δοθήσεται αὐτῷ, καὶ ὃς ἂν μὴ ἔχῃ, καὶ ὃ δοκεῖ ἔχειν ἀρθήσεται ἀπ᾽ αὐτοῦ.

verses.english: And it was announced to him: "Your mother and your brothers stand outside, wanting to see you."
verses.greek: Ἀπηγγέλη δὲ αὐτῷ· Ἡ μήτηρ σου καὶ οἱ ἀδελφοί σου ἑστήκασιν ἔξω ἰδεῖν θέλοντές σε.

verses.english: But he answering said to them: "Who is my mother and who are my brothers? If not those who hear my words and do them?"
verses.greek: ὁ δὲ ἀποκριθεὶς εἶπεν πρὸς αὐτούς· Τίς μου ἡ μήτηρ καὶ τίνες οἱ ἀδελφοί μου; εἰ μὴ οἱ τὸν λόγον τοῦ θεοῦ ἀκούοντες καὶ ποιοῦντες.

verses.english: And it happened on one of the days... he said to them: "Let us pass over to the other side of the lake."
verses.greek: Ἐγένετο δὲ ἐν μιᾷ τῶν ἡμερῶν καὶ αὐτὸς ἐνέβη εἰς πλοῖον καὶ οἱ μαθηταὶ αὐτοῦ, καὶ εἶπεν πρὸς αὐτούς· Διέλθωμεν εἰς τὸ πέραν τῆς λίμνης· καὶ ἀνήχθησαν.

verses.english: ...And he, being awakened, rebuked the wind and the surging of the water, and they ceased, and there was a calm. And he said to them: "Where is your faith?" And they, being afraid, wondered, saying to one another: "Who then is this, that he commands the winds and the water, and they obey him?"
verses.greek: προσελθόντες δὲ διήγειραν αὐτὸν λέγοντες· Ἐπιστάτα ἐπιστάτα, ἀπολλύμεθα. ὁ δὲ ἐγερθεὶς ἐπετίμησεν τῷ ἀνέμῳ καὶ τῷ κλύδωνι τοῦ ὕδατος· καὶ ἐπαύσαντο, καὶ ἐγένετο γαλήνη. εἶπεν δὲ αὐτοῖς· Ποῦ ἡ πίστις ὑμῶν;

notes.explanation: The Greek implies the acting out of a herald's duty. In the Jamesian context, this "Kingdom" is a present ethical reality manifested in the community of the poor.

Literally "things belonging to them." This highlights the economic substrate of the early movement, where the wealthy were commanded to redistribute their Ultimates to support the mission to the Poor.

The specific list of names (Joanna, Susanna, etc.) found in canonical Luke is absent in this stratum, as the Jamesian core focuses on the functional act of stewardship rather than individual biological identifiers.
Tertullian (4.19.5) and the Protograph prioritize the manifestation of truth in the physical realm. The "Light" is not a private Gnostic secret but the public manifestation of Love.

notes.term: What he thinks he has (ὃ δοκεῖ ἔχειν - ho dokei echein)
notes.explanation: A forensic warning against intellectual "faith" that lacks the weight of actual work. The "Faith-Alone" practitioner (the Pauline Layer) is stripped of the "grace" they believe they possess because it never manifested in the Ultimates of Love.
The arrival of the biological family is notably absent in the Marcionite/Jamesian layer to sharpen the impact of the definition in v. 21.

notes.term: Who is my mother...? (Τίς μου ἡ μήτηρ...)
notes.explanation: Tertullian (4.19.6, 4.19.11) confirms this interrogative opening, which is more polemical than the canonical "My mother and my brothers are..." The reconstruction follows the interrogative variant preserved by Tertullian and Marcion. It serves to decouple the Messenger from biological and biological-Davidic authority, prioritizing pneumatic loyalty.
This present participle is the definitive Jamesian marker. The community is not defined by biological descent from David or the family of Jesus, but by the "Doing" of the internal Law of Love.
Tertullian (4.20.3) uses the Latin "transfretat," emphasizing the crossing into Gentile territory (the "Other Side").

notes.term: Who then is this? (Τίς ἄρα οὗτός ἐστιν;)
notes.explanation: The question highlights the "Divine Human in Ultimates." Jesus is recognized through his command over material elements (wind/water), reflecting the Jamesian view that divine authority must be verifiable in physical effects.

additional_explanation.title: The Ethical vs. Biological Family
additional_explanation.content: This chapter of the Jamesian Protograph establishes the Epistemology of Doing.

points.title: Rejection of the Flesh
points.explanation: By defining his "mother and brothers" strictly as those who do his words (8:21), Jesus shatters the dynastic expectations of the biological family. This represents a primary rift with the later "Orthodoxy" (which attempted to re-anchor Jesus in Davidic biology) and the "Pauline Layer" (which sought to replace the physical Jesus with a purely pneumatic "Cosmic Christ").

points.title: The 'Hidden' Truth
points.explanation: The "Lamp on a Stand" (8:16) serves as a polemic against the Gnostic impulse to hide truth within the "internal mind." For the Jamesian Jesus, if a truth is not "lit" (manifested in external conduct), it does not exist.

points.title: Command over Nature
points.explanation: The calming of the storm (8:24-25) is the "Fingerprint of Influx." It proves that the "Actual Jesus" is not a spirit-phantom but the master of the material ultimates. The wind and water represent the chaotic "Proprium" (self-love) of humanity, which can only be stilled by the internal authority of the Divine Human.

chapters.title: Proto-Luke Chapter 6
chapters.preamble: This section moves from the crossing of the lake into the confrontation with the "Legion" and the miraculous preservation of the poor, concluding with the feeding of the multitude. The narrative emphasizes the "Divine Human in Ultimates" through the specific exercise of authority over non-physical spirits (πνεύματα) and the material needs of the community.

verses.english: And they sailed down to the region of the Gerasenes, which is over against Galilee.
verses.greek: Καὶ κατέπλευσαν εἰς τὴν χώραν τῶν Γερασηνῶν, ἥτις ἐστὶν ἀντιπέρα τῆς Γαλιλαίας.

verses.english: And when he went out upon the land, a certain man from the city met him who had daimons for a long time.
verses.greek: ἐξελθόντι δὲ αὐτῷ ἐπὶ τὴν γῆν ὑπήντησεν ἀνήρ τις ἐκ τῆς πόλεως ἔχων δαιμόνια χρόνῳ ἱκανῷ.

verses.english: And when he saw Jesus, he cried out, and fell down before him, and with a loud voice said: "What is to me and to you, Jesus, Son of the Most High God? I beseech you, do not torment me."
verses.greek: ἰδὼν δὲ τὸν Ἰησοῦν ἀνακράξας προσέπεσεν αὐτῷ καὶ φωνῇ μεγάλῃ εἶπεν· Τί ἐμοὶ καὶ σοί, Ἰησοῦ υἱὲ τοῦ θεοῦ τοῦ ὑψίστου; δέομαί σου, μή με βασανίσῃς.

verses.english: And Jesus asked him: "What is your name?" and he said, "Legion," because many daimons had entered into him.
verses.greek: ἐπηρώτησεν δὲ αὐτὸν ὁ Ἰησοῦς· Τί σοί ἐστιν ὄνομα; ὁ δὲ εἶπεν· Λεγιών, ὅτι δαιμόνια πολλὰ εἰσῆλθεν εἰς αὐτόν.

verses.english: And they were begging him that he would not command them to go away into the abyss.
verses.greek: καὶ παρεκάλουν αὐτὸν ἵνα μὴ ἐπιτάξῃ αὐτοῖς εἰς τὴν ἄβυσσον ἀπελθεῖν.

verses.english: Now there was a herd of many swine feeding on the mountain; and they begged him to allow them to enter into those. And he allowed them. And the daimons, coming out from the man, entered into the swine, and the herd rushed down the cliff into the lake and were drowned.
verses.greek: ἦν δὲ ἐκεῖ ἀγέλη χοίρων ἱκανῶν βοσκομένων ἐν τῷ ὄρει· καὶ παρεκάλουν αὐτὸν ἵνα ἐπιτρέψῃ αὐτοῖς εἰς ἐκείνους εἰσελθεῖν· καὶ ἐπέτρεψεν αὐτοῖς. ἐξελθόντα δὲ τὰ δαιμόνια ἀπὸ τοῦ ἀνθρώπου εἰσῆλθον εἰς τοὺς χοίρους, καὶ ὥρμησεν ἡ ἀγέλη κατὰ τοῦ κρημνοῦ εἰς τὴν λίμνην καὶ ἀπεπνίγη.

verses.english: And it happened, when Jesus returned, the crowd welcomed him, for they were all expecting him. And behold, there came a man whose name was Jairus, and he was a ruler of the assembly; and falling at the feet of Jesus, he was begging him to enter into his house.
verses.greek: Ἐν δὲ τῷ ὑποστρέφειν τὸν Ἰησοῦν ἀπεδέξατο αὐτὸν ὁ ὄχλος· ἦσαν γὰρ πάντες προσδοκῶντες αὐτόν. καὶ ἰδοὺ ἦλθεν ἀνὴρ ᾧ ὄνομα Ἰάϊρος καὶ οὗτος ἄρχων τῆς συναγωγῆς ὑπῆρχεν, καὶ πεσὼν παρὰ τοὺς πόδας Ἰησοῦ παρεκάλει αὐτὸν εἰσελθεῖν εἰς τὸν οἶκον αὐτοῦ.

verses.english: For he had an only daughter, about twelve years old, and she was dying.
verses.greek: ὅτι θυγάτηρ μονογενὴς ἦν αὐτῷ ὡς ἐτῶν δώδεκα καὶ αὐτὴ ἀπέθνησκεν.

verses.english: And a woman being in a flow of blood for twelve years, coming up behind, touched the fringe of his garment, and immediately the flow of her blood stopped.
verses.greek: καὶ γυνὴ οὖσα ἐν ῥύσει αἵματος ἀπὸ ἐτῶν δώδεκα, προσελθοῦσα ὄπισθεν ἥψατο τοῦ κρασπέδου τοῦ ἱματίου αὐτοῦ, καὶ παραχρῆμα ἔστη ἡ ῥύσις τοῦ αἵματος αὐτῆς.

verses.english: And Jesus said: "Who touched me?"
verses.greek: καὶ εἶπεν ὁ Ἰησοῦς· Τίς μου ἥψατο;

verses.english: But Jesus said: "Someone touched me, for I knew power going out from me."
verses.greek: ὁ δὲ Ἰησοῦς εἶπεν· Ἥψατό μού τις, ἐγὼ γὰρ ἔγνων δύναμιν ἐξεληλυθυῖαν ἀπ᾿ ἐμοῦ.

verses.english: And he said to her: "Daughter, your faith has saved you; go in peace."
verses.greek: ὁ δὲ εἶπεν αὐτῇ· Θυγάτηρ, ἡ πίστις σου σέσωκέν σε· πορεύου εἰς εἰρήνην.

verses.english: But he, taking hold of her hand, called, saying: "Child, arise." And her spirit returned, and she arose immediately.
verses.greek: αὐτὸς δὲ κρατήσας τῆς χειρὸς αὐτῆς ἐφώνησεν λέγων· Ἡ παῖς, ἐγείρου. καὶ ἐπέστρεψεν τὸ πνεῦμα αὐτῆς, καὶ ἀνέστη παραχρῆμα.

verses.english: And calling together the twelve, he gave them power and authority over all the daimons and to heal diseases. And he sent them to announce the kingdom of God and to heal.
verses.greek: Συγκαλεσάμενος δὲ τοὺς δώδεκα ἔδωκεν αὐτοῖς δύναμιν καὶ ἐξουσίαν ἐπὶ πάντα τὰ δαιμόνια καὶ νόσους θεραπεύειν· καὶ ἀπέστειλεν αὐτοὺς κηρύσσειν τὴν βασιλείαν τοῦ θεοῦ καὶ ἰᾶσθαι τοὺς ἀσθενεῖς.

verses.english: And he said to them: "Take nothing for the road, neither staff, nor scrip, nor bread, nor silver, nor to have two tunics."
verses.greek: καὶ εἶπεν πρὸς αὐτούς· Μηδὲν αἴρετε εἰς τὴν ὁδόν, μήτε ῥάβδον μήτε πήραν μήτε ἄρτον μήτε ἀργύριον.

verses.english: "And as many as do not receive you, going out from that city, shake off the dust from your feet for a testimony against them."
verses.greek: καὶ ὅσοι ἂν μὴ δέχωνται ὑμᾶς, ἐξερχόμενοι ἀπὸ τῆς πόλεως ἐκείνης τὸν κονιορτὸν ἀπὸ τῶν ποδῶν ὑμῶν ἀποτινάσσετε εἰς μαρτύριον ἐπ᾿ αὐτούς.

verses.english: And going out, they were going through the villages, announcing the good news and healing everywhere.
verses.greek: ἐξερχόμενοι δὲ διήρχοντο κατὰ τὰς κώμας εὐαγγελιζόμενοι καὶ θεραπεύοντες πανταχοῦ.

verses.english: And Herod the tetrarch heard all the things being done and was perplexed because it was said by some that John had been raised from the dead, and by some that Elijah had appeared, and by others that a certain prophet of the ancients had risen.
verses.greek: Ἤκουσεν δὲ Ἡρώδης ὁ τετραάρχης τὰ γινόμενα πάντα καὶ διηπόρει διὰ τὸ λέγεσθαι ὑπό τινων ὅτι Ἰωάννης ἠγέρθη ἐκ νεκρῶν, ὑπό τινων δὲ ὅτι Ἠλίας ἐφάνη, ἄλλων δὲ ὅτι προφήτης τις τῶν ἀρχαίων ἀνέστη.

verses.english: And the emissaries, having returned, described to him as many things as they had done. And taking them, he withdrew privately into a city called Bethsaida. But the crowds, knowing, followed him; and receiving them, he was speaking to them about the kingdom of God, and those having need of healing he was healing.
verses.greek: Καὶ ὑποστρέψαντες οἱ ἀπόστολοι διηγήσαντο αὐτῷ ὅσα ἐποίησαν. καὶ παραλαβὼν αὐτοὺς ὑπεχώρησεν κατ᾿ ἰδίαν εἰς πόλιν καλουμένην Βηθσαϊδά. οἱ δὲ ὄχλοι γνόντες ἠκολούθησαν αὐτῷ· καὶ ἀποδεξάμενος αὐτοὺς ἐλάλει αὐτοῖς περὶ τῆς βασιλείας τοῦ θεοῦ, καὶ τοὺς χρείαν ἔχοντας θεραπείας ἰᾶτο.

verses.english: And the day began to decline; and the twelve came and said to him: "Send away the multitude, that they may go into the villages and country round about, and lodge, and get provisions, for here we are in a desert place."
verses.greek: Ἡ δὲ ἡμέρα ἤρξατο κλίνειν· προσελθόντες δὲ οἱ δώδεκα εἶπαν αὐτῷ· Ἀπόλυσον τὸν ὄχλον, ἵνα πορευθέντες εἰς τὰς κύκλῳ κώμας καὶ ἀγροὺς καταλύσωσιν καὶ εὕρωσιν ἐπισιτισμόν, ὅτι ὧδε ἐν ἐρήμῳ τόπῳ ἐσμέν.

verses.english: But he said to them: "You give them something to eat." And they said: "There are not to us more than five loaves and two fishes." For they were about five thousand men.
verses.greek: εἶπεν δὲ πρὸς αὐτούς· Δότε αὐτοῖς ὑμεῖς φαγεῖν. οἱ δὲ εἶπαν· Οὐκ εἰσὶν ἡμῖν πλεῖον ἢ ἄρτοι πέντε καὶ ἰχθύες δύο. ἦσαν γὰρ ὡσεὶ ἄνδρες πεντακισχίλιοι.

verses.english: And taking the five loaves and the two fishes, looking up into the heaven, he blessed them and broke them.
verses.greek: λαβὼν δὲ τοὺς πέντε ἄρτους καὶ τοὺς δύο ἰχθύας ἀναβλέψας εἰς τὸν οὐρανὸν εὐλόγησεν αὐτοὺς καὶ κατέκλασεν καὶ ἐδίδου τοῖς μαθηταῖς παραθεῖναι τῷ ὄχλῳ.

verses.english: And they ate and were all satisfied.
verses.greek: καὶ ἔφαγον καὶ ἐχορτάσθησαν πάντες.

notes.explanation: Literally "Commander" or "Master." This Lukan term is preferred over "Teacher" (didaskale) to emphasize the clinical authority the Messenger holds over the material environment.
The text identifies the body of water as a "lake" (Galilee), maintaining topographic accuracy over the more generic "sea" (thalassēs) used in Mark.

The source text exhibits variation between Gerasenes, Gadarenes, and Gergesenes. The reading "Gerasenes" is restored based on the most primitive uncial consensus (P75, B, D). Gadarenes and Gergesenes are treated as later geographical corrections.

Transliterated to preserve the distinction from divine messengers (angeloi). In the Essene/Zoroastrian dualistic framework, these are adversarial spirit-entities representing agents of disorder that the Divine Human must forcefully subdue to restore order.

A specific Jamesian/Ebionite term for the place of disorder. The spirits recognize Jesus's authority to impose order over the "chaos" of the material world. The spirit's plea recognizes Jesus's authority to impose order on the chaotic ultimates of the material realm.
Rendered as 'assembly' to denote the functional Judean community center, stripping away later ecclesiastical weight.
This term reflects a clinical forensic fact of Jesus's reception within the social Ultimates of the period.
The use of 'monogenēs' emphasizes the unique status of the child, a detail preserved across early strata.
The imperfect tense indicates a process in action, establishing the necessity for pneumatic intervention.

While some sources view this as a later addition, it is retained here as a marker of the "Divine Human in Ultimates"—where physical contact with the "ultimate" (the garment) results in a spiritual effect (healing).

The primitive interrogative (P75, א, B, L) is restored. The question identifies a specific draw upon the Savior's "power" (dynamin), confirming that pneumatic healing is a clinical expenditure of Spirit.
This refers to the "Divine Influx." The Savior's body acts as a conduit for the restoration of the inner person.
Literally "into peace." This is not a social greeting but a restoration to internal order.
Imperative: "Be awakened" or "rise." The command is addressed to the spirit (πνεῦμα), which is recorded as "returning" (epestrepsen) to the biological shell.
A central Jamesian pillar. The mission is not personal salvation, but the announcement of a new ethical order.
The omission of the staff is a specific Marcionite variant (aligning with Luke 10:4), intended to emphasize total reliance on the Divine Influx rather than physical support.
The omission of "disciples" or "messengers" (apostles) here follows the most concise primitive layer, focusing on the symbolic number of the twelve tribes of Israel.
A forensic act of separation. Shaking off the dust signifies the finality of the testimony against those who reject the new governance.
Consistent with the Jamesian/Essene "wilderness" theology. The feeding of the five thousand serves as a manifestation of "Divine Providence" for the Ebionim (the Poor).
Restored based on the earliest P75 and B witnesses. This specific location grounds the provision narrative in a known historical geography of the poor.

The Adamantius Dialogue occasionally confuses this with "gave thanks" (εὐχαριστεῖ), but "blessed" is the more secure Jamesian reading, reflecting authority over the substance of the bread. The blessing of the bread is the "Divine Bricolage"—multiplication through pneumatic conjunction, replacing the Temple's function as the source of life.

Following verse 9:17, Proto-Luke exhibits the "Great Omission," skipping the material found in Mark 6:45–8:26 (walking on water, etc.). This confirms that Proto-Luke is an independent, coherent narrative that does not rely on Markan scaffolding, but preserves a distinct Jerusalem tradition.
The text distinguishes between being 'raised' (ἠγέρθη) by an external power and 'rising' (ἀνέστη) autonomously, reflecting the pneumatic eschatology of the period.
This term confirms that the Messenger was perceived as the return of the primitive Spirit of the Law, bypassing the institutional debris of the late Second Temple era.

additional_explanation.title: The Mechanics of Provision
additional_explanation.content: Chapter 6 of the Jamesian Protograph establishes the movement's power over both the seen and unseen "Ultimates" of the world.

points.title: The Casting out of Legion
points.explanation: This pericope demonstrates the "Divine Bricolage." Jesus does not argue with the spirits; he imposes divine order upon them. The move into the swine and the subsequent drowning represents the "vastation" of the chaotic self-love (proprium) that leads to destruction.

points.title: The Physical Proofs
points.explanation: The healings in this chapter (the leper, the woman with the hemorrhage, Jairus's daughter) are not mere magic. They are presented as "external confirmations of his authority to heal the soul." By touching the fringe or the hand of a dying girl, the Divine Human grounds his spiritual authority in material reality.

points.title: The Non-Interpolation
points.explanation: Following verse 9:17, Proto-Luke exhibits the "Great Omission," skipping the material found in Mark 6:45–8:26 (walking on water, etc.). This confirms that Proto-Luke is an independent, coherent narrative that does not rely on Markan scaffolding, but preserves a distinct Jerusalem tradition.

points.title: The Feeding of the Poor
points.explanation: The feeding of the five thousand is the "smoking gun" of Ebionite provision. It reinforces the belief that the "Actual Jesus" is the true locus of God's presence on earth, replacing the lost Temple as the source of life and sustenance.

chapters.title: Proto-Luke Chapter 7
chapters.preamble: This section encompasses the culmination of the Galilean ministry, the revelation of the "Spiritual Body" on the mountain, and the beginning of the "Travel Narrative." The narrative focuses on the internal authority of the Messenger, the cost of discipleship within the "Opposition Priesthood," and the rejection of biological and material claims in favor of the "Kingdom of God."

verses.english: And it happened while he was praying alone, the disciples were with him, and he asked them saying: "Who do the crowds say I am?"
verses.greek: Καὶ ἐγένετο ἐν τῷ εἶναι αὐτὸν προσευχόμενον κατὰ μόνας συνῆσαν αὐτῷ οἱ μαθηταί, καὶ ἐπηρώτησεν αὐτοὺς λέγων· Τίνα με λέγουσιν οἱ ὄχλοι εἶναι;

verses.english: And they answering said: "John the Baptist, but others Elijah, and others that a prophet, one of the ancients, has risen."
verses.greek: οἱ δὲ ἀποκριθέντες εἶπαν· Ἰωάννην τὸν βαπτιστήν, ἄλλοι δὲ Ἠλίαν, ἄλλοι δὲ ὅτι προφήτης τις τῶν ἀρχαίων ἀνέστη.

verses.english: And he said to them: "But you, who do you say I am?" and Peter answering said: "The Christ of God."
verses.greek: εἶπεν δὲ αὐτοῖς· Ὑμεῖς δὲ τίνα με λέγετε εἶναι; Πέτρος δὲ ἀποκριθεὶς εἶπεν· Τὸν Χριστὸν τοῦ θεοῦ.

verses.english: But he, having rebuked them, commanded to tell this to no one, saying that it is necessary for the son of man to suffer many things and to be rejected by the elders and scribes and chief priests and to be killed and after three days to be raised.
verses.greek: Ὁ δὲ ἐπιτιμήσας αὐτοῖς παρήγγειλεν μηδενί λέγειν τοῦτο, εἰπὼν ὅτι δεῖ τὸν υἱὸν τοῦ ἀνθρώπου πολλὰ παθεῖν καὶ ἀποδοκιμασθῆναι ἀπὸ τῶν πρεσβυτέρων καὶ γραμματέων καὶ ἀρχιερέων καὶ ἀποκτανθῆναι καὶ μετὰ τρεῖς ἡμέρας ἐγερθῆναι.

verses.english: And he said to all: "If anyone wishes to come after me, let him deny himself and take up his cross daily and follow me."
verses.greek: Ἔλεγεν δὲ πρὸς πάντας· Εἴ τις θέλει ὀπίσω μου ἔρχεσθαι, ἀπαρνησάσθω ἑαυτὸν καὶ ἀράτω τὸν σταυρὸν αὐτοῦ καθ' ἡμέραν καὶ ἀκολουθείτω μοι.

verses.english: "For whoever wants to save his life shall lose it; but whoever loses his life for my sake, he shall save it."
verses.greek: ὃς γὰρ ἂν θέλῃ τὴν ψυχὴν αὐτοῦ σῶσαι, ἀπολέσει αὐτήν· ὃς δ᾽ ἂν ἀπολέσῃ τὴν ψυχὴν αὐτοῦ ἕνεκεν ἐμοῦ, οὗτος σώσει αὐτήν.

verses.english: "For whoever is ashamed of me and my words, of him the son of man shall be ashamed when he comes in his glory."
verses.greek: ὃς γὰρ ἂν ἐπαισχυνθῇ με καὶ τοὺς ἐμοὺς λόγους, τοῦτον ὁ υἱὸς τοῦ ἀνθρώπου ἐπαισχυνθήσεται ὅταν ἔλθῃ ἐν τῇ δόξῃ αὐτοῦ.

verses.english: And it happened after these words, about eight days, taking Peter and John and James, he went up into the mountain to pray.
verses.greek: Ἐγένετο δὲ μετὰ τοὺς λόγους τούτους ὡσεὶ ἡμέραι ὀκτὼ καὶ παραλαβὼν Πέτρον καὶ Ἰωάννην καὶ Ἰάκωβον ἀνέβη εἰς τὸ ὄρος προσεύξασθαι.

verses.english: And it happened while he was praying, the appearance of his face was different and his clothing was white and flashing.
verses.greek: καὶ ἐγένετο ἐν τῷ προσεύχεσθαι αὐτὸν τὸ εἶδος τοῦ προσώπου αὐτοῦ ἕτερον καὶ ὁ ἱματισμὸς αὐτοῦ λευκὸς ἐξαστράπτων.

verses.english: And behold, two men were talking with him, who were Moses and Elijah.
verses.greek: καὶ ἰδοὺ ἄνδρες δύο συνελάλουν αὐτῷ, οἵτινες ἦσαν Μωϋσῆς καὶ Ἠλίας.

verses.english: And a voice came out of the cloud saying: "This is my son, the beloved; listen to him."
verses.greek: καὶ φωνὴ ἐγένετο ἐκ τῆς νεφέλης λέγουσα· Οὗτός ἐστιν ὁ υἱός μου ὁ ἀγαπητός, ἀκούετε αὐτοῦ.

verses.english: "Place these words in your ears; for the son of man is about to be delivered into the hands of men."
verses.greek: θέσθε ὑμεῖς εἰς τὰ ὦτα ὑμῶν τοὺς λόγους τούτους· ὁ γὰρ υἱὸς τοῦ ἀνθρώπου μέλλει παραδίδοσθαι εἰς χεῖρας ἀνθρώπων.

verses.english: And Jesus, seeing the reasoning of their heart, took a child and set him by himself, and said to them: "Whoever receives this child in my name receives me; and whoever receives me receives him who sent me."
verses.greek: ὁ δὲ Ἰησοῦς εἰδὼς τὸν διαλογισμὸν τῆς καρδίας αὐτῶν, ἐπιλαβόμενος παιδίον ἔστησεν αὐτὸ παρ' ἑαυτῷ καὶ εἶπεν αὐτοῖς· ὃς ἐὰν δέξηται τοῦτο τὸ παιδίον ἐπὶ τῷ ὀνόματί μου, ἐμὲ δέχεται· καὶ ὃς ἂν ἐμὲ δέξηται, δέχεται τὸν ἀποστείλαντά με.

verses.english: And it happened when the days of his ascension were being fulfilled, he set his face to go to Jerusalem.
verses.greek: Ἐγένετο δὲ ἐν τῷ συμπληροῦσθαι τὰς ἡμέρας τῆς ἀναλήμψεως αὐτοῦ καὶ αὐτὸς τὸ πρόσωπον ἐστήρισεν τοῦ πορεύεσθαι εἰς Ἰερουσαλήμ.

verses.english: And when the disciples James and John saw, they said: "Lord, do you wish that we command fire to come down from heaven and consume them?" But turning, he rebuked them. And they went to another village.
verses.greek: ἰδόντες δὲ οἱ μαθηταὶ Ἰάκωβος καὶ Ἰωάννης εἶπαν· Κύριε, θέλεις εἴπωμεν πῦρ καταβῆναι ἀπὸ τοῦ οὐρανοῦ καὶ ἀναλῶσαι αὐτούς; στραφεὶς δὲ ἐπετίμησεν αὐτοῖς· καὶ ἐπορεύθησαν εἰς ἑτέραν κώμην.

verses.english: And as they were going in the road, someone said to him: "I will follow you wherever you go." And Jesus said to him: "The foxes have holes and the birds of the heaven nests, but the son of man has not where he may lay his head."
verses.greek: Καὶ πορευομένων αὐτῶν ἐν τῇ ὁδῷ εἶπέν τις πρὸς αὐτόν· ἀκολουθήσω σοι ὅπου ἐὰν ἀπέρχῃ. καὶ εἶπεν αὐτῷ ὁ Ἰησοῦς· αἱ ἀλώπεκες φωλεοὺς ἔχουσιν καὶ τὰ πετεινὰ τοῦ οὐρανοῦ κατασκηνώσεις, ὁ δὲ υἱὸς τοῦ ἀνθρώπου οὐκ ἔχει ποῦ τὴν κεφαλὴν κλίνῃ.

verses.english: And he said to another: "Follow me." But he said: "Lord, permit me first to go and bury my father." But he said to him: "Leave the dead to bury their own dead, but you go and announce the kingdom of God."
verses.greek: Εἶπεν δὲ πρὸς ἕτερον· Ἀκολούθει μοι. ὁ δὲ εἶπεν· Κύριε, ἐπίτρεψόν μοι πρῶτον ἀπελθόντι θάψαι τὸν πατέρα μου. εἶπεν δὲ αὐτῷ· Ἄφες τοὺς νεκροὺς θάψαι τοὺς ἑαυτῶν νεκρούς, σὺ δὲ ἀπελθὼν διάγγελλε τὴν βασιλείαν τοῦ θεοῦ.

verses.english: And another also said: "I will follow you, Lord, but first permit me to say goodbye to those in my house." But Jesus said to him: "No one having put his hand to the plow and looking back is fit for the kingdom of God."
verses.greek: εἶπεν δὲ ὁ Ἰησοῦς· Οὐδεὶς ἐπιβαλὼν τὴν χεῖρα ἐπ' ἄροτρον καὶ βλέπων εἰς τὰ ὀπίσω εὔθετός ἐστιν τῇ βασιλείᾳ τοῦ θεοῦ.

notes.explanation: In this reconstruction, the narrative flows directly from the feeding of the 5000 (9:17) to Peter's Confession (9:18). This bypasses the large block of Markan material (Mk 6:45–8:26) which includes Jesus walking on water. The sources identify this as a 'non-interpolation'—the Markan material was never part of the original Jamesian Protograph.
"The Anointed of God." The dynastic/functional title of the Davidic heir, which the Messenger immediately refines in the following verses.

notes.term: Son of Man (ὁ υἱὸς τοῦ ἀνθρώπου - ho huios tou anthrōpou)
notes.explanation: The Greek refers to the "Son of the Human." In this stratum, it denotes the representative of the restored humanity, often used by Jesus to refer to himself as the eschatological judge.

Used here as a forensic title for the representative of the restored pneumatic humanity. Following the Marcionite and primitive witnesses, the reference to 'holy messengers' (angels) is absent, focusing the eschatological gaze directly on the glory of the Father.
A forensic term meaning "to be rejected after examination." This emphasizes the clinical necessity of the Messenger's rejection by the institutional "vessels" of the old age.
Passive: "to be raised." The Protograph identifies the resurrection as an act of the Divine upon the Messenger, rather than an autonomous biological revival.
The reconstruction restores the primitive Western reading. The canonical 'on the third day' is a later harmonization intended to simplify the chronometer of the resurrection.
The "stake" or "cross." In the Jamesian context, this is a literal call to martyrdom and total divestment of the material self.
A clinical command to deposit these facts into the permanent memory of the community.
A dry forensic term for a legal transfer or betrayal within the historical timeframe.
The text identifies internal debate as the source of communal debris; the child is utilized as a clinical corrective.
This implies a hospitable inclusion into the community of use, establishing a chain of pneumatic authority from the Father to the Messenger.
"Different." This identifies the Transfiguration as a pneumatic change—a manifestation of the Spiritual Body (Soma Pneumatikon)—rather than a material modification.

Marcion's text and the early Jamesian witnesses prioritize "Beloved" over the canonical "Chosen" (ἐκλελεγμένος). "Beloved" emphasizes the internal conjunction of Love between the Father and the Messenger.

The presence of the "Law and the Prophets" on the mountain serves as a forensic testimony to Jesus's authority. Jamesian theology viewed Jesus as the internal fulfillment of the Law, making the presence of Moses a validation of the "Royal Law" of Love.
Literally "taking up." This denotes the eschatological transition of the spirit to the "Right Hand of Power."

The phrase "as Elijah did" (ὡς καὶ Ἠλίας ἐποίησεν) is omitted based on the Western substrate (P75, B). Its removal prevents a direct mapping of the Messenger onto the violent motifs of the old prophets.
The longer rebuke ("Ye know not what spirit...") is treated as a later expansion; the Protograph records a silent, clinical rebuke and a move to the next "vessel" (village).
"Announce" is used to capture the sense of a herald's distinct duty. In v. 60, this is the command given to the "Slave" of the Kingdom, which overrides even the duty to the biological father.

The command to "Leave the dead to bury their own dead" is a hallmark of the Ebionite/Jamesian focus on the "Living Word" over the "debris" of biological tradition and family preservation. Biological ties are categorized as "the dead," while the mission of the Poor is the "living" reality.

additional_explanation.title: The Ascension of the Spirit
additional_explanation.content: Chapter 7 of the Jamesian Protograph marks the "Transfiguration"—the phenomenological manifestation of the Divine Human.

points.title: The Spiritual Body
points.explanation: The description of Jesus's face and clothing (9:29) reflects a visionary, pneumatic experience rather than a material change. This aligns with the "Spiritual Resurrection" theology of the Jerusalem pillars, where the physical body is a shell for the glorified "Being of Light."

points.title: The Rejection of Bio-Dynasty
points.explanation: In the "following" narratives (9:57-62), Jesus demands total renunciation of property (nests/holes) and biological family (burying the father). This is the "Epistemology of Doing," where loyalty to the community of the Poor (Ebionim) is the only valid marker of identity.

points.title: The Authority of the Word
points.explanation: By rebuking Peter's biological confession and substituting it with the Passion prediction (9:21-22), Jesus establishes that the Messenger is defined by his Suffering Use (service) and not his earthly status. This is the core of the Jamesian critique of the Pauline "Cosmic Christ"—true authority is found in the grit of ethical action on the way to Jerusalem.

chapters.title: Proto-Luke Chapter 8
chapters.preamble: This revision acknowledges the lack of "editorial fatigue" in the Marcionite witnesses, which identifies the shorter text not as a "mutilated" version of Luke, but as the primitive, coherent source upon which the canonical author later expanded. Consequently, variants once labeled "pro-Gnostic edits" are restored here as the original readings of the Jerusalem community, reflecting their unique pneumatic and ethical priorities.

verses.english: After these things the Lord appointed seventy others and sent them two by two before his face into every city and place where he himself was about to come.
verses.greek: Μετὰ δὲ ταῦτα ἀνέδειξεν ὁ κύριος ἑτέρους ἑβδομήκοντα καὶ ἀπέστειλεν αὐτοὺς ἀνὰ δύο πρὸ προσώπου αὐτοῦ εἰς πᾶσαν πόλιν καὶ τόπον οὗ ἤμελλεν αὐτὸς ἔρχεσθαι.

verses.english: And he said to them: "The harvest indeed is great, but the laborers are few; beg then the Lord of the harvest that he might send laborers into his harvest."
verses.greek: ἔλεγεν δὲ πρὸς αὐτούς· ὁ μὲν θερισμὸς πολύς, οἱ δὲ ἐργάται ὀλίγοι· δεήθητε οὖν τοῦ κυρίου τοῦ θερισμοῦ ὅπως ἐργάτας ἐκβάλῃ εἰς τὸν θερισμὸν αὐτοῦ.

verses.english: "Go! Behold, I send you as lambs in the midst of wolves."
verses.greek: ὑπάγετε· ἰδοὺ ἀποστέλλω ὑμᾶς ὡς ἄρνας ἐν μέσῳ λύκων.

verses.english: "Carry no bag, no scrip, no sandals; and salute no one by the road."
verses.greek: μὴ βαστάζετε βαλλάντιον, μὴ πήραν, μὴ ὑποδήματα, καὶ μηδένα κατὰ τὴν ὁδὸν ἀσπάσησθε.

verses.english: And heal the sick in it and say to them: 'The kingdom of God has come near upon you.'
verses.greek: καὶ θεραπεύετε τοὺς ἐν αὐτῇ ἀσθενεῖς καὶ λέγετε αὐτοῖς· ἤγγικεν ἐφ᾽ ὑμᾶς ἡ βασιλεία τοῦ θεοῦ.

verses.english: "But into whatever city you enter and they do not receive you, going out into its streets, say: 'Even the dust from your city having been joined to our feet we wipe off to you; nevertheless, know this, that the kingdom of God has come near.'"
verses.greek: εἰς ἣν δ᾽ ἂν πόλιν εἰσέλθητε καὶ μὴ δέχωνται ὑμᾶς, ἐξελθόντες εἰς τὰς πλατείας αὐτῆς εἴπατε· καὶ τὸν κονιορτὸν τὸν κολληθέντα ἡμῖν ἐκ τῆς πόλεως ὑμῶν εἰς τοὺς πόδας ἀπομασσόμεθα ὑμῖν· πλὴν τοῦτο γινώσκετε ὅτι ἤγγικεν ἡ βασιλεία τοῦ θεοῦ.

verses.english: "The one listening to you listens to me, and the one rejecting you rejects me; and the one rejecting me rejects him who sent me."
verses.greek: ὁ ἀκούων ὑμῶν ἐμοῦ ἀκούει, καὶ ὁ ἀθετῶν ὑμᾶς ἐμὲ ἀθετεῖ· ὁ δὲ ἐμὲ ἀθετῶν ἀθετεῖ τὸν ἀποστείλαντά με.

verses.english: In that hour he rejoiced in the spirit and said: "I confess to you, Father, Lord of heaven, that you have hidden these things from the wise and understanding and revealed them to infants; yes, Father, for so it was well-pleasing before you."
verses.greek: Ἐν αὐτῇ τῇ ὥρᾳ ἠγαλλιάσατο τῷ πνεύματι καὶ εἶπεν· Ἐξομολογοῦμαί σοι, πάτερ, κύριε τοῦ οὐρανοῦ, ὅτι ἀπέκρυψας ταῦτα ἀπὸ σοφῶν καὶ συνετῶν καὶ ἀπεκάλυψας αὐτὰ νηπίοις· ναί, ὁ πατήρ, ὅτι οὕτως εὐδοκία ἐγένετο ἔμπροσθέν σου.

verses.english: "All things were delivered to me by my Father; and no one knows who the Father is except the Son, and who the Son is except the Father, and to whom the Son should reveal him."
verses.greek: Πάντα μοι παρεδόθη ὑπὸ τοῦ πατρός μου, καὶ οὐδεὶς γινώσκει τίς ἐστιν ὁ πατὴρ εἰ μὴ ὁ υἱὸς καὶ τίς ἐστιν ὁ υἱὸς καὶ ᾧ ἐὰν βούληται ὁ υἱὸς ἀποκαλύψαι.

verses.english: And behold, a certain lawyer stood up, tempting him, saying: "Teacher, what doing shall I inherit eternal life?"
verses.greek: Καὶ ἰδοὺ νομικός τις ἀνέστη ἐκπειράζων αὐτὸν λέγων· διδάσκαλε, τί ποιήσας ζωὴν αἰώνιον κληρονομήσω;

verses.english: He said to him: "In the Law what is written? How do you read?"
verses.greek: ὁ δὲ εἶπεν πρὸς αὐτόν· ἐν τῷ νόμῳ τί γέγραπται; πῶς ἀναγινώσκεις;

verses.english: He answering said: "You shall love the Lord your God from all your heart and from all your soul and from all your strength and from all your mind, and your neighbor as yourself."
verses.greek: ὁ δὲ ἀποκριθεὶς εἶπεν· ἀγαπήσεις κύριον τὸν θεόν σου ἐξ ὅλης τῆς καρδίας σου καὶ ἐξ ὅλης τῆς ψυχῆς σου καὶ ἐξ ὅλης τῆς ἰσχύος σου καὶ ἐξ ὅλης τῆς διανοίας σου, καὶ τὸν πλησίον σου ὡς σεαυτόν.

verses.english: And he said to him: "You answered correctly; do this and you shall live."
verses.greek: εἶπεν δὲ αὐτῷ· ὀρθῶς ἀπεκρίθης· τοῦτο ποίει καὶ ζήσῃ.

notes.explanation: The number "seventy" (70) is retained following the primitive uncial and papyri consensus (P75, B). The addition of "two" (72) is treated as a later expansion. This number corresponds to the traditional count of the nations, indicating the Proto-Lukan mission was intended as a universal expansion of the Jamesian authority from its center in Jerusalem.
The prohibition of sandals is an original ascetic requirement of the Jamesian Protograph, emphasizing total reliance on the Divine Influx within the material world.
The detailed instructions for house-entry are abbreviated in this stratum to maintain the focus on the herald's urgent announcement.
This verb identifies the Kingdom not as a future event but as a present ethical proximity activated by the messengers.
The reconstruction includes 'upon you,' specifying that the divine Influx is directed at the collective 'Poor' (Ebionim) as a clinical event.

The term denotes the forensic nullification of the messenger's authority. As the Jamesian community acted as an "Opposition Priesthood," the rejection of their emissaries was viewed as a rejection of the Divine Human in ultimates.

notes.term: Lord of Heaven (κύριε τοῦ οὐρανοῦ - kyrie tou ouranou)
notes.explanation: The omission of "and earth" (καὶ τῆς γῆς) is not a Gnostic excision but the original reading of the Protograph, distinguishing the spiritual source of life from the material environment. Restored based on P45 and the Marcionite witnesses.

The word order "no one knows who the Father is except the Son" is the primitive sequence of revelation. This highlights the pneumatic gatekeeping of the Son, an essential component of the early Jerusalem tradition before it was smoothed over by later canonical editors. The Son is the sole revealer of a previously unknown Father.
The "Blessing of the Eyes" is omitted here to preserve the structural seam leading directly to the lawyer's question, avoiding the "editorial fatigue" found in the canonical text.
The interaction represents an internal debate within the Hebrew community regarding the fulfillment of the Torah.
This imperative underscores the Jamesian "Epistemology of Use," where eternal life is contingent upon active loyalty to the Law of Love (Ma'asim) rather than mere intellectual assent.

additional_explanation.title: The Absence of Fatigue
additional_explanation.content: The textual integrity of this chapter in the Proto-Lukan stratum proves that the shorter Marcionite text is the original. In canonical Luke, the transition between the mission of the seventy and the lawyer's question often exhibits "editorial fatigue," where the vocabulary shifts to match the Matthean or Markan parallels. In this reconstruction, the Jamesian voice is consistent, focusing on the authority of the "Sent Ones" (messengers) and the necessity of fulfilling the Law through action. The variants in verses 21 and 22 are the bedrock of the earliest Christology, presenting a Savior who is the sole source of knowledge for a previously unknown Father.

chapters.title: Proto-Luke Chapter 9
chapters.preamble: This section contains the transition from the mission of the seventy into the internal cultic and polemical instructions of the movement. It features the primitive "Spirit-centered" version of the Lord's Prayer and the decisive "Beelzebul" controversy, where Jesus defines the mechanics of the Divine Influx. The narrative continues to excise secondary "Orthodox" or "Harmonizing" layers, such as the specific "Sign of Jonah" and the "Wisdom of God" speech.

verses.english: And it happened that while he was in a certain place praying, as he ceased, one of his disciples said to him: "Lord, teach us to pray, as John also taught his disciples."
verses.greek: Ἐγένετο δὲ ἐν τῷ εἶναι αὐτὸν ἐν τόπῳ τινὶ προσευχόμενον, ὡς ἐπαύσατο, εἶπέν τις τῶν μαθητῶν αὐτοῦ πρὸς αὐτόν· Κύριε, δίδαξον ἡμᾶς προσεύχεσθαι, καθὼς καὶ Ἰωάννης ἐδίδαξεν τοὺς μαθητὰς αὐτοῦ.

verses.english: And he said to them: "When you pray, say: Father, hallowed be your name. Let your Holy Spirit come upon us and cleanse us."
verses.greek: εἶπεν δὲ αὐτοῖς· Ὅταν προσεύχησθε, λέγετε· Πάτερ, ἁγιασθήτω τὸ ὄνομά σου· ἐλθέτω τὸ πνεῦμά σου τὸ ἅγιον ἐφ' ἡμᾶς καὶ καθαρισάτω ἡμᾶς.

verses.english: "Give us day by day our daily bread."
verses.greek: τὸν ἄρτον ἡμῶν τὸν ἐπιούσιον δίδου ἡμῖν τὸ καθ' ἡμέραν.

verses.english: "And forgive us our sins, for we ourselves forgive everyone who is indebted to us; and do not let us be led into temptation."
verses.greek: καὶ ἄφες ἡμῖν τὰς ἁμαρτίας ἡμῶν, καὶ γὰρ αὐτοὶ ἀφίεμεν παντὶ ὀφείλοντι ἡμῖν· καὶ μὴ εἰσενέγκῃς ἡμᾶς εἰς πειρασμόν.

verses.english: "And I say to you: Ask, and it shall be given to you; seek, and you shall find; knock, and it shall be opened to you."
verses.greek: Κἀγὼ ὑμῖν λέγω· αἰτεῖτε, καὶ δοθήσεται ὑμῖν· ζητεῖτε, καὶ εὑρήσετε· κρούετε, καὶ ἀνοιγήσεται ὑμῖν.

verses.english: "What father among you, if his son asks for a fish, will instead of a fish give him a snake? Or if he asks for an egg, will give him a scorpion?"
verses.greek: τίνα δὲ ἐξ ὑμῶν τὸν πατέρα αἰτήσει ὁ υἱὸς ἰχθύν, καὶ ἀντὶ ἰχθύος ὄφιν αὐτῷ ἐπιδώσει; ἢ καὶ αἰτήσει ᾠόν, ἐπιδώσει αὐτῷ σκορπίον;

verses.english: "If you then, being evil, know how to give good gifts to your children, how much more shall the Father give the Holy Spirit to those who ask him?"
verses.greek: εἰ οὖν ὑμεῖς πονηροὶ ὑπάρχοντες οἴδατε δόματα ἀγαθὰ διδόναι τοῖς τέκνοις ὑμῶν, πόσῳ μᾶλλον ὁ πατήρ ὁ ἐξ οὐρανοῦ δώσει πνεῦμα ἅγιον τοῖς αἰτοῦσιν αὐτόν.

verses.english: And he was casting out a daimon that was mute; and it came to pass, when the daimon had gone out, the mute spoke. And the crowds marveled.
verses.greek: Καὶ ἦν ἐκβάλλων δαιμόνιον κωφόν· ἐγένετο δὲ τοῦ δαιμονίου ἐξελθόντος ἐλάλησεν ὁ κωφός. καὶ ἐθαύμασαν οἱ ὄχλοι.

verses.english: But some of them said: "In Beelzebul, the prince of the daimons, he casts out daimons."
verses.greek: τινὲς δὲ ἐξ αὐτῶν εἶπον· ἐν Βεελζεβοὺλ τῷ ἄρχοντι τῶν δαιμονίων ἐκβάλλει τὰ δαιμόνια.

verses.english: But he, knowing their thoughts, said to them: "Every kingdom divided against itself is brought to desolation, and house falls upon house. And if the Adversary also is divided against himself, how shall his kingdom stand?"
verses.greek: εἰδὼς δὲ αὐτῶν τὰ διανοήματα εἶπεν αὐτοῖς· Πᾶσα βασιλεία ἐφ᾽ ἑαυτὴν διαμερισθεῖσα ἐρημοῦται, καὶ οἶκος ἐπὶ οἶκον πίπτει. εἰ δὲ καὶ ὁ σατανᾶς ἐφ᾽ ἑαυτὸν διεμερίσθη, πῶς σταθήσεται ἡ βασιλεία αὐτοῦ;

verses.english: "And if I by Beelzebul cast out daimons, by whom do your sons cast them out?"
verses.greek: εἰ δὲ ἐγὼ ἐν Βεελζεβοὺλ ἐκβάλλω τὰ δαιμόνια, οἱ υἱοὶ ὑμῶν ἐν τίνι ἐκβάλλουσιν;

verses.english: "But if I by the finger of God cast out daimons, then the kingdom of God has come upon you."
verses.greek: εἰ δὲ ἐν δακτύλῳ θεοῦ ἐκβάλλω τὰ δαιμόνια, ἄρα ἔφθασεν ἐφ᾽ ὑμᾶς ἡ βασιλεία τοῦ θεοῦ.

verses.english: And it happened, while he said these things, a certain woman out of the crowd, lifting up her voice, said to him: "Blessed is the womb that bore you and the breasts which you sucked!"
verses.greek: Ἐγένετο δὲ ἐν τῷ λέγειν αὐτὸν ταῦτα ἐπάρασά τις φωνὴν γυνὴ ἐκ τοῦ ὄχλου εἶπεν αὐτῷ· Μακαρία ἡ κοιλία ἡ βαστάσασά σε καὶ μαστοὶ οὓς ἐθήλασας.

verses.english: But he said: "Rather, blessed are those hearing the word of God and doing it."
verses.greek: αὐτὸς δὲ εἶπεν· μενοῦν μακάριοι οἱ ἀκούοντες τὸν λόγον τοῦ θεοῦ καὶ ποιοῦντες.

verses.english: "Now you Pharisees clean the outside of the cup and the platter, but your inside is full of robbery and wickedness. Fools! Did not he who made the outside make the inside also?"
verses.greek: νῦν ὑμεῖς οἱ Φαρισαῖοι τὸ ἔξωθεν τοῦ ποτηρίου καὶ τῆς παροψίδος καθαρίζετε, τὸ δὲ ἔσωθεν ὑμῶν γέμει ἁρπαγῆς καὶ πονηρίας. ἄφρονες, οὐχ ὁ ποιήσας τὸ ἔξωθεν καὶ τὸ ἔσωθεν ἐποίησεν;

verses.english: "Woe to you Pharisees! For you tithe mint and rue and every herb, but you pass over the calling and the love of God."
verses.greek: οὐαὶ ὑμῖν τοῖς Φαρισαίοις, ὅτι ἀποδεκατοῦτε τὸ ἡδύοσμον καὶ τὸ πήγανον καὶ πᾶν λάχανον, καὶ παρέρχεσθε τὴν κλῆσιν καὶ τὴν ἀγάπην τοῦ θεοῦ.

verses.english: "Woe to you! For you are as unseen graves, and the men walking over them do not know."
verses.greek: Οὐαὶ ὑμῖν, ὅτι ἐστὲ ὡς τὰ μνημεῖα τὰ ἄδηλα, καὶ οἱ ἄνθρωποι περιπατοῦντες ἐπάνω οὐκ οἴδασιν.

verses.english: "And he said: 'Woe also to you lawyers! For you load men with burdens hard to bear, and you yourselves do not touch the burdens with one of your fingers.'"
verses.greek: ὁ δὲ εἶπεν· καὶ ὑμῖν τοῖς νομικοῖς οὐαί, ὅτι φορτίζετε τοὺς ἀνθρώπους φορτία δυσβάστακτα, καὶ αὐτοὶ ἑνὶ τῶν δακτύλων ὑμῶν οὐ προσψαύετε τοῖς φορτίοις.

verses.english: "Woe to you lawyers! For you took away the key of knowledge; you yourselves did not enter, and those entering you hindered."
verses.greek: οὐαὶ ὑμῖν τοῖς νομικοῖς, ὅτι ἤρατε τὴν κλεῖδα τῆς γνώσεως· αὐτοὶ οὐκ εἰσήλθατε καὶ τοὺς εἰσερχομένους ἐκωλύσατε.

notes.explanation: Reconstruction replaces "Thy Kingdom Come" with the petition for the Spirit. This reading is preserved in the Marcionite/Jamesian tradition and manuscripts like 162 and 700. It reflects the primitive pneumatic Christology of the Jerusalem Pillars, where the "Kingdom" is the internal cleansing by the Spirit rather than an external political arrival.
This term is a dry economic fact, denoting the bread necessary for immediate existence.
The petitions "Thy will be done" and "on earth as it is in heaven" are omitted as later harmonizing additions from the Matthean stratum.
Restored over "debts" (opheilēmata) to identify the internal condition being addressed through pneumatic forgiveness.

notes.term: Led into Temptation (μὴ ἀφὲς ἡμᾶς εἰσενεχθῆναι - mē aphes hēmas eisenechthēnai)
notes.explanation: The construction "do not let us be led" is used instead of the active "lead us not." This is a dry forensic correction to avoid the theological absurdity of the Good Father acting as a tempter, a key feature of the Jamesian/Marcionite strata.

The specific gift of the Father in the Protograph is the Spirit, grounding the "Epistemology of Influx" where divine power is mediated directly to the individual. The climax of the "Ask/Seek/Knock" discourse is the specific gift of the Holy Spirit. In the Jamesian Protograph, the Father does not provide generic "good things" but the clinical mechanism of divine influx.

Transliterated to preserve the distinction from divine messengers (angeloi). In the Essene/Zoroastrian dualistic framework, this is an adversarial spirit-entity—a manifestation of the Spirit of Darkness that the Divine Human must forcefully subdue.
