The spelling follows the primitive tradition. Jesus's response highlights the "Kingdom" as a field of power (finger of God) rather than a geographical territory.
This is the definitive marker of the Jamesian Protograph. Jesus immediately pivots from biological glorification (the womb/breasts) to the "Epistemology of Use" (the doing of the word).
Reconstruction follows the variant "calling" instead of "judgment" (κρίσιν), as attested in the earliest Marcionite/Jamesian records. This emphasizes the vocational nature of the community.

Refers to specialists in the Torah. The "Key of Knowledge" (gnōsis) refers to the internal interpretation of the Law that the institutional elite had suppressed. The term refers to legal experts or lawyers of the old order. The "Woe" is clinical; they are accused of obstructing the pneumatic path by prioritizing material regulations over the Spirit.

notes.term: Key of Knowledge (κλεῖδα τῆς γνώσεως - kleida tēs gnōseōs)
notes.explanation: In this stratum, it identifies the esoteric authority held by the scribes which the movement seeks to liberate and return to the Poor.
The "unmarked tombs." This serves as a dry forensic metaphor for those who appear clean but are internally occupied by the debris of the old aeon.

The references to the "Sign of Jonah" and the "Wisdom of God" are recognized as later interpolations. In the Jamesian core, Jesus does not require the "Sign of Jonah" to validate his authority, nor does he appeal to a personified "Wisdom" to justify the persecution of prophets; his authority is clinical and self-evident in the restoration of the poor.
The "Sign of Jonah" and the "Wisdom of God" speech are excised as secondary layers used to link the narrative to the prophetic modulo of the old age.

additional_explanation.title: The Interior Kingdom
additional_explanation.content: Chapter 9 of the Jamesian Protograph represents the "Internalization of the Law."

points.title: The Pneumatic Prayer
points.explanation: By focusing the Lord's Prayer on the "cleansing of the Spirit," the Protograph defines the Kingdom not as a future Roman-style empire, but as an immediate internal state of order.

points.title: The Finger of God
points.explanation: The Beelzebul controversy establishes the "Actual Jesus" as a conduit of Influx. His power is a "clinical fact" (the finger of God) that restores human form by displacing the "debris" of spiritual disorder.

points.title: The Critique of Externalism
points.explanation: The Woes (11:39-52) function as a forensic assault on the "State Stabilization" of the Pharisees. Jesus identifies "cleanness" as an internal attribute of the soul rather than a ritual attribute of the cup or the flesh. This aligns with the "Jamesian Layer," which prioritizes the internal "Royal Law of Liberty" over the dead forms of the Temple hierarchy.

chapters.title: Proto-Luke Chapter 10
chapters.preamble: This stratum continues the "Travel Narrative," focusing on the internal vigilance of the community, the clinical rejection of material anxiety, and the radical division between the "Kingdom" and the established socio-religious order.

verses.english: But nothing is covered that will not be revealed, and nothing is hidden that will not be known.
verses.greek: Οὐδὲν δὲ συγκεκαλυμμένον ἐστὶν ὃ οὐκ ἀποκαλυφθήσεται, καὶ κρυπτὸν ὃ οὐ γνωσθήσεται.

verses.english: And I say to you, my friends: Do not fear those who are able to kill you only, and after this have no power over you.
verses.greek: Λέγω δὲ ὑμῖν τοῖς φίλοις μου· μὴ φοβηθῆτε ἀπὸ τῶν ἀποκτεννόντων ὑμᾶς μόνον καὶ μετὰ ταῦτα μὴ ἐχόντων περισσότερόν τι ποιῆσαι.

verses.english: But I will show you whom to fear: fear him who, after killing, has authority to cast into Gehenna.
verses.greek: ὑποδείξω δὲ ὑμῖν τίνα φοβηθῆτε· φοβήθητε τὸν μετὰ τὸ ἀποκτεῖναι ἔχοντα ἐξουσίαν ἐμβαλεῖν εἰς τὴν γέενναν.

verses.english: And I say to you: Everyone who confesses in me before men, the son of man shall also confess in him before God.
verses.greek: Λέγω δὲ ὑμῖν, πᾶς ὃς ἂν ὁμολογήσῃ ἐν ἐμοὶ ἔμπροσθεν τῶν ἀνθρώπων, καὶ ὁ υἱὸς τοῦ ἀνθρώπου ὁμολογήσει ἐν αὐτῷ ἔμπροσθεν τοῦ θεοῦ.

verses.english: But the one having denied me before men shall be denied before God.
verses.greek: ὁ δὲ ἀρνησάμενός με ἐνώπιον τῶν ἀνθρώπων ἀπαρνηθήσεται ἐνώπιον τοῦ θεοῦ.

verses.english: And everyone who shall speak a word against the son of man, it shall be forgiven him; but to the one having spoken against the Holy Spirit, it shall not be forgiven.
verses.greek: καὶ ὃς ἂν εἴπῃ λόγον εἰς τὸν υἱὸν τοῦ ἀνθρώπου, ἀφεθήσεται αὐτῷ· τῷ δὲ εἰς τὸ ἅγιον πνεῦμα εἴποντι οὐκ ἀφεθήσεται.

verses.english: And when they bring you before the assemblies and the rulers and the authorities, do not worry how you shall defend or what you shall say.
verses.greek: ὅταν δὲ εἰσφέρωσιν ὑμᾶς ἐπὶ τὰς συναγωγὰς καὶ τὰς ἀρχὰς καὶ τὰς ἐξουσίας, μὴ μεριμνήσητε πῶς ἢ τί ἀπολογήσησθε ἢ τί εἴπητε.

verses.english: For the Holy Spirit shall teach you in that very hour what it is necessary to say.
verses.greek: τὸ γὰρ ἅγιον πνεῦμα διδάξει ὑμᾶς ἐν αὐτῇ τῇ ὥρᾳ ἃ δεῖ εἰπεῖν.

verses.english: And someone from the crowd said to him: "Teacher, tell my brother to divide the inheritance with me."
verses.greek: Εἶπεν δέ τις ἐκ τοῦ ὄχλου αὐτῷ· Διδάσκαλε, εἰπὲ τῷ ἀδελφῷ μου μερίσασθαι μετ᾿ ἐμοῦ τὴν κληρονομίαν.

verses.english: But he said to him: "Man, who appointed me a judge or a divider over you?"
verses.greek: ὁ δὲ εἶπεν αὐτῷ· Ἄνθρωπε, τίς με κατέστησεν κριτὴν ἢ μεριστὴν ἐφ᾽ ὑμᾶς;

verses.english: And he said to them: "Watch and guard yourselves from all covetousness, for one's life does not consist of the abundance of his possessions."
verses.greek: εἶπεν δὲ πρὸς αὐτούς· ὁρᾶτε καὶ φυλάσσεσθε ἀπὸ πάσης πλεονεξίας, ὅτι οὐκ ἐν τῷ περισσεύειν τινὶ ἡ ζωὴ αὐτοῦ ἐστιν ἐκ τῶν ὑπαρχόντων αὐτῷ.

verses.english: But God said to him: "Fool! In this night they require your soul from you; and the things you prepared, whose shall they be?"
verses.greek: εἶπεν δὲ αὐτῷ ὁ θεός· ἄφρων, ταύτῃ τῇ νυκτὶ τὴν ψυχήν σου ἀπαιτοῦσιν ἀπὸ σοῦ· ἃ δὲ ἡτοίμασας, τίνι ἔσται;

verses.english: And he said to his disciples: "Therefore I say to you, do not worry for your soul, what you shall eat; nor for the body, what you shall put on."
verses.greek: Εἶπεν δὲ πρὸς τοὺς μαθητὰς αὐτοῦ· Διὰ τοῦτο λέγω ὑμῖν, μὴ μεριμνᾶτε τῇ ψυχῇ τί φάγητε, μηδὲ τῷ σώματι τί ἐνδύσησθε.

verses.english: "Consider the ravens, for they do not sow nor reap, which have no storehouse nor barn, and God feeds them. How much more are you worth than the birds!"
verses.greek: κατανοήσατε τοὺς κόρακας ὅτι οὐ σπείρουσιν οὐδὲ θερίζουσιν, οἷς οὐκ ἔστιν ταμεῖον οὐδὲ ἀποθήκη, καὶ ὁ θεὸς τρέφει αὐτούς· πόσῳ μᾶλλον ὑμεῖς διαφέρετε τῶν πετεινῶν.

verses.english: "For the nations of the world seek after all these things, but your Father knows that you have need of these."
verses.greek: ταῦτα γὰρ πάντα τὰ ἔθνη τοῦ κόσμου ἐπιζητοῦσιν· ὑμῶν δὲ ὁ πατὴρ οἶδεν ὅτι χρήζετε τούτων.

verses.english: "But seek the kingdom of God, and these things shall be added to you."
verses.greek: πλὴν ζητεῖτε τὴν βασιλείαν τοῦ θεοῦ, καὶ ταῦτα πάντα προστεθήσεται ὑμῖν.

verses.english: "Fear not, little flock, for the Father was well-pleased to give you the kingdom."
verses.greek: μὴ φοβοῦ, τὸ μικρὸν ποίμνιον, ὅτι εὐδόκησεν ὁ πατὴρ δοῦναι ὑμῖν τὴν βασιλείαν.

verses.english: "Let your loins be girded and your lamps burning."
verses.greek: Ἔστωσαν ὑμῶν αἱ ὀσφύες περιεζωσμέναι καὶ οἱ λύχνοι καιόμενοι.

verses.english: "Blessed are those slaves whom the lord, having come, shall find watching."
verses.greek: μακάριοι οἱ δοῦλοι ἐκεῖνοι, οὓς ἐλθὼν ὁ κύριος εὑρήσει γρηγοροῦντας.

verses.english: "And if he comes in the evening watch, and finds them thus, blessed are those slaves."
verses.greek: καὶ ἐὰν ἔλθῃ τῇ ἑσπερινῇ φυλακῇ καὶ εὕρῃ οὕτως, μακάριοί εἰσιν.

verses.english: "And you, become ready, for in the hour you do not think, the son of man comes."
verses.greek: καὶ ὑμεῖς γίνεσθε ἕτοιμοι, ὅτι ᾗ ὥρᾳ οὐ δοκεῖτε ὁ υἱὸς τοῦ ἀνθρώπου ἔρχεται.

verses.english: And Peter said to him: "Lord, do you speak this parable to us or also to all?"
verses.greek: εἶπεν δὲ ὁ Πέτρος· κύριε, πρὸς ἡμᾶς τὴν παραβολὴν ταύτην λέγεις ἢ καὶ πρὸς πάντας;

verses.english: "I came to cast fire upon the earth."
verses.greek: Πῦρ ἦλθον βαλεῖν ἐπὶ τὴν γῆν.

verses.english: "Do you think that I have arrived to give peace on the earth? I tell you, no, but division."
verses.greek: Δοκεῖτε ὅτι εἰρήνην παρεγενόμην δοῦναι ἐν τῇ γῇ; οὐχί, λέγω ὑμῖν, ἀλλ᾽ ἢ διαμερισμόν.

verses.english: "For from now on there shall be five in one house divided, three against two and two against three."
verses.greek: ἔσονται γὰρ ἀπὸ τοῦ νῦν πέντε ἐν ἑνὶ οἴκῳ διαμεμερισμένοι, τρεῖς ἐπὶ δυσὶν καὶ δύο ἐπὶ τρισίν.

verses.english: "The father shall be divided against the son and the son against the father, mother against daughter and daughter against mother."
verses.greek: διαμερισθήσονται πατὴρ ἐπὶ υἱῷ καὶ υἱὸς ἐπὶ πατρί, καὶ μήτηρ ἐπὶ θυγατρὶ καὶ θυγάτηρ ἐπὶ μητρί.

verses.english: "Hypocrites! You know how to judge the face of the heaven and of the earth, but how do you not judge this time?"
verses.greek: Ὑποκριταί, τὸ πρόσωπον τοῦ οὐρανοῦ καὶ τῆς γῆς οἴδατε δοκιμάζειν, τὸν δὲ καιρὸν τοῦτον πῶς οὐ δοκιμάζετε;

notes.explanation: Retained rather than the Western "Hell" to maintain the specific Judean topographic metaphor for the place of disorder.

notes.term: Kill you only (ὑμᾶς μόνον ἀποκτέννειν - hymas monon apoktennein)
notes.explanation: The Jamesian Protograph likely omitted "body" (σῶμα) in verse 4, focusing the threat directly on the "you" (the self), emphasizing the existential nature of martyrdom in the early Jerusalem community.
Literally "anything more." This establishes a clinical boundary where material power ends and the pneumatic authority begins.

notes.term: Before God (ἐνώπιον τοῦ θεοῦ - enōpion tou theou)
notes.explanation: In verses 8 and 9, the later canonical addition of "messengers" (angels) is omitted, as the earliest witnesses (Tertullian/Epiphanius) reflect a more direct pneumatic accountability before the Divine.

The reference to "messengers" (angels) found in the canonical text is removed. The earliest historical witnesses, including the Marcionite and Jamesian layers, record a direct pneumatic accountability before the Divine (ἔμπροσθεν τοῦ θεοῦ), avoiding later celestial bureaucracies.

notes.term: Speak Against (εἴπῃ εἰς - eipē eis) in 12:10
notes.explanation: The reconstruction utilizes 'speak toward/against' in both halves of the verse, creating a clinical parallel between the two speech-acts.
The term 'blaspheming' (βλασφημήσαντι) is excluded in the second half to reflect the primitive Marcionite/Jamesian reading, which focuses on the act of rejecting the pneumatic influx.

notes.term: ὁ υἱὸς τοῦ ἀνθρώπου (ho huios tou anthrōpou)
notes.explanation: "The Son of the Human." This title denotes the Messenger as the representative of the restored pneumatic humanity.
Rendered as 'assemblies' to maintain the literal sense of a gathering place within the Judean administrative framework, stripped of later specialized religious weight.

notes.term: Rulers and Authorities (ἀρχὰς καὶ ἐξουσίας) in 12:11
notes.explanation: These terms denote the institutional structures of the Old Aeon—the 'debris' that the Kingdom actively bypasses.
The command shuns the 'calculating logic' of the state in favor of an absolute reliance on Divine Influx.
The reconstruction follows the Marcionite sequence (τὸ γὰρ ἅγιον πνεῦμα), which prioritizes the quality of the Spirit as the primary actor.
The use of δεῖ implies a forensic or divine necessity; the speech given under pressure is a direct result of pneumatic influx rather than prepared rhetoric.

Epiphanius (Pan. 42.11.6, scholion 34) explicitly attests that Marcion's Gospel did not read 'your' before 'Father'. The omission is a diagnostic marker of the Jamesian/Marcionite stratum, decoupling the Father from specific biological or tribal ownership.
This term refers to the Ebionim (the Poor Ones), identified here as the sole heirs of the established Kingdom.

notes.term: Judge or Divider (κριτὴν ἢ μεριστήν - kritēn ē meristēn)
notes.explanation: The term "divider" (μεριστήν) is the literal translation denoting a functional office of legal distribution. The Messenger's refusal to act in this capacity reinforces the separation between the Kingdom and material debt-management.
"Possessions" or "Ultimates." The Greek clinical fact is that life does not consist of material accumulation.
Translated literally; the specific use of "ravens" rather than "birds" (Matthew) is a Proto-Lukan hallmark linking Jesus to the feeding of Elijah.
To be anxious or divided. The command is to reject the "debris" of material worry.
The term is used here in its clinical, pneumatic sense to denote the life-force or the self, rather than a religious 'ghost.'
The term identifies the basic unit of biological debris which the Kingdom actively disrupts.
Strictly rendered as "slaves" instead of "servants" to reflect the total, non-negotiable loyalty required of the community members toward their Lord.
This is the specific variant in the Jamesian Protograph, suggesting a much more urgent, immediate context for the Parousia than the later canonical "second or third watch."

notes.term: Become ready (γίνεσθε ἕτοιμοι - ginesthe hetoimoi) in 12:40
notes.explanation: The imperative denotes a required state of pneumatic alertness rather than a passive expectation.
The reconstruction omits the conjunction following P75 and B, reflecting the blunt, non-connective style of the primitive source.
The vocative translates the Greek term used to address the teacher in his functional capacity as master of the word.

notes.term: To us or to all (πρὸς ἡμᾶς... ἢ καὶ πρὸς πάντας) in 12:41
notes.explanation: Peter's query highlights the division between the inner community of use and the external sensory debris of the crowd.
The reconstruction utilizes 'upon' (with the accusative) following P45, P75, and the Western tradition to emphasize the outward, forceful manifestation of the spirit upon the physical realm.
The term identifies the material arena that is to be purged by the divine influx.
A clinical description of those whose internal spiritual perception is masked by their external focus on material signs.
Refers to the visible sensory debris of the material universe.
The specific, appointed eschatological moment or season that requires pneumatic discernment.
"Division" or "shattering." This term is a clinical counterpoint to peace, denoting the necessary breaking of biological family vessels to prioritize pneumatic loyalty to the Kingdom.
"From now on." This identifies the establishment of the Kingdom as a present, transformative event starting at the point of the Messenger's descent.

additional_explanation.title: The Epistemology of Use
additional_explanation.content: Chapter 10 of the Protograph articulates the movement's radical Anti-Anxiety Protocol.

points.title: The Rejection of Material Worry
points.explanation: By commanding the disciples to "Consider the ravens" (12:24) and "the lilies" (12:27), Jesus establishes a lifestyle of total reliance on the Divine Influx (Providence). This was the economic substrate of the Jerusalem Ebionim (The Poor), who surrendered private property to live in a community of "Use."

points.title: The Divider of Inheritance
points.explanation: Jesus's refusal to adjudicate a property dispute (12:14) is a clinical rejection of the "Old Aeon" legalism. He asserts that his authority is not to regulate the distribution of material "debris" but to restore the internal state of humanity.

points.title: The Fire of Division
points.explanation: The "Fire" and "Division" mentioned in 12:49-51 serve as a forensic warning that the Truth is not an irenic synthesis but a sword of separation. It severs the follower from biological family ties (12:53) and social approval (12:8-9) to foster absolute loyalty to the Spirit.

points.title: The Archeology of the Soul
points.explanation: The warning against "Hypocrites" who can read the weather but not the "Time" (12:56) targets those who rely on external sensory data (the "Serpent" principle) while ignoring the internal arrival of the Divine Human in ultimates.

chapters.title: Proto-Luke Chapter 11
chapters.preamble: This reconstruction excises later "Orthodox" or "Harmonizing" additions, such as the Jerusalem Lament or the specific parables of tragedy in the opening verses (Galileans, fig tree), to reveal the dry facts of the primitive source.

verses.english: And he was teaching in one of the assemblies on the Sabbaths.
verses.greek: Ἦν δὲ διδάσκων ἐν μιᾷ τῶν συναγωγῶν ἐν τοῖς σάββασιν.

verses.english: "Hypocrites! Does not each one of you on the Sabbath untie his ox or his donkey from the manger and leading it away water it?"
verses.greek: ἀπεκρίθη δὲ αὐτῷ ὁ κύριος καὶ εἶπεν· Ὑποκριταί, ἕκαστος ὑμῶν τῷ σαββάτῳ οὐ λύει τὸν βοῦν αὐτοῦ ἢ τὸν ὄνον ἀπὸ τῆς φάτνης καὶ ἀπαγαγὼν ποτίζει;

verses.english: "And this woman, being a daughter of Abraham, whom the Adversary bound—behold, for eighteen years—was it not necessary to be loosed from this bond on the day of the Sabbath?"
verses.greek: ταύτην δὲ θυγατέρα Ἀβραὰμ οὖσαν, ἣν ἔδησεν ὁ Σατανᾶς ἰδοὺ δεκαοκτὼ ἔτη, οὐκ ἔδει λυθῆναι ἀπὸ τοῦ δεσμοῦ τούτου τῇ ἡμέρᾳ τοῦ σαββάτου;

verses.english: Therefore he said: "To what is the kingdom of God like and to what shall I compare it?"
verses.greek: Ἔλεγεν οὖν· Τίνι ὁμοία ἐστὶν ἡ βασιλεία τοῦ θεοῦ καὶ τίνι ὁμοιώσω αὐτήν;

verses.english: "It is like a grain of mustard, which a man taking cast into his own garden; and it grew and became a great tree, and the birds of the heaven nested in its branches."
verses.greek: ὁμοία ἐστὶν κόκκῳ σινάπεως, ὃν λαβὼν ἄνθρωπος ἔβαλεν εἰς κῆπον ἑαυτοῦ, καὶ ηὔξησεν καὶ ἐγένετο εἰς δένδρον, καὶ τὰ πετεινὰ τοῦ οὐρανοῦ κατεσκήνωσεν ἐν τοῖς κλάδοις αὐτοῦ.

verses.english: "It is like leaven, which a woman taking hid in three measures of meal until the whole was leavened."
verses.greek: ὁμοία ἐστὶν ζύμῃ, ἣν λαβοῦσα γυνὴ ἐνέκρυψεν εἰς ἀλεύρου σάτα τρία ἕως οὗ ἐζυμώθη ὅλον.

verses.english: "Strive to enter through the narrow door, for many, I tell you, will seek to enter and will not be able."
verses.greek: Ἀγωνίζεσθε εἰσελθεῖν διὰ τῆς στενῆς θύρας, ὅτι πολλοί, λέγω ὑμῖν, ζητήσουσιν εἰσελθεῖν καὶ οὐκ ἰσχύσουσιν.

verses.english: "From the time the master of the house has risen and has locked the door, and you begin to stand outside and to knock at the door, saying, 'Lord, open to us,' and answering he will say to you, 'I do not know you, from where you are.'"
verses.greek: ἀφ᾿ οὗ ἂν ἐγερθῇ ὁ οἰκοδεσπότης καὶ ἀποκλείσῃ τὴν θύραν καὶ ἄρξησθε ἔξω ἑστάναι καὶ κρούειν τὴν θύραν λέγοντες· Κύριε, ἄνοιξον ἡμῖν, καὶ ἀποκριθεὶς ἐρεῖ ὑμῖν· Οὐκ οἶδα ὑμᾶς πόθεν ἐστέ.

verses.english: "Then you will begin to say, 'We ate in your presence and drank, and you taught in our streets.'"
verses.greek: τότε ἄρξεσθε λέγειν· Ἐφάγομεν ἐνώπιόν σου καὶ ἐπίομεν καὶ ἐν ταῖς πλατείαις ἡμῶν ἐδίδαξας.

verses.english: "And he will say, I tell you, I do not know from where you are; depart from me, all you workers of unrighteousness."
verses.greek: καὶ ἐρεῖ λέγων ὑμῖν· Οὐκ οἶδα πόθεν ἐστέ· ἀπόστητε ἀπ᾽ ἐμοῦ πάντες ἐργάται ἀδικίας.

verses.english: "There will be the weeping and the gnashing of teeth, when you see all the righteous in the kingdom of God, but you being kept outside."
verses.greek: ἐκεῖ ἔσται ὁ κλαυθμὸς καὶ ὁ βρυγμὸς τῶν ὀδόντων, ὅταν ὄψησθε πάντας τοὺς δικαίους ἐν τῇ βασιλείᾳ τοῦ θεοῦ, ὑμᾶς δὲ κρατουμένους ἔξω.

verses.english: "And they will come from east and west and from north and south and recline in the kingdom of God."
verses.greek: καὶ ἥξουσιν ἀπὸ ἀνατολῶν καὶ δυσμῶν καὶ ἀπὸ βορρᾶ καὶ νότου καὶ ἀνακλιθήσονται ἐν τῇ βασιλείᾳ τοῦ θεοῦ.

notes.explanation: The reports on the Galileans and the parable of the fig tree are entirely absent from this stratum. These are identified as later moralizing additions designed to justify the destruction of Jerusalem as a divine tragedy.

notes.term: Donkey or his ox (asinum aut bovem)
notes.explanation: The specific word order here is preserved in the earliest Marcionite records, which differ from the later canonical inversion.
The Greek term refers specifically to a feeding trough; the comparison is used to expose the inconsistency of the legalistic restrictions on the Sabbath.

The Greek retains the definite article (ὁ), signifying a functional title rather than a personal name. Rendered as 'the Adversary' (from Hebrew Śāṭān) to reflect its role as the personification of the cosmic 'Opposition' within the Jamesian/Zoroastrian dualism absorbed by the Jerusalem community. This entity functions as the prosecutor or 'stumbling block' within the eschatological framework.
Unlike other synoptic variants that mention a "field," this stratum specifies a private garden, emphasizing internal cultivation.
The "tree." In the Jamesian context, this represents the communal growth of the poor into a stable pneumatic shelter.
This forensic term defines the stringent requirements for entry into the community of the Ebionim.
This term denotes a householder or a position of absolute domestic authority.

notes.term: I do not know where you are from (Οὐκ οἶδα ὑμᾶς πόθεν ἐστέ)
notes.explanation: The Master's refusal is clinical, rejecting those who lack the internal signature of the Spirit despite external proximity.
Translated as "unrighteousness" to preserve the forensic meaning of acting outside the established law or ethical order.

notes.term: All the righteous (πάντας τοὺς δικαίους - pantas tous dikaious)
notes.explanation: This is a critical Jamesian variant where the names of the patriarchs (Abraham, Isaac, Jacob) are replaced by a general ethical category. This prioritizes "Doing" and ethical status over biological or national lineage.
"Being kept/held back." Restored over the canonical "thrown out" (ekballomenous). It denotes a state of being prevented or hindered from entering the pneumatic order.

The departure from Galilee and the "Jerusalem Lament" are excised. These are recognized as secondary "Pastoral" layers intended to harmonize the text with Davidic piety and the post-70 CE ruin of the city.

additional_explanation.title: The Narrow Door and Ethical Priority
additional_explanation.content: Chapter 11 of the Protograph emphasizes the stringent requirements for entry into the Kingdom.

points.title: Sabbath Controversy
points.explanation: The healing of the woman on the Sabbath demonstrates the priority of human restoration over legalistic observance. The comparison to watering animals exposes the hypocrisy of religious restrictions.

points.title: The Mustard Seed and Leaven
points.explanation: Both parables emphasize internal, organic growth. The Kingdom is not an external political entity but an internal transformation that spreads through the community of the Poor.

points.title: The Closed Door
points.explanation: The imagery of the narrow door and the locked house establishes that mere proximity to Jesus or external religious observance is insufficient. Entry requires the internal signature of the Spirit and active righteousness.

points.title: All the Righteous
points.explanation: The replacement of patriarchal names with "all the righteous" is a critical Jamesian marker. It universalizes salvation based on ethical conduct rather than ethnic lineage, consistent with the "Epistemology of Use."

chapters.title: Proto-Luke Chapter 12
chapters.preamble: This section corresponds to canonical Luke 14 and contains the core ethical directives regarding communal meals, the parabolic rejection of the institutional elite, and the absolute requirements for entry into the community of the Ebionim (The Poor).

verses.english: Then he said also to the one who invited him, "When you make a dinner or a banquet, do not call your friends, nor your brothers, nor your kinsmen, nor rich neighbors."
verses.greek: Ἔλεγεν δὲ καὶ τῷ κεκληκότι αὐτόν· Ὅταν ποιῇς ἄριστον ἢ δεῖπνον, μὴ φώνει τοὺς φίλους σου μηδὲ τοὺς ἀδελφούς σου μηδὲ τοὺς συγγενεῖς σου μηδὲ γείτονας πλουσίους.

verses.english: "For they have not the means to repay you; but it shall be repaid to you in the resurrection."
verses.greek: ὅτι οὐκ ἔχουσιν ἀνταποδοῦναί σοι, ἀνταποδοθήσεται γάρ σοι ἐν τῇ ἀναστάσει.

verses.english: And he said to him: 'A certain man made a banquet and called many.'
verses.greek: Ὁ δὲ εἶπεν αὐτῷ· Ἄνθρωπός τις ἐποίει δεῖπνον, καὶ ἐκάλεσεν πολλούς.

verses.english: And he sent his slave at the hour of the banquet to say to those who were invited, "Come, for it is now ready."
verses.greek: καὶ ἀπέστειλεν τὸν δοῦλον αὐτοῦ τῇ ὥρᾳ τοῦ δείπνου εἰπεῖν τοῖς κεκλημένοις· Ἔρχεσθε, ὅτι ἤδη ἕτοιμά ἐστιν.

verses.english: And they all began to excuse themselves. The first said to him, "I bought a field, and I must go out and see it; I ask you, have me excused."
verses.greek: καὶ ἤρξαντο ἀπὸ μιᾶς πάντες παραιτεῖσθαι. ὁ πρῶτος εἶπεν αὐτῷ· Ἀγρὸν ἠγόρασα καὶ ἔχω ἀνάγκην ἐξελθὼν ἰδεῖν αὐτόν· ἐρωτῶ σε, ἔχε με παρῃτημένον.

verses.english: And another said, "I bought five pairs of oxen, and I am going to prove them; I ask you, have me excused."
verses.greek: καὶ ἕτερος εἶπεν· Ζεύγη βοῶν ἠγόρασα πέντε καὶ πορεύομαι δοκιμάσαι αὐτά· ἐρωτῶ σε, ἔχε με παρῃτημένον.

verses.english: And another said, "I married a wife, and therefore I cannot come."
verses.greek: καὶ ἕτερος εἶπεν· Γυναῖκα ἔγημα καὶ διὰ τοῦτο οὐ δύναμαι ἐλθεῖν.

verses.english: So that slave came and reported these things to his lord. Then the master of the house, being angry, said to his slave: "Go out quickly into the squares and streets of the city, and bring in here the poor and maimed and blind and lame."
verses.greek: εἰσάγαγε ὧδε τοὺς πτωχοὺς καὶ ἀναπείρους καὶ τυφλοὺς καὶ χωλούς.

verses.english: And the slave said, "Lord, it has been done as you commanded, and still there is room."
verses.greek: καὶ εἶπεν ὁ δοῦλος· κύριε, γέγονεν ὃ ἐπέταξας, καὶ ἔτι τόπος ἐστίν.

verses.english: And the lord said to the slave, "Go out into the roads and hedges and compel them to come in, that my house may be filled."
verses.greek: καὶ εἶπεν ὁ κύριος πρὸς τὸν δοῦλον· ἔξελθε εἰς τὰς ὁδοὺς καὶ φραγμοὺς καὶ ἀνάγκασον εἰσελθεῖν, ἵνα γεμισθῇ μου ὁ οἶκος.

verses.english: "For I say to you, that none of those men who were invited shall taste of my banquet."
verses.greek: λέγω γὰρ ὑμῖν ὅτι οὐδεὶς τῶν ἀνδρῶν ἐκείνων τῶν κεκλημένων γεύσεταί μου τοῦ δείπνου.

verses.english: "If anyone comes to me and does not hate his own father and mother and wife and children and brothers and sisters, and even his own life also, he cannot be my disciple."
verses.greek: Εἴ τις ἔρχεται πρός με καὶ οὐ μισεῖ τὸν πατέρα ἑαυτοῦ καὶ τὴν μητέρα καὶ τὴν γυναῖκα καὶ τὰ τέκνα καὶ τοὺς ἀδελφοὺς καὶ τὰς ἀδελφὰς ἔτι τε καὶ τὴν ψυχὴν ἑαυτοῦ, οὐ δύναται εἶναί μου μαθητής.

verses.english: "So therefore, any one of you who does not renounce all that he has cannot be my disciple."
verses.greek: οὕτως οὖν πᾶς ἐξ ὑμῶν ὃς οὐκ ἀποτάσσεται πᾶσιν τοῖς ὑπάρχουσιν αὐτοῦ οὐ δύναται εἶναί μου μαθητής.

notes.explanation: The narrative concerning the healing of the man with dropsy and the teaching on choosing the lowest place is unattested in this stratum. The removal of these domestic and social etiquette parables focuses the narrative on the radical socio-economic instructions.
The Greek distinguishes between a midday meal and a formal evening banquet; the instruction targets the entire social economy of reciprocity.
The literal "call" denotes a formal invitation to a social contract, reflecting a dry historical command rather than casual assembly.
Tertullian's Latin (non possint) likely renders this Lukan reading, focusing on the economic inability of the poor to maintain the "Old Aeon" cycle of debt and favor.
The text omits the later qualifying "of the righteous," focusing on the event of restoration itself as the point of ultimate compensation.
The reconstruction omits "great" (μέγα), which is absent in several early witnesses including X, 213, and the Marcionite layer.
Strictly rendered as "slave" to reflect the actual socioeconomic hierarchy of the Roman-Judean substrate.
The excuses focus on material Ultimates (land, labor, biological kinship) as the primary obstacles to the Kingdom.
This term denotes the functional authority of the household, a central figure in the Jamesian parables of stewardship.
Refers to the spatial reality of the Kingdom; there is always "place" for the marginalized within the new social order.
The command signifies the urgency of the gathering of the Ebionim as the old institutional invitations are nullified.
This marks the clinical recovery of the marginalized (the Ebionim) into the new communal order.
These terms identify the Ebionim (the Poor), who are the functional heirs of the Jamesian community's socio-economic reversal.
Refers specifically to the "men" of the institutional elite who were originally called.

Retained as the stark 'hate' found in the Proto-Lukan layer. Luke 14:26 is technically unattested in the direct lists of Marcionite variations (Tertullian, Epiphanius, Adamantius), though Epiphanius references it in refutation 70. The harsh formulation aligns with the radical ascetic requirements of the L/Q source substrate; 'love less' is an ecclesiastical softening unsupported by the primitive text. In the Jamesian stratum, μισεῖ functions as a forensic requirement to detach the self from the 'Proprium' (self-love) and biological 'debris' that inhibit absolute loyalty to the spiritual order. This aligns with the Ebionim (The Poor), who practiced total liquidation of private property and material ties. While Mark uses family hostility as polemic against Jesus's biological family, the Jamesian Protograph utilizes this language as a requirement for 'final separation' from the maternal/finite self—James was simultaneously the Davidic 'Bulwark' and leader of a sect requiring renunciation of all possessions.

notes.term: Renounce all possessions (ἀποτάσσεται πᾶσιν τοῖς ὑπάρχουσιν)
notes.explanation: "Says farewell to all his possessions." This is the definitive forensic requirement for entry into the community of the Poor. Discipleship is contingent upon the total liquidation of private material Ultimates.

additional_explanation.title: The Economy of the Kingdom
additional_explanation.content: Chapter 12 of the Protograph articulates the movement's Socio-Economic Constitution.

points.title: The Abolition of Reciprocity
points.explanation: By forbidding invitations to those who can "repay," Jesus severs the community from the Roman system of patronage. The "Resurrection" serves as the only valid transaction point.

points.title: The Rejection of Debris
points.explanation: The excuses offered in the Parable of the Banquet (14:18-20) are the "ultimates" of the material world—land, capital (oxen), and biological lineage. The "Master" (the Spirit) identifies these as the primary inhibitors of the Divine Influx.

points.title: The Call to the Margin
points.explanation: The filling of the house with the "maimed" and "blind" is the clinical manifestation of the Theology of Reversal. The "Poor" are not an object of charity but the very substance of the Kingdom.

points.title: The Law of Hate
points.explanation: The command to "hate" one's family (14:26) is a forensic requirement to detach the self from the "Proprium" (self-love) mediated through biological ties, ensuring absolute loyalty to the Messenger.

chapters.title: Proto-Luke Chapter 13
chapters.preamble: This stratum corresponds to canonical Luke 15 and is characterized by the "Parables of the Lost," focusing on the recovery of the marginalized (the Ebionim). Significantly, the Parable of the Prodigal Son (15:11-32) is entirely absent from this layer, as verified by both the silence of Tertullian and the explicit notes of Epiphanius.

verses.english: Now all the tax-collectors and the sinners were coming near to him to listen to him.
verses.greek: Ἦσαν δὲ αὐτῷ ἐγγίζοντες πάντες οἱ τελῶναι καὶ οἱ ἁμαρτωλοὶ ἀκούειν αὐτοῦ.

verses.english: And the Pharisees and the scribes were grumbling, saying: "This man receives sinners and eats with them."
verses.greek: καὶ διεγόγγυζον οἵ τε Φαρισαῖοι καὶ οἱ γραμματεῖς λέγοντες ὅτι οὗτος ἁμαρτωλοὺς προσδέχεται καὶ συνεσθίει αὐτοῖς.

verses.english: "What man among you, having a hundred sheep and having lost one of them, does not leave the ninety-nine in the desert and go after the one having been lost until he finds it?"
verses.greek: Τίς ἄνθρωπος ἐξ ὑμῶν ἔχων ἑκατὸν πρόβατα καὶ ἀπολέσας ἐξ αὐτῶν ἓν οὐ καταλείπει τὰ ἐνενήκοντα ἐννέα ἐν τῇ ἐρήμῳ καὶ ἐπορεύεται ἐπὶ τὸ ἀπολωλὸς ἕως εὕρῃ αὐτό;

verses.english: "And having found it, he places it upon his shoulders, rejoicing."
verses.greek: καὶ εὑρὼν ἐπιτίθησιν ἐπὶ τοὺς ὤμους αὐτοῦ χαίρων.

verses.english: "And coming into the house, he calls together the friends and the neighbors, saying to them: 'Rejoice with me, for I found my sheep which was lost.'"
verses.greek: καὶ ἐλθὼν εἰς τὸν οἶκον συγκαλεῖ τοὺς φίλους καὶ τοὺς γείτονας λέγων αὐτοῖς· συγχάρητέ μοι, ὅτι εὗρον τὸ πρόβατόν μου τὸ ἀπολωλός.

verses.english: "I say to you that so there shall be joy in the heaven over one sinner repenting."
verses.greek: λέγω ὑμῖν ὅτι οὕτως χαρὰ ἐν τῷ οὐρανῷ ἔσται ἐπὶ ἑνὶ ἁμαρτωλῷ μετανοοῦντι ἢ ἐπὶ ἐνενήκοντα ἐννέα δικαίοις οἵτινες οὐ χρείαν ἔχουσιν μετανοίας.

verses.english: "Or what woman having ten drachmas, if she should lose one drachma, does not light a lamp and sweep the house and seek carefully until she finds it?"
verses.greek: ἢ τίς γυνὴ δραχμὰς ἔχουσα δέκα, ἐὰν ἀπολέσῃ δραχμὴν μίαν, οὐχὶ ἅπτει λύχνον καὶ σαροῖ τὴν οἰκίαν καὶ ζητεῖ ἐπιμελῶς ἕως οὗ εὕρῃ;

verses.english: "And having found it, she calls together the friends and neighbors, saying: 'Rejoice with me, for I found the drachma which I lost.'"
verses.greek: καὶ εὑροῦσα συγκαλεῖ τὰς φίλας καὶ γείτονας λέγουσα· συγχάρητέ μοι, ὅτι εὕρον τὴν δραχμὴν ἣν ἀπώλεσα.

verses.english: "So, I say to you, there is joy before God over one sinner repenting."
verses.greek: οὕτως, λέγω ὑμῖν, χαρὰ γίνεται ἐνώπιον τοῦ θεοῦ ἐπὶ ἑνὶ ἁμαρτωλῷ μετανοοῦντι.

notes.explanation: In the Jamesian context, this term identifies those outside the strict purity regulations of the Temple elite, here being brought into the new communal "use."
Literally "drawing near." This describes a clinical proximity to the Messenger to receive the Word.
Translated literally. The forensic analogy emphasizes the specific labor of the seeker to restore the lost element of the flock.

notes.term: Joy in the heaven (χαρὰ ἐν τῷ οὐρανῷ - chara en tō ouranō)
notes.explanation: The reconstruction follows the more direct pneumatic reading. The later addition of "messengers" (angels) was absent in the Jamesian Protograph, with the joy occurring directly before the Father.
Greek silver coins. The loss of a material "ultimate" (the coin) serves as a dry fact to illustrate the value of the individual within the community of the poor.

notes.term: Before God (ἐνώπιον τοῦ θεοῦ - enōpion tou theou)
notes.explanation: Consistent with the prior verse, the mention of "messengers" (angels) is unattested here in the primitive stratum. The "joy" is a direct result of the Divine Influx recognizing the return to order.

This major pericope is absent from the Marcionite and Jamesian records. The narrative of a wealthy father's house and the squandering of property is identified as a later domestic expansion (likely an "L" source harmonization) that conflicts with the strict Ebionite poverty theology of the original core.

additional_explanation.title: The Omission of the Prodigal
additional_explanation.content: The absence of the "Prodigal Son" (15:11-32) is one of the most distinctive features of the Proto-Lukan/Marcionite stratum.

points.title: The Context of Omission
points.explanation: While later orthodoxy valued the parable for its theme of repentance, the Jamesian community likely viewed the narrative as a later harmonization. The story of a younger son "squandering property" and then being restored to a wealthy father's house does not align with the strict Ebionite (poverty) theology found elsewhere in the Protograph.

points.title: Structural Integrity
points.explanation: Without verses 11-32, the chapter remains a coherent unit focused on the "Search and Recovery" mechanics of the Kingdom (the Sheep and the Coin). The transition from the finding of the coin directly into the stewardship parables is seamless, avoiding the lengthy narrative detour of the Prodigal.

points.title: The Anti-Harmonization Rule
points.explanation: The "Prodigal Son" exhibits signs of being an "L" source expansion designed to provide a more domestic, less radical entry point into the movement, which was later incorporated during the transition from Proto-Luke to the canonical edition. In the Jamesian Protograph, the focus remains clinical: the restoration of the "lost" is a functional necessity of the Spirit, not a family drama.

chapters.title: Proto-Luke Chapter 14
chapters.preamble: This stratum corresponds to canonical Luke 16 and is arguably the most critical for understanding the "Jamesian" identity of the early movement, containing the radical socio-economic instructions for the Ebionim (The Poor) and the definitive Lazarus narrative.

verses.english: "And I say to you, make for yourselves friends from the mammon of unrighteousness, that when it fails, they may receive you into the eternal dwellings."
verses.greek: κἀγὼ ὑμῖν λέγω, ἑαυτοῖς ποιήσατε φίλους ἐκ τοῦ μαμωνᾶ τῆς ἀδικίας, ἵνα ὅταν ἐκλίπῃ δέξωνται ὑμᾶς εἰς τὰς αἰωνίους σκηνάς.

verses.english: "He who is faithful in a very little is faithful also in much, and he who is unrighteous in a very little is unrighteous also in much."
verses.greek: ὁ πιστὸς ἐν ἐλαχίστῳ καὶ ἐν πολλῷ πιστός ἐστιν, καὶ ὁ ἐν ἐλαχίστῳ ἄδικος καὶ ἐν πολλῷ ἄδικός ἐστιν.

verses.english: "If then you were not faithful in the unrighteous mammon, who will entrust to you the true?"
verses.greek: εἰ οὖν ἐν τῷ ἀδίκῳ μαμωνᾷ πιστοὶ οὐκ ἐγένεσθε, τὸ ἀληθινὸν τίς ὑμῖν πιστεύσει;

verses.english: "And if you were not found faithful in that which belongs to another, who will give to you that which is mine?"
verses.greek: καὶ εἰ ἐν τῷ ἀλλοτρίῳ πιστοὶ οὐκ ἐγένεσθε, τὸ ἐμὸν τίς ὑμῖν δώσει;

verses.english: "No house-slave is able to serve two masters; for either he will hate the one and love the other, or he will hold to one and despise the other. You are not able to serve God and mammon."
verses.greek: Οὐδεὶς οἰκέτης δύναται δυσὶν κυρίοις δουλεύειν· ἢ γὰρ τὸν ἕνα μισήσει καὶ τὸν ἕτερον ἀγαπήσει, ἢ ἑνὸς ἀνθέξεται καὶ τοῦ ἑτέρου καταφρονήσει. οὐ δύνασθε θεῷ δουλεύειν καὶ μαμωνᾷ.

verses.english: Now the Pharisees, who were lovers of money, heard all these things and were sneering at him.
verses.greek: Ἤκουον δὲ ταῦτα πάντα οἱ Φαρισαῖοι φιλάργυροι ὑπάρχοντες καὶ ἐξεμυκτήριζον αὐτόν.

verses.english: And he said to them: "You are those who justify yourselves before men, but God knows your hearts; for that which is highly esteemed among men is an abomination before God."
verses.greek: καὶ εἶπεν αὐτοῖς· ὑμεῖς ἐστε οἱ δικαιοῦντες ἑαυτοὺς ἐνώπιον τῶν ἀνθρώπων, ὁ δὲ θεὸς γινώσκει τὰς καρδίας ὑμῶν· ὅτι τὸ ἐν ἀνθρώποις ὑψηλὸν βδέλυγμα ἐνώπιον τοῦ θεοῦ.

verses.english: "The law and the prophets were until John; since then the kingdom of God is announced, and everyone is forced into it."
verses.greek: Ὁ νόμος καὶ οἱ προφῆται μέχρι Ἰωάννου· ἀπὸ τότε ἡ βασιλεία τοῦ θεοῦ εὐαγγελίζεται καὶ πᾶς εἰς αὐτὴν βιάζεται.

verses.english: "It is easier for heaven and earth to pass than for one tittle of my words to pass."
verses.greek: εὐκοπώτερον δέ ἐστιν τὸν οὐρανὸν καὶ τὴν γῆν παρελθεῖν ἢ τῶν λόγων μου μίαν κεραίαν πεσεῖν.

verses.english: "Every one who divorces his wife and marries another commits adultery; and he who marries a woman divorced from a husband likewise commits adultery."
verses.greek: πᾶς ὁ ἀπολύων τὴν γυναῖκα αὐτοῦ καὶ γαμῶν ἑτέραν μοιχεύει, καὶ ὁ ἀπολελυμένην ἀπὸ ἀνδρὸς γαμῶν μοιχεύει.

verses.english: "There was a certain rich man, and he dressed in purple and fine linen, enjoying himself daily in splendor."
verses.greek: Ἄνθρωπος δέ τις ἦν πλούσιος, καὶ ἐνεδιδύσκετο πορφύραν καὶ βύσσον εὐφραινόμενος καθ' ἡμέραν λαμπρῶς.

verses.english: "And there was a certain poor man named Lazarus, who had been cast at his gate, full of sores."
verses.greek: πτωχὸς δέ τις ὀνόματι Λάζαρος ἐβέβλητο πρὸς τὸν πυλῶνα αὐτοῦ εἱλκωμένος.

verses.english: "...and desiring to be fed from the things falling from the table of the rich man; but even the dogs coming were licking his sores."
verses.greek: καὶ ἐπιθυμῶν χορτασθῆναι ἀπὸ τῶν πιπτόντων ἀπὸ τῆς τραπέζης τοῦ πλουσίου· ἀλλὰ καὶ οἱ κύνες ἐρχόμενοι ἀπέλειχον τὰ ἕλκη αὐτοῦ.

verses.english: "And it happened that the poor man died and was carried by the messengers into Abraham's bosom; and the rich man also died and was buried."
verses.greek: ἐγένετο δὲ ἀποθανεῖν τὸν πτωχὸν καὶ ἀπενεχθῆναι αὐτὸν ὑπὸ τῶν ἀγγέλων εἰς τὸν κόλπον Ἀβραάμ· ἀπέθανεν δὲ καὶ ὁ πλούσιος καὶ ἐτάφη.

verses.english: "And in Hades, lifting up his eyes, being in torments, he sees Abraham from a distance and Lazarus in his bosom."
verses.greek: καὶ ἐν τῷ ᾅδῃ ἐπάρας τοὺς ὀφθαλμοὺς αὐτοῦ, ὑπάρχων ἐν βασάνοις, ὁρᾷ Ἀβραὰμ ἀπὸ μακρόθεν καὶ Λάζαρον ἐν τοῖς κόλποις αὐτοῦ.

verses.english: "And he cried out and said, 'Father Abraham, have mercy on me and send Lazarus that he may dip the tip of his finger in water and cool my tongue, for I am in anguish in this flame.'"
verses.greek: καὶ αὐτὸς φωνήσας εἶπεν· πάτερ Ἀβραάμ, ἐλέησόν με καὶ πέμψον Λάζαρον ἵνα βάψῃ τὸ ἄκρον τοῦ δακτύλου αὐτοῦ ὕδατος καὶ καταψύξῃ τὴν γλῶσσάν μου, ὅτι ὀδυνῶμαι ἐν τῇ φλογὶ ταύτῃ.

verses.english: "But Abraham said, 'Child, remember that you received your good things in your life... but now he is comforted here, and you are in anguish.'"
verses.greek: εἶπεν δὲ Ἀβραάμ· τέκνον, μνήσθητι ὅτι ἀπέλαβες τὰ ἀγαθά σου ἐν τη ζωῇ σου, καὶ Λάζαρος ὁμοίως τὰ κακά· νῦν δὲ ὧδε παρακαλεῖται, σὺ δὲ ὀδυνᾶσαι.

verses.english: "And besides all these things, between us and you a great chasm has been fixed, so that those from here wanting to cross to you are not able, nor may they cross from there to us."
verses.greek: καὶ ἐπὶ πᾶσι τούτοις μεταξὺ ἡμῶν καὶ ὑμῶν χάσμα μέγα ἐστήρικται, ὅπως οἱ ἐνταῦθα διαβῆναι πρὸς ὑμᾶς μὴ δύνωνται, μηδὲ ἐκεῖθεν ὧδε διαπερῶσιν.

verses.english: "And he said: 'I ask you then, father, that you might send him to the house of my father, for I have five brothers, so that he may testify to them.'"
verses.greek: εἶπεν δέ· ἐρωτῶ οὖν σε, πάτερ, ἵνα πέμψῃς αὐτὸν εἰς τὸν οἶκον τοῦ πατρός μου, ἔχω γὰρ πέντε ἀδελφούς, ὅπως διαμαρτύρηται αὐτοῖς.

verses.english: "But Abraham says to him, 'They have Moses and the prophets; let them listen to them.'"
verses.greek: Λέγει δὲ αὐτῷ Ἀβραάμ· ἔχουσι Μωϋσέα καὶ τοὺς προφήτας· ἀκουσάτωσαν αὐτῶν.

verses.english: "But he said, 'No, father Abraham, but if someone from the dead should go to them, they will repent.'"
verses.greek: ὁ δὲ εἶπεν· οὐχί, πάτερ Ἀβραάμ, ἀλλ᾽ ἐάν τις ἐκ νεκρῶν πορευθῇ πρὸς αὐτούς, μετανοήσουσιν.

verses.english: "And he said to him, 'If they do not listen to Moses and the prophets, neither will they be convinced if someone from the dead should rise.'"
verses.greek: εἶπεν δὲ αὐτῷ· εἰ Μωϋσέως καὶ τῶν προφητῶν οὐκ ἀκούουσιν, οὐδὲ ἐάν τις ἐκ νεκρῶν ἀναστῇ πεισθήσονται.

notes.explanation: CONFLICTING EVIDENCE. Tertullian (Adv. Marc. 4.33.1) explicitly alludes to 'that servant' (servi illius exemplum) who was removed from office and 'reduces the debts' of his master's debtors. This contradicts the claim that the parable was absent from the Marcionite layer. The parable was likely present in some form, with its themes of stewardship informing the subsequent verses on Mammon and faithful service.

notes.term: Mammon of unrighteousness (μαμωνᾶ τῆς ἀδικίας - mamōna tēs adikias)
notes.explanation: "Unrighteousness" is the dry forensic rendering of adikia, denoting wealth accumulated within the corrupt legal and economic framework of the current age.

While canonical texts read "your own" (τὸ ὑμέτερον), the Jamesian Protograph emphasizes that spiritual wealth is the specific property of the Messenger, which he chooses to share with the faithful. This establishes a clinical hierarchy: the Spirit's resources belong to the Messenger/Father, and the follower is merely a steward of what is "His."

The term derives from οἶκος (oikos), meaning house or household. It is strictly rendered as "house-slave" to reflect the total, singular loyalty required within the specific "household economy" (oikonomia) of the Kingdom mission. This distinguishes it from the generic δοῦλος (doulos), preserving the specific dualism of the passage: one cannot be a domestic agent of the Kingdom while maintaining a domestic contract with Mammon.
This term identifies high social standing in the old order as a forensic pollutant before the Divine.

This designates a historical boundary, suggesting that the era of the Law and Prophets reached its terminus with John. The "violence" (biazetai) mentioned refers to the radical internal effort required to break from the material age.
Avoided "preached" to maintain the forensic sense of a royal herald making a formal proclamation.

notes.term: My words (τῶν λόγων μου - tōn logōn mou)
notes.explanation: This reading replaces the canonical 'the Law' (τοῦ νόμου). In the Jamesian Protograph, the authority of the 'Old Aeon' (the Law and Prophets) reaches its terminus with John. The permanence once ascribed to the Torah is transferred to the pneumatic proclamation of the Savior. Tertullian notes this specific 'emendation,' though forensically it is treated as the original reading of the Proto-Lukan source. The replacement identifies the Messenger as a new Lawgiver whose internal 'Law of Love' supersedes the external ritual requirements of the Temple cult.

The only named character in the parables, likely an etymological signifier for the Ebionite (Poor) sect. In the Jamesian context, this narrative is not about individual morality but about the clinical reversal of economic status in the pneumatic age.
Retained as the topographical term for the unseen realm of the dead, rather than the theological "Hell."
This denotes a permanent pneumatic boundary established by the reversal of economic ultimates.
A forensic term for giving legal testimony regarding the consequences of wealth and the rejection of the poor.
The clinical number refers to the biological survivors of the elite household, emphasizing the warning against a continued reliance on material wealth.
Found in the "Western" witnesses and the Jamesian stratum, emphasizing the immediate spatial reality of the spiritual state.
The final forensic statement links the rejection of the Messenger's word directly to the inability to perceive the Spirit, regardless of physical signs.

While Abraham is removed from eschatological lists in other chapters to de-emphasize biological lineage (see 13:28), he is retained here as a functional character in the parable's existing structure to represent the "Righteous Steward" of the previous age.

additional_explanation.title: The Ebionite Manifesto
additional_explanation.content: Chapter 14 of the Protograph defines the movement's relationship to wealth and lineage.

points.title: The Abolition of Private Mammon
points.explanation: The instructions in verses 9-13 constitute an economic "Path of Reversal." Wealth is clinical debris; the only valid "use" for it is to liquidate it for the benefit of the community to secure "eternal dwellings."

points.title: Biological vs. Pneumatic Property
points.explanation: By contrasting "another's" (material) wealth with "mine" (Jesus's spiritual words), the text creates a dualism where only the pneumatic influx is true property.

points.title: The Sufficiency of the Word
points.explanation: The Lazarus narrative (16:19-31) functions as a polemic against those who demand signs (like physical resurrection appearances). Abraham's refusal to send Lazarus back establishes that the "Royal Law of Love" found in the Prophets is the ultimate authority, surpassing even the resuscitation of a corpse.

chapters.title: Proto-Luke Chapter 15
chapters.preamble: This stratum corresponds to canonical Luke 17 and is defined by its focus on internal communal discipline, the rejection of "unprofitable" status for active followers, and the clinical definition of the Kingdom as an internal pneumatic state. The healing of the lepers is structurally linked to the precedent of Naaman the Syrian.

verses.english: And he said to his disciples: "It is impossible that stumbling blocks should not come; but woe to him through whom they come!"
verses.greek: Εἶπεν δὲ πρὸς τοὺς μαθητὰς αὐτοῦ· ἀνένδεκτόν ἐστιν τοῦ τὰ σκάνδαλα μὴ ἐλθεῖν, πλὴν οὐαὶ δι᾿ οὗ ἔρχεται.

verses.english: "It would be better for him if a millstone were hanged about his neck and he were thrown into the sea, than that he should cause one of these little ones to stumble."
verses.greek: λυσιτελεῖ αὐτῷ εἰ λίθος μυλικός περίκειται περὶ τὸν τράχηλον αὐτοῦ καὶ ἔρριπται εἰς τὴν θάλασσαν ἢ ἵνα σκανδαλίσῃ τῶν μικρῶν τούτων ἕνα.

verses.english: "Take heed to yourselves. If your brother sins, rebuke him; and if he repents, forgive him."
verses.greek: προσέχετε ἑαυτοῖς. ἐὰν ἁμάρτῃ ὁ ἀδελφός σου ἐπιτίμησον αὐτῷ, καὶ ἐὰν μετανοήσῃ ἄφες αὐτῷ.

verses.english: "And if he sins against you seven times in a day, and seven times turns back to you, saying, 'I repent,' you shall forgive him."
verses.greek: καὶ ἐὰν ἑπτάκις τῆς ἡμέρας ἁμαρτήσῃ εἰς σὲ καὶ ἑπτάκις ἐπιστρέψῃ πρὸς σὲ λέγων· μετανοῶ, ἀφήσεις αὐτῷ.

verses.english: "So also you, when you have done all the things commanded you, say: 'We have done what we were obligated to do.'"
verses.greek: οὕτως καὶ ὑμεῖς, ὅταν ποιήσητε πάντα τὰ διαταχθέντα ὑμῖν, λέγετε ὅτι ἃ ὠφείλομεν ποιῆσαι πεποιήκαμεν.

verses.english: And it happened that while he was going to Jerusalem, he passed through the midst of Samaria and Galilee.
verses.greek: Καὶ ἐγένετο ἐν τῷ πορεύεσθαι εἰς Ἱερουσαλήμ καὶ αὐτὸς διήρχετο διὰ μέσον Σαμαρείας καὶ Γαλιλαίας.

verses.english: And as he entered into a certain village, there met him ten lepers, who stood at a distance.
verses.greek: Καὶ εἰσερχομένου αὐτοῦ εἴς τινα κώμην ἀπήντησαν δέκα λεπροὶ ἄνδρες, οἳ ἔστησαν πόρρωθεν.

verses.english: And they lifted up their voice, saying: "Jesus, Commander, have mercy on us."
verses.greek: καὶ αὐτοὶ ἦραν φωνὴν λέγοντες· Ἰησοῦ ἐπιστάτα, ἐλέησον ἡμᾶς.

verses.english: "And he said: 'There were many lepers in Israel in the days of Elisha the prophet; and none of them was cleansed, except Naaman the Syrian.'"
verses.greek: πολλοὶ λεπροὶ ἦσαν ἐν τῷ Ἰσραὴλ ἐν ἡμέραις Ἐλισσαίου τοῦ προφήτου καὶ οὐδεὶς αὐτῶν ἐκαθαρίσθη εἰ μὴ Νεεμὰν ὁ Σύρος.

verses.english: And seeing them, he said to them: "Go, show yourselves to the priests." And it happened that while they were going, they were cleansed.
verses.greek: καὶ ἰδὼν εἶπεν αὐτοῖς· πορευθέντες ἐπιδείξατε ἑαυτοὺς τοῖς ἱερεῦσιν. καὶ ἐγένετο ἐν τῷ ὑπάγειν αὐτοὺς ἐκαθαρίσθησαν.

verses.english: And one of them, seeing that he was healed, turned back, with a loud voice glorifying God.
verses.greek: εἷς δὲ ἐξ αὐτῶν, ἰδὼν ὅτι ἰάθη, ὑπέστρεψεν μετὰ φωνῆς μεγάλης δοξάζων τὸν θεόν.

verses.english: And he fell upon his face at his feet, giving him thanks; and he was a Samaritan.
verses.greek: καὶ ἔπεσεν ἐπὶ πρόσωπον παρὰ τοὺς πόδας αὐτοῦ εὐχαριστῶν αὐτῷ· καὶ αὐτὸς ἦν Σαμαρίτης.

verses.english: And he said to him: "Arise, go; your faith has saved you."
verses.greek: καὶ εἶπεν αὐτῷ· ἀναστάς πορεύου· ἡ πίστις σου σέσωκέν σε.

verses.english: And having been questioned by the Pharisees as to when the kingdom of God comes, he answered them and said: "The kingdom of God does not come with observation."
verses.greek: Ἐπερωτηθεὶς δὲ ὑπὸ τῶν Φαρισαίων πότε ἔρχεται ἡ βασιλεία τοῦ θεοῦ ἀπεκρίθη αὐτοῖς καὶ εἶπεν· οὐκ ἔρχεται ἡ βασιλεία τοῦ θεοῦ μετὰ παρατηρήσεως.

verses.english: "Neither shall they say, 'Behold, here!' or 'Behold, there!'; for behold, the kingdom of God is within you."
verses.greek: οὐδὲ ἐροῦσιν· ἰδοὺ ὧδε ἢ· ἐκεῖ, ἰδοὺ γὰρ ἡ βασιλεία τοῦ θεοῦ ἐντὸς ὑμῶν ἐστιν.

verses.english: And he said to the disciples: "The days will come when you will desire to see one of the days of the son of man, and you will not see it."
verses.greek: Εἶπεν δὲ πρὸς τοὺς μαθητάς· ἐλεύσονται ἡμέραι ὅτε ἐπιθυμήσετε μίαν τῶν ἡμερῶν τοῦ υἱοῦ τοῦ ἀνθρώπου ἰδεῖν καὶ οὐκ ὄψεσθε.

verses.english: "For as the lightning flashing from under heaven shines to under heaven, so shall be the son of man."
verses.greek: ὥσπερ γὰρ ἡ ἀστραπὴ ἀστράπτουσα ἐκ τῆς ὑπὸ τὸν οὐρανὸν εἰς τὴν ὑπ᾿ οὐρανὸν λάμπει, οὕτως ἔσται ὁ υἱὸς τοῦ ἀνθρώπου.

verses.english: "But first it is necessary for him to suffer many things and to be rejected by this generation."
verses.greek: πρῶτον δὲ δεῖ αὐτὸν πολλὰ παθεῖν καὶ ἀποδοκιμασθῆναι ἀπὸ τῆς γενεᾶς ταύτης.

verses.english: "And as it was in the days of Noah, so shall it be also in the days of the son of man."
verses.greek: καὶ καθὼς ἐγένετο ἐν ταῖς ἡμέραις Νῶε, οὕτως ἔσται καὶ ἐν ταῖς ἡμέραις τοῦ υἱοῦ τοῦ ἀνθρώπου.

verses.english: "Likewise also as it happened in the days of Lot..."
verses.greek: ὁμοίως καθὼς ἐγένετο ἐν ταῖς ἡμέραις Λώτ.

verses.english: "Remember Lot's wife."
verses.greek: μνημονεύετε τῆς γυναικὸς Λώτ.

notes.explanation: Retained in its forensic sense of a trap or impediment to the path, avoiding the softer "offenses." In the Jamesian stratum, this refers to obstacles that hinder the pneumatic progress of the community.
The Jamesian layer emphasizes concrete material consequences for those who disrupt the internal order of the "Poor." Retained as the specific term for a heavy grinding stone.
This identifies the mathematical limit of communal endurance in the primitive source, prioritizing defined social order over infinite abstractions.

The phrase "We are unprofitable slaves" (ἀχρεῖοι δοῦλοί ἐσμεν) is explicitly absent in this stratum. In the Jamesian matrix, the slave who follows the "Law of Liberty" is inherently profitable to the community and the Master.

notes.term: Through the midst (διὰ μέσον - dia meson)
notes.explanation: This topographic detail marks the mixed status of the territory, serving as a forensic transition for the movement's inclusion of Samaritans.
Rendered literally as a title of rank within the pneumatic hierarchy, avoiding the religious connotations of "Master."

The structural displacement of the Naaman reference into this narrative is explicitly attested by the primary forensic witnesses. Tertullian (Adv. Marc. 4.35.6) links the Naaman reference to the healing of the ten lepers, stating that Christ 'prefaced' (praefatus est) the healing with this historical precedent. Epiphanius (Pan. 42.11.6, scholion 48) identifies this verse as occurring within the Luke 17 pericope, noting that Marcion 'cut away much' (ἀπέκοψε δὲ πολλά) from the original and replaced/supplemented it with the Naaman reference (ἄλλα ἀντὶ ἄλλων ἐποίησε). Based on these data points (Harnack/Tsutsui), forensic reconstructions place Luke 4:27 immediately before Luke 17:14 in the Jamesian Protograph. Evidence of canonical displacement exists in Luke 4:23's reference to Capernaum miracles before Jesus arrives there narratively—proving editorial rearrangement of a pre-existing source.
The command functions as a clinical validation within the legal framework, even as the narrative highlights the Samaritan to subvert institutional boundaries.
This term refers to the outward monitoring of celestial or political signs. The Protograph rejects the external "State" model of the Kingdom in favor of a pneumatic reality.
An aorist participle indicating the completed inward shift necessary before outward movement.
The perfect tense denotes a completed state of preservation resulting from the pneumatic shift triggered by faith.
In the Jamesian stratum, this refers to loyalty or stability in the Word rather than an abstract belief.
The Kingdom is defined as an internal state of order, accessible through the spirit rather than sensory debris.
A clinical metaphor for the suddenness of the pneumatic manifestation, stripping away gradualist biological expectations.
A forensic term for being "disqualified" after examination; the rejection is a clinical necessity before the unveiling of the Son of Man.
This stark warning serves as a direct command to detach the self from the material "debris" (possessions) of the old age.
The narrative concerning Lot and his wife and the instruction on "saving one's life" are partially absent in the primary Marcionite/Jamesian records, viewed as later "Pastoral" expansions.

additional_explanation.title: The Internal Kingdom
additional_explanation.content: Chapter 15 of the Protograph articulates the pneumatic definition of the Kingdom.

points.title: Communal Discipline
points.explanation: The opening verses establish the internal order of the community through rebuke and forgiveness. The sevenfold limit identifies a mathematical boundary for communal endurance.

points.title: The Samaritan Precedent
points.explanation: The healing of the ten lepers, with only the Samaritan returning, is structurally linked to Naaman the Syrian. This provides forensic scriptural warrant for the inclusion of non-Israelites in the restoration of the "lost."

points.title: The Kingdom Within
points.explanation: The definitive statement "the kingdom of God is within you" (17:21) rejects all external, observable, political definitions of the Kingdom. It is an internal pneumatic state activated by the Divine Influx.

points.title: The Sudden Manifestation
points.explanation: The lightning metaphor and the warnings about Noah and Lot establish the eschatological expectation as sudden and requiring detachment from material "debris."

chapters.title: Proto-Luke Chapter 16
chapters.preamble: This stratum corresponds to canonical Luke 18 and is defined by its focus on the "Gospel of the Poor" and a high degree of textual variance in the interaction with the ruler, where authority is transferred from the Law to the person of the Messenger.

verses.english: And he spoke also a parable to them, for the necessity to pray always and not to give up.
verses.greek: Ἔλεγεν δὲ παραβολὴν αὐτοῖς πρὸς τὸ δεῖν πάντοτε προσεύχεσθαι καὶ μὴ ἐγκακεῖν.

verses.english: "There was a certain judge in a certain city, not fearing God and not respecting man."
verses.greek: λέγων· Κριτής τις ἦν ἔν τινι πόλει τὸν θεὸν μὴ φοβούμενος καὶ ἄνθρωπον μὴ ἐντρεπόμενος.

verses.english: "And a widow was in that city, and she came to him saying: 'Avenge me of my adversary.'"
verses.greek: χήρα δὲ ἦν ἐν τῇ πόλει ἐκείνῃ καὶ ἤρχετο πρὸς αὐτὸν λέγουσα· Ἐκδίκησόν με ἀπὸ τοῦ ἀντιδίκου μου.

verses.english: "...because this widow causes me trouble, I will avenge her, that she might not in the end, coming, wear me out."
verses.greek: διά γε τὸ παρέχειν μοι κόπον τὴν χήραν ταύτην, ἐκδικήσω αὐτήν.

verses.english: "I say to you that he will do the vindication of them speedily."
verses.greek: λέγω ὑμῖν ὅτι ποιήσει τὴν ἐκδίκησιν αὐτῶν ἐν τάχει.

verses.english: And he spoke also toward certain ones having trusted in themselves that they are righteous and treating the rest with contempt, this parable.
verses.greek: Ἔλεγεν δὲ καὶ πρός τινας τοὺς πεποιθότας ἐφ᾽ ἑαυτοῖς ὅτι εἰσὶν δίκαιοι καὶ ἐξουθενοῦντας τοὺς λοιποὺς τὴν παραβολὴν ταύτην.

verses.english: "Two men went up into the Temple to pray; one a Pharisee and the other a tax-collector."
verses.greek: Ἄνθρωποι δύο ἀνέβησαν εἰς τὸ ἱερὸν προσεύξασθαι, ὁ εἷς Φαρισαῖος καὶ ὁ ἕτερος τελώνης.

verses.english: "The Pharisee, having been stationed, prayed these things toward himself: 'God, I thank you that I am not as the rest of men...'"
verses.greek: ὁ Φαρισαῖος σταθεὶς ταῦτα πρὸς ἑαυτὸν προσηύχετο· Ὁ θεός, εὐχαριστῶ σοι ὅτι οὐκ εἰμὶ ὥσπερ οἱ λοιποὶ τῶν ἀνθρώπων.

verses.english: "And the tax-collector, having been stationed from a distance, would not even lift his eyes into the heaven... but struck his chest saying: 'God, be merciful to me, the sinner.'"
verses.greek: ὁ δὲ τελώνης μακρόθεν ἑστὼς οὐκ ἤθελεν οὐδὲ τοὺς ὀφθαλμοὺς εἰς τὸν οὐρανὸν ἐπᾶραι, ἀλλ' ἔτυπτεν τὸ στῆθος ἑαυτοῦ λέγων· Ὁ θεός, ἱλάσθητί μοι τῷ ἁμαρτωλῷ.

verses.english: "I say to you, this man went down into his house having been justified rather than that man; for everyone who exalts himself will be humbled, but the one who humbles himself will be exalted."
verses.greek: λέγω ὑμῖν, κατέβη οὗτος δεδικαιωμένος εἰς τὸν οἶκον αὐτοῦ παρ' ἐκεῖνον· ὅτι πᾶς ὁ ὑψῶν ἑαυτὸν ταπεινωθήσεται, ὁ δὲ ταπεινῶν ἑαυτὸν ὑψωθήσεται.

verses.english: And a certain ruler questioned him, saying: "Good Teacher, what doing shall I inherit life?"
verses.greek: Καὶ ἐπηρώτησέν τις αὐτὸν ἄρχων λέγων· Διδάσκαλε ἀγαθέ, τί ποιήσας ζωὴν αἰώνιον κληρονομήσω;

verses.english: And Jesus said to him: "Why do you call me good? No one is good except one, God."
verses.greek: εἶπεν δὲ αὐτῷ ὁ Ἰησοῦς· Τί με λέγεις ἀγαθόν; οὐδεὶς ἀγαθὸς εἰ μὴ εἷς ὁ θεός.

verses.english: The Ruler said: "I know the commandments: You should not commit adultery, you should not kill, you should not steal, you should not bear false witness, honour father and mother."
verses.greek: ὁ δὲ ἄρχων εἶπεν· Τὰς ἐντολὰς οἶδα· μὴ μοιχεύσῃς, μὴ φονεύσῃς, μὴ κλέψῃς, μὴ ψευδομαρτυρήσῃς, τίμα τὸν πατέρα καὶ τὴν μητέρα.

verses.english: And he said: "All these things I have guarded from my youth."
verses.greek: ὁ δὲ εἶπεν· ταῦτα πάντα ἐφύλαξα ἐκ νεότητος.

verses.english: And hearing this, Jesus said to him: "Yet one thing is lacking to you: Sell all, as much as you have, and distribute to the poor, and you shall have treasure in heaven; and come, follow me."
verses.greek: ἀκούσας δὲ ὁ Ἰησοῦς εἶπεν αὐτῷ· Ἔτι ἕν σοι λείπει· πάντα ὅσα ἔχεις πώλησον καὶ διάδος πτωχοῖς, καὶ ἕξεις θησαυρὸν ἐν οὐρανῷ, καὶ δεῦρο ἀκολούθει μοι.

verses.english: But hearing these things, he became very sorrowful, for he was rich exceedingly.
verses.greek: ὁ δὲ ἀκούσας ταῦτα περίλυπος ἐγενήθη· ἦν γὰρ πλούσιος σφόδρα.

verses.english: And Jesus, seeing him, said: "How difficult it is for those having the riches to enter into the kingdom of God."
verses.greek: ἰδὼν δὲ αὐτὸν ὁ Ἰησοῦς εἶπεν· Πῶς δυσκόλως οἱ τὰ χρήματα ἔχοντες εἰς τὴν βασιλείαν τοῦ θεοῦ εἰσπορεύονται.

verses.english: "For it is easier for a camel to enter through a needle's eye than for a rich man to enter into the kingdom of God."
verses.greek: εὐκοπώτερον γάρ ἐστιν κάμηλον διὰ τρυπήματος ῥαφίδος εἰσελθεῖν ἢ πλούσιον εἰς τὴν βασιλείαν τοῦ θεοῦ εἰσελθεῖν.

verses.english: And it happened in his drawing near to Jericho, a certain blind man sat by the road begging.
verses.greek: Ἐγένετο δὲ ἐν τῷ ἐγγίζειν αὐτὸν εἰς Ἰεριχὼ τυφλός τις ἐκάθητο παρὰ τὴν ὁδὸν ἐπαιτῶν.

verses.english: And they reported to him that Jesus is passing by.
verses.greek: ἀπήγγειλαν δὲ αὐτῷ ὅτι Ἰησοῦς παρέρχεται.

verses.english: And he cried out saying: "Jesus, Son of David, have mercy on me!"
verses.greek: καὶ ἐβόησεν λέγων· Ἰησοῦ υἱὲ Δαυίδ, ἐλέησόν με.

verses.english: And Jesus said to him: "See! Your faith has saved you."
verses.greek: καὶ ὁ Ἰησοῦς εἶπεν αὐτῷ· Ἀνάβλεψον· ἡ πίστις σου σέσωκέν σε.

verses.english: And immediately he saw, and he followed him, glorifying God.
verses.greek: καὶ παραχρῆμα ἀνέβλεψεν καὶ ἠκολούθει αὐτῷ δοξάζων τὸν θεόν.

notes.explanation: A dry forensic term for failing or losing heart in the face of the material age's resistance.
To vindicate or provide justice. In this stratum, it identifies the legal demand of the Poor (Ebionim) against the institutional creditors of the old order.
The judge is presented forensically as an agent of the material age (the "World") who eventually yields to the persistence of the marginalized.
This term denotes the total nullification of another's worth. In the Jamesian context, the "righteousness" of the institutional elite is clinical debris compared to the humility of the tax-collector.
Strictly the Temple complex. This identifies the setting of the "Opposition Priesthood" within the physical center of Judean authority.
Literally "be propitiated" or "be merciful." It describes a clinical request for the removal of a forensic debt or stain.

notes.term: Toward himself (ταῦτα πρὸς ἑαυτὸν - tauta pros heauton)
notes.explanation: "These things toward himself." This reading, supported by the primitive layer, emphasizes the internal, self-justifying nature of the Pharisee's religion.

notes.term: I know the commandments (Τὰς ἐντολὰς οἶδα - Tas entolas oida)
notes.explanation: This is the definitive Jamesian variant where the Ruler asserts personal mastery over the Law. The Adamantius Dialogue (92,29) explicitly introduces a speaker shift with 'ὁ δὲ ἔφη' (but he said), indicating the ruler begins his recitation at this point. Epiphanius (Pan. 42.11.6, scholion 50) records the reading 'I know (οἶδα)' rather than the canonical 'You know (οἶδας).' Scholars (Zahn, Lieu) argue that placing the Law in the mouth of the ruler serves to relieve Jesus of any direct appeal to the law. Tertullian (Marc. 4.36.4, 7) contradicts this variant, recording Jesus as the speaker with 'nostis/scis' (you know), suggesting variation between Greek and Latin copies. Tertullian (4.36.5) also omits the possessive 'your' (σου) after 'father,' a reading reflected in this reconstruction.
"Guarded" reflects the clinical sense of observing or keeping a legal deposit. In the Jamesian layer, the Law is treated as a baseline of knowledge rather than the climax of the Messenger's teaching.
The reconstruction follows the primitive variant which often omits the personal possessive pronoun in this stratum, focusing on the act of guarding the Law as a dry fact.

This denotes an intense, encompassing sorrow. In the Ebionite (Poor) context, wealth is identified as a definitive consolidation of the corrupt current age, creating a clinical barrier to the Kingdom.
The term σφόδρα emphasizes the extreme nature of the material 'ultimate' that obstructed the ruler's pneumatic transition.

A clinical marker of the sudden manifestation of power in the Jamesian Protograph. Faith in this stratum is viewed as a functional stability or loyalty to the Word that triggers immediate restoration.
Literally 'looked up' or 'saw again.' The restoration of sight serves as forensic proof of the Messenger's authority within the material realm.

notes.term: Sell all (πάντα ὅσα ἔχεις πώλησον - panta hosa echeis pōlēson)
notes.explanation: The command is forensic: "Sell all, as much as you have." This is the absolute economic requirement of the Ebionite community.
Retained as the literal animal over the late "rope" conjecture (kamilos), keeping the dry forensic hyperbole of the source.
The prediction of the passion and the "rising on the third day" is not present in this stratum, preventing harmonization of the ethical encounter with a later suffering-messiah narrative.

In verse 37, the reconstruction follows the primitive variant that omits the geographical/biological marker. This presents the Messenger as a clinical fact of spiritual power rather than a localized human entity.

notes.term: Son of David (υἱὲ Δαυίδ - huiē Dauid)
notes.explanation: While later layers used this for biological pedigree, in the Jamesian stratum it serves as a forensic title for the restorer of the Poor.
This detail reinforces the Messenger's association with the marginalized Ebionim.

additional_explanation.title: The Absence of Harmonization
additional_explanation.content: The textual analysis of this chapter confirms the absence of the third passion prediction (18:31-33).

points.title: The Persistent Widow
points.explanation: The parable of the widow and the unjust judge establishes the efficacy of persistent prayer by the marginalized against the institutions of the material age.

points.title: The Pharisee and Tax-Collector
points.explanation: This parable inverts religious expectations. The self-justifying Pharisee is rejected while the humble tax-collector is justified, consistent with the Jamesian reversal theology.

points.title: The Rich Ruler Encounter
points.explanation: The "I know" variant where the Ruler speaks the commandments is a hallmark of the earliest strata. The Law is a baseline of knowledge, but the Ruler lacks the internal Spirit. The solution is total economic liquidation for the community of the Poor.

points.title: The Blind Man at Jericho
points.explanation: The healing narrative, without the third passion prediction, maintains focus on the power of the Spirit over physical lack. The Messenger moves from the ethical encounter with the rich ruler directly to the restoration of the marginalized.

chapters.title: Proto-Luke Chapter 17
chapters.preamble: This stratum corresponds to canonical Luke 19 and focuses on the radical economic redistribution exemplified by Zacchaeus and the clinical judgment of stewardship in the parable of the minas. The entire narrative of the "Triumphal Entry" into Jerusalem (19:29-46) is entirely absent from the primitive source.

verses.english: And having entered he was passing through Jericho.
verses.greek: Καὶ εἰσελθὼν διήρχετο τὴν Ἰεριχώ.

verses.english: And behold, a man named Zacchaeus, and this man was a chief tax-collector and he was rich.
verses.greek: καὶ ἰδοὺ ἀνὴρ ὀνόματι Ζακχαῖος, καὶ οὗτος ἦν ἀρχιτελώνης καὶ οὗτος πλούσιος.

verses.english: And running ahead to the front he climbed up into a sycamore tree that he might see him, for he was about to pass that way.
verses.greek: καὶ προδραμὼν εἰς τὸ ἔμπροσθεν ἀνέβη ἐπὶ συκομορέαν ἵνα ἴδῃ αὐτόν, ὅτι ἐκείνης ἤμελλεν διέρχεσθαι.

verses.english: And when he came to the place, looking up he said to him: "Zacchaeus, hurry and come down, for today I must stay at your house."
verses.greek: καὶ ὡς ἦλθεν ἐπὶ τὸν τόπον, ἀναβλέψας εἶπεν πρὸς αὐτόν· Ζακχαῖε, σπεύσας κατάβηθι, σήμερον γὰρ ἐν τῷ οἴκῳ σου δεῖ με μεῖναι.

verses.english: And he hurried and came down and received him rejoicing.
verses.greek: καὶ σπεύσας κατέβη καὶ ὑπεδέξατο αὐτὸν χαίρων.

verses.english: And Zacchaeus said: "Behold, the half of my possessions, Lord, I give to the poor, and if I have taken anything from anyone by false accusation, fourfold I return it."
verses.greek: σταθεὶς δὲ Ζακχαῖος εἶπεν πρὸς τὸν κύριον· ἰδοὺ τὰ ἡμίσιά μου τῶν ὑπαρχόντων, κύριε, τοῖς πτωχοῖς δίδωμι, καὶ εἴ τινός τι ἐσυκοφάντησα ἀποδίδωμι τετραπλοῦν.

verses.english: And Jesus said to him: "Today salvation has come to this house, because he also is a son of Abraham."
verses.greek: εἶπεν δὲ πρὸς αὐτὸν ὅτι σήμερον σωτηρία τῷ οἴκῳ τούτῳ ἐγένετο, καθότι καὶ αὐτὸς υἱὸς Ἀβραάμ ἐστιν.

verses.english: "For the son of man came to seek and to save the lost."
verses.greek: ἦλθεν γὰρ ὁ υἱὸς τοῦ ἀνθρώπου ζητῆσαι καὶ σῶσαι τὸ ἀπολωλός.

verses.english: And as they were hearing these things, adding he spoke a parable because he was near Jerusalem and they thought that the kingdom of God was about to appear immediately.
verses.greek: Ἀκουόντων δὲ αὐτῶν ταῦτα προσθεὶς εἶπεν παραβολὴν διὰ τὸ ἐγγὺς εἶναι Ἰερουσαλήμ αὐτὸν καὶ δοκεῖν αὐτοὺς ὅτι παραχρῆμα μέλλει ἡ βασιλεία τοῦ θεοῦ ἀναφαίνεσθαι.

verses.english: Therefore he said: "A certain nobleman went into a far country to receive for himself a kingdom and to return."
verses.greek: εἶπεν οὖν· Ἄνθρωπός τις εὐγενὴς ἐπορεύθη εἰς χώραν μακρὰν λαβεῖν ἑαυτῷ βασιλείαν καὶ ὑποστρέψαι.

verses.english: And calling ten of his slaves, he gave them ten minas and said to them: "Trade with these until I come."
verses.greek: καλέσας δὲ δέκα δούλους ἑαυτοῦ ἔδωκεν αὐτοῖς δέκα μνᾶς καὶ εἶπεν πρὸς αὐτούς· Πραγματεύσασθε ἐν ᾧ ἔρχομαι.

verses.english: And it happened when he returned having received the kingdom, he ordered these slaves to whom he had given the money to be called to him.
verses.greek: καὶ εγένετο ἐν τῷ επανελθεῖν αὐτὸν λαβόντα τὴν βασιλείαν καὶ εἶπεν φωνηθῆναι αὐτῷ τοὺς δούλους τούτους οἷς δεδωκει τὸ ἀργύριον.

verses.english: And he says to him: "Out of your own mouth I will judge you, you wicked slave. You knew that I am an austere man, taking what I did not lay down and reaping what I did not sow."
verses.greek: λέγει αὐτῷ· ἐκ τοῦ στόματός σου κρινῶ σε, πονηρὲ δοῦλε. ᾔδεις ὅτι ἐγὼ ἄνθρωπος αὐστηρός εἰμι, αἴρων ὃ οὐκ ἔθηκα καὶ θερίζων ὃ οὐκ ἔσπειρα;

verses.english: "Why then did you not give my money to the bank, that coming I might have required it with interest?"
verses.greek: καὶ διὰ τί οὐκ ἔδωκάς μου τὸ ἀργύριον ἐπὶ τράπεζαν; κἀγὼ ἐλθὼν σὺν τόκῳ ἂν αὐτὸ ἔπραξα.

verses.english: "For I say to you, that to everyone who has it shall be given; but from him who has not, even what he seems to have shall be taken from him."
verses.greek: λέγω ὑμῖν ὅτι παντὶ τῷ ἔχοντι δοθήσεται, ἀπὸ δὲ τοῦ μὴ ἔχοντος καὶ ὃ δοκεῖ ἔχειν ἀρθήσεται ἀπ᾿ αὐτοῦ.

verses.english: The whole multitude of the disciples began rejoicing to praise God with a loud voice for all the powers they had seen.
verses.greek: ἤρξαντο ἅπαν τὸ πλῆθος τῶν μαθητῶν χαίροντες αἰνεῖν τὸν θεὸν φωνῇ μεγάλῃ περὶ πασῶν ὧν εἶδον δυνάμεων.

verses.english: Saying: "Blessed is the king in the name of the Lord; peace in heavens and glory in the highest."
verses.greek: λέγοντες· Εὐλογημένος ὁ βασιλεύς ἐν ὀνόματι κυρίου· εἰρήνη ἐν οὐρανοῖς καὶ δόξα ἐν ὑψίστοις.

verses.english: "For the days shall come upon you and your enemies shall cast up a rampart against you and surround you and hem you in from every side, and they will level you to the ground and your children within you, and they will not leave stone upon stone in you, because you did not know the time of your visitation."
verses.greek: ὅτι ἥξουσιν ἡμέραι ἐπὶ σέ καὶ περιβαλοῦσιν οἱ ἐχθροί σου χάρακά σοι καὶ περικυκλώσουσιν σε καὶ συνέξουσιν σε πάντοθεν, καὶ ἐδαφιοῦσίν σε καὶ τὰ τέκνα σου ἐν σοί, καὶ οὐκ ἀφήσουσιν λίθον ἐπὶ λίθον ἐν σοί, ἀνθ᾽ ὧν οὐκ ἔγνως τὸν καιρὸν τῆς ἐπισκοπῆς σου.

verses.english: And entering into the Temple he began to cast out those selling, saying to them: "It is written: 'And my house shall be a house of prayer,' but you have made it a den of robbers."
verses.greek: Καὶ εἰσελθὼν εἰς τὸ ἱερὸν ἤρξατο ἐκβάλλειν τοὺς πωλοῦντας λέγων αὐτοῖς· Γέγραπται· Καὶ ἔσται ὁ οἶκός μου οἶκος προσευχῆς, ὑμεῖς δὲ αὐτὸν ἐποιήσατε σπήλαιον ληστῶν.

notes.explanation: Tertullian identifies Zacchaeus as a foreigner (allophylus), yet his presence is retained as a dry fact of the Messenger's interaction with those outside the elite.
The term denotes material debris or property; Zacchaeus's act is the clinical liquidation of capital for communal use.
The order of "fourfold I return" is specific to the earlier witnesses, matching the Latin translations used by Tertullian.

notes.term: Son of Abraham (υἱὸς Ἀβραάμ - huios Abraam)
notes.explanation: While Abraham is removed from eschatological lists (13:28) to de-emphasize biological right, the name is retained here to signify a communal/ethical return to the heritage of the Poor.

notes.term: Save the lost (σῶσαι τὸ ἀπολωλός - sōsai to apolōlos)
notes.explanation: The primitive stratum notably omits "seek" (ζητῆσαι) in some variants. The Messenger's function is defined as the final recovery of the human form from its state of debris.
Strictly rendered as "slaves" to denote the absolute domestic authority of the Master (the Spirit) over his agents.
Retained as the specific unit of currency, denoting the pneumatic resources entrusted to the community members.
This is the constitutional imperative for the community to actively utilize the Spirit's influx rather than remain passive.
The term describes a clinical, rigorous nature, used by the Master to expose the slave's internal lack of productivity.

notes.term: What he seems to have (ὃ δοκεῖ ἔχειν - ho dokei echein)
notes.explanation: This variant, found in Marcion and several early Greek witnesses, suggests that the "unprofitable slave" only possessed an appearance of wealth/knowledge, which is exposed as debris upon judgment.

Epiphanius and other witnesses explicitly state that Marcion's text "jumped over" this section. This omission removes the Messianic political theater of entering Jerusalem, keeping the focus on the internal teaching of the Travel Narrative.

notes.term: Peace in heavens (εἰρήνη ἐν οὐρανοῖς - eirēnē en ouranois)
notes.explanation: This variant (A, etc.) is restored over the canonical "peace on earth." It reflects the pneumatic priority of the Jamesian stratum, where order is first restored in the celestial sphere before descending.
A forensic term for the moment of divine scrutiny.
This reflects the urgent eschatological expectation of the early community before the transition into a stabilized institution.
A clinical military term for a siege wall. In the Jamesian Protograph, this serves as the 'Pella Oracle,' a cryptic warning that allowed the Jerusalem community to flee before the city was locked.

notes.term: Children within you (τὰ τέκνα σου ἐν σοί)
notes.explanation: Refers to the biological and cultural offspring of the old order that will be purged in the collapse of the material ultimates.
Strictly the Temple complex, identified as the clinical site where the "Opposition Priesthood" challenged the institutional elite.
The reconstruction omits "and those buying," following the shorter reading which focuses the Messenger's action on the removal of commercial "debris" from the sacred space.

additional_explanation.title: The Stewardship of the Word
additional_explanation.content: Chapter 17 of the Protograph defines the Economics of Judgment.

points.title: The Case of Zacchaeus
points.explanation: The story is a forensic demonstration of the "Ebionite" ethic. Zacchaeus is not saved by faith in an abstract sense, but by the clinical act of returning stolen capital and liquidating his property. This serves as the ultimate realization of the "Law of Liberty" within the community of the poor.

points.title: The Rejection of the Temple Entry
points.explanation: By omitting the Triumphal Entry (19:29-46), the Protograph avoids portraying Jesus as a Davidic king claiming the physical Temple. Instead, the narrative transitions directly from the stewardship of the minas to the internal reality of the Messenger's authority.

points.title: The Austere Master
points.explanation: The parable of the minas functions as a warning against the "unprofitable" state. The judgment is based strictly on the "use" of what was given; the slave who treats the Word as static debris is stripped of even his "appearance" of possession.

chapters.title: Proto-Luke Chapter 18
chapters.preamble: This stratum corresponds to canonical Luke 20 and continues the confrontation with the Jerusalem elite, focusing on the source of authority and the rejection of material/biological ties in the age to come. The Parable of the Wicked Tenants (20:9-18) and the Proof from the Bush (20:37-38a) are NOT present in this primitive layer.

verses.english: And it happened on one of the days, as he was teaching the people in the Temple and announcing the good news...
verses.greek: Ἐγένετο ἐν μιᾷ τῶν ἡμερῶν διδάσκοντος αὐτοῦ τὸν λαὸν ἐν τῷ ἱερῷ καὶ εὐαγγελιζομένου, ἐπέστησαν οἱ ἀρχιερεῖς καὶ οἱ γραμματεῖς σὺν τοῖς πρεσβυτέροις,

verses.english: And they said, saying to him: 'Tell us by what authority you do these things, or who is the one who gave you this authority?' And answering he said to them: 'I will ask you also a word, and tell me:'
verses.greek: καὶ εἶπαν λέγοντες πρὸς αὐτόν· Εἰπὸν ἡμῖν ἐν ποίᾳ ἐξουσίᾳ ταῦτα ποιεῖς, ἢ τίς ἐστιν ὁ δούς σοι τὴν ἐξουσίαν ταύτην; Ἀποκριθεὶς δὲ εἶπεν πρὸς αὐτούς· Ἐρωτήσω ὑμᾶς κἀγὼ λόγον, καὶ εἴπατέ μοι·

verses.english: The baptism of John, was it from heaven or from men?
verses.greek: Τὸ βάπτισμα Ἰωάννου ἐξ οὐρανοῦ ἦν ἢ ἐξ ἀνθρώπων;
