verses.english: And they reasoned among themselves, saying: 'If we say, From heaven, he will say, Why did you not believe him? But if we say, From men, all the people will stone us...'
verses.greek: οἱ δὲ συνελογίσαντο πρὸς ἑαυτοὺς λέγοντες ὅτι ἐὰν εἴπωμεν· Ἐξ οὐρανοῦ, ἐρεῖ· Διὰ τί οὐκ ἐπιστεύσατε αὐτῷ; ἐὰν δὲ εἴπωμεν· Ἐξ ἀνθρώπων, ὁ λαὸς ἅπας καταλιθάσει ἡμᾶς·

verses.english: And he said to them, 'Neither do I tell you by what authority I do these things.'
verses.greek: καὶ ὁ Ἰησοῦς εἶπεν αὐτοῖς· Οὐδὲ ἐγὼ λέγω ὑμῖν ἐν ποίᾳ ἐξουσίᾳ ταῦτα ποιῶ.

verses.english: And the scribes and the chief priests sought to lay hands on him in that very hour, and they feared the people.
verses.greek: Καὶ ἐζήτησαν οἱ γραμματεῖς καὶ οἱ ἀρχιερεῖς ἐπιβαλεῖν ἐπ᾿ αὐτὸν τὰς χεῖρας ἐν αὐτῇ τῇ ὥρᾳ, καὶ ἐφοβήθησαν τὸν λαόν.

verses.english: Show me a denarius. Whose image and inscription does it have? And they said, 'Caesar's.'
verses.greek: Δείξατέ μοι δηνάριον· τίνος ἔχει εἰκόνα καὶ ἐπιγραφήν; οἱ δὲ εἶπαν· Καίσαρος.

verses.english: And he said to them: 'Give back therefore the things of Caesar to Caesar, and the things of God to God.'
verses.greek: ὁ δὲ εἶπεν αὐτοῖς· Τοίνυν ἀπόδοτε τὰ Καίσαρος Καίσαρι καὶ τὰ τοῦ θεοῦ τῷ θεῷ.

verses.english: And certain of the Sadducees came to him, those saying against there being a resurrection, and questioned him.
verses.greek: Προσελθόντες δέ τινες τῶν Σαδδουκαίων, οἱ ἀντιλέγοντες ἀνάστασιν μὴ εἶναι, ἐπηρώτησαν αὐτόν.

verses.english: And Jesus said to them: 'The sons of this age marry and are given in marriage, but those considered worthy to attain that age and the resurrection from the dead neither marry nor are given in marriage.'
verses.greek: καὶ εἶπεν αὐτοῖς ὁ Ἰησοῦς· Οἱ υἱοὶ τοῦ αἰῶνος τούτου γαμοῦσιν καὶ γαμίσκονται, οἱ δὲ καταξιωθέντες τοῦ αἰῶνος ἐκείνου τυχεῖν καὶ τῆς ἀναστάσεως τῆς ἐκ νεκρῶν οὔτε γαμοῦσιν οὔτε γαμίζονται·

verses.english: For they cannot die anymore, for they are equal to messengers and are sons of God, being sons of the resurrection.
verses.greek: οὐδὲ γὰρ ἀποθανεῖν ἔτι δύνανται, ἰσάγγελοι γάρ εἰσιν καὶ υἱοί εἰσιν θεοῦ τῆς ἀναστάσεως υἱοὶ ὄντες.

verses.english: And he said to them: 'How do they say that the Christ is the son of David?'
verses.greek: Εἶπεν δὲ πρὸς αὐτούς· Πῶς λέγουσιν τὸν χριστὸν εἶναι υἱὸν Δαυίδ;

verses.english: David therefore calls him 'Lord,' and how is he his son?
verses.greek: Δαυὶδ οὖν κύριον αὐτὸν καλεῖ, καὶ πῶς αὐτοῦ υἱός ἐστιν;

verses.english: And while all the people were listening, he said to the disciples: 'Beware of the scribes who desire to walk around in robes and love greetings in the marketplaces and chief seats in the assemblies and chief places at the suppers.'
verses.greek: Ἀκούοντος δὲ παντὸς τοῦ λαοῦ εἶπεν τοῖς μαθηταῖς· Προσέχετε ἀπὸ τῶν γραμματέων τῶν θελόντων περιπατεῖν ἐν στολαῖς καὶ φιλούντων ἀσπασμοὺς ἐν ταῖς ἀγοραῖς καὶ πρωτοκαθεδρίας ἐν ταῖς συναγωγαῖς καὶ πρωτοκλισίας ἐν τοῖς δείπνοις.

notes.explanation: The term refers specifically to the physical complex where the Jamesian 'Opposition Priesthood' confronted the Sadducean establishment.
This implies the performance of heraldic duty, a definitive Jamesian marker.
Reconstructed as the primitive technical term for the internal legal deliberation of the elite.
A specific forensic threat of execution from the marginalized crowds.

Epiphanius confirms this section was absent. The parable anchors Jesus in a biological 'inheritance' (klēronomia) from the previous 'prophets,' a concept the Protograph rejects in favor of a pneumatic descent.
A dry forensic fact—the Roman silver coin representing the 'Mammon of unrighteousness' within the imperial economy.
Reflects the Greek sense of rendering a debt or returning what is already owed to the worldly power, separating it entirely from the things of the Spirit.
The reconstruction confirms that entry into the 'age to come' is a pneumatic achievement rather than a biological right.

notes.term: Neither marry nor are given in marriage
notes.explanation: This highlights the Jamesian/Ebionite focus on asceticism and the dissolution of the 'Proprium' (self-love) through the abolition of biological family structures.
Per the philosophy, 'angeloi' is translated as messengers, identifying the state of the risen as entities of the pneumatic order.

Epiphanius explicitly states this section was absent. Its removal excises the canonical attempt to anchor the resurrection in the 'God of the Fathers' (Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob), maintaining the Protograph's focus on the Spirit over historical biology.
The Messenger uses the internal logic of the Spirit to decouple the Christ from biological Davidic ancestry, consistent with the Adoptionist stratum of the Jamesian source.
Denotes the formal, status-heavy attire of the institutional elite, which the Protograph identifies as material debris.

additional_explanation.title: The Rejection of Biological Authority
additional_explanation.content: Chapter 18 of the Protograph systematically dismantles the theological foundations of the Jerusalem elite.

points.title: The Decoupling from the Prophets
points.explanation: By omitting the Parable of the Wicked Tenants (20:9-18), the Protograph rejects the notion that Jesus is the 'heir' of the prophetic tradition in a biological or institutional sense. The authority of the Messenger comes directly from the Spirit, not through inheritance.

points.title: The Abolition of Marriage
points.explanation: The teaching on resurrection (20:35) declares that the biological family structure is abolished in the age to come. This aligns with the Ebionite asceticism and the rejection of 'Proprium' (self-love) that defines the community of the Poor.

points.title: Christ Not David's Son
points.explanation: The riddle about David calling the Christ 'Lord' (20:41-44) is the climax of the chapter. It uses scriptural logic to sever the Christ from the Davidic bloodline, reinforcing the Adoptionist Christology of the Protograph.

chapters.title: Proto-Luke Chapter 19
chapters.preamble: This stratum corresponds to canonical Luke 21 and comprises the 'Little Apocalypse,' providing the eschatological framework for the movement. A defining feature is the absence of the post-70 CE 'Armies surrounding Jerusalem' prophecy, which is restored here to its primitive Danielic 'Abomination of Desolation' form.

verses.english: And looking up, he saw the rich casting their gifts into the treasury. And he saw a certain poor widow casting in there two lepta.
verses.greek: Καὶ ἀναβλέψας εἶδεν τοὺς βάλλοντας εἰς τὸ γαζοφυλάκιον τὰ δῶρα αὐτῶν πλουσίους. εἶδεν δέ τινα χήραν πενιχρὰν βάλλουσαν ἐκεῖ λεπτὰ δύο.

verses.english: And he said, 'Truly I say to you, that this poor widow has cast in more than all. For all these out of their abundance cast into the gifts, but she out of her lack cast in all the living that she had.'
verses.greek: καὶ εἶπεν· ἀληθῶς λέγω ὑμῖν ὅτι ἡ χήρα ἡ πτωχὴ αὕτη πλεῖον πάντων ἔβαλεν· πάντες γὰρ οὗτοι ἐκ τοῦ περισσεύοντος αὐτοῖς ἔβαλον εἰς τὰ δῶρα, αὕτη δὲ ἐκ τοῦ ὑστερήματος αὐτῆς πάντα τὸν βίον ὃν εἶχεν ἔβαλεν.

verses.english: And he said, 'Take heed that you be not led astray; for many shall come in my name, saying, I am the Christ, and the time has come near; do not go after them.'
verses.greek: ὁ δὲ εἶπεν· βλέπετε μὴ πλανηθῆτε· πολλοὶ γὰρ ἐλεύσονται ἐπὶ τῷ ὀνόματί μου λέγοντες· ἐγώ εἰμι ὁ Χριστός, καὶ· ὁ καιρὸς ἤγγικεν· μὴ πορευθῆτε ὀπίσω αὐτῶν.

verses.english: And when you hear of wars and disturbances, do not be terrified; for these things must first happen, but the end is not immediately. Then he said to them, 'Nation shall rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom.'
verses.greek: ὅταν δὲ ἀκούσητε πολέμους καὶ ἀκαταστασίας, μὴ πτοηθῆτε· δεῖ γὰρ ταῦτα γενέσθαι πρῶτον, ἀλλ᾽ οὐκ εὐθέως τὸ τέλος. Τότε ἔλεγεν αὐτοῖς· ἐγερθήσεται ἔθνος ἐπ᾽ ἔθνος καὶ βασιλεία ἐπὶ βασιλείαν.

verses.english: And there shall be great earthquakes, and in various places pestilences and famines; and there shall be terrors and great signs from heaven.
verses.greek: σεισμοί τε μεγάλοι καὶ κατὰ τόπους λοιμοὶ καὶ λιμοὶ ἔσονται, φόβητρά τε καὶ ἀπ᾿ οὐρανοῦ σημεῖα μεγάλα ἔσται.

verses.english: But before all these things they will lay their hands upon you and persecute you, delivering you up to the assemblies and prisons, being led before kings and governors for my name's sake; it will result in testimony for you.
verses.greek: πρὸ δὲ τούτων ἐπιβαλοῦσιν ἐφ᾽ ὑμᾶς τὰς χεῖρας αὐτῶν καὶ διώξουσιν, παραδιδόντες εἰς τὰς συναγωγὰς καὶ φυλακάς, ἀπαγομένους ἐπὶ βασιλεῖς καὶ ἡγεμόνας ἕνεκεν τοῦ ὀνόματός μου· ἀποβήσεται ὑμῖν εἰς μαρτύριον.

verses.english: For I will give you a mouth and wisdom which all those opposing you will not be able to resist or contradict.
verses.greek: ἐγὼ γὰρ δώσω ὑμῖν στόμα καὶ σοφίαν ᾗ οὐ δυνήσονται ἀντιστῆναι ἢ ἀντειπεῖν πάντες οἱ ἀντικείμενοι ὑμῖν.

verses.english: And you will be hated by all because of my name.
verses.greek: καὶ ἔσεσθε μισούμενοι ὑπὸ πάντων διὰ τὸ ὄνομά μου.

verses.english: In your patience you will save yourselves.
verses.greek: ἐν τῇ ὑπομονῇ σώσετε ἑαυτούς.

verses.english: But when you see the abomination of desolation standing where it ought not, then know that its desolation has come near.
verses.greek: Ὅταν δὲ ἴδητε τὸ βδέλυγμα τῆς ἐρημώσεως ἑστὼς ὅπου οὐ δεῖ, τότε γνῶτε ὅτι ἤγγικεν ἡ ἐρήμωσις αὐτῆς.

verses.english: And there shall be signs in sun and moon and stars, and on the earth distress of nations in perplexity at the roar of the sea and the surging. Men fainting from fear and expectation of the things coming on the world; for the powers of the heavens shall be shaken.
verses.greek: Καὶ ἔσονται σημεῖα ἐν ἡλίῳ καὶ σελήνῃ καὶ ἄστροις, καὶ ἐπὶ τῆς γῆς συνοχὴ ἐθνῶν ἐν ἀπορίᾳ ἤχους θαλάσσης καὶ σάλου, ἀποψυχόντων ἀνθρώπων ἀπὸ φόβου καὶ προσδοκίας τῶν ἐπερχομένων τῇ οἰκουμένῃ, αἱ γὰρ δυνάμεις τῶν οὐρανῶν σαλευθήσονται.

verses.english: And then they shall see the son of man coming from the heavens with much power and glory.
verses.greek: καὶ τότε ὄψονται τὸν υἱὸν τοῦ ἀνθρώπου ἐρχόμενον ἐν νεφέλῃ μετὰ δυνάμεως καὶ δόξης πολλῆς.

verses.english: But when these things begin to happen, stand up and lift up your heads, because your redemption draws near.
verses.greek: ἀρχομένων δὲ τούτων γίνεσθαι ἀνακύψατε καὶ ἐπάρατε τὰς κεφαλὰς ὑμῶν, διότι ἐγγίζει ἡ ἀπολύτρωσις ὑμῶν.

verses.english: And he spoke a parable to them: 'Look at the fig tree and all the trees. When they already bring forth fruit, looking at them you know for yourselves that the summer is already near.'
verses.greek: Καὶ εἶπεν παραβολὴν αὐτοῖς· ἴδετε τὴν συκῆν καὶ πάντα τὰ δένδρα· ὅταν προβάλωσιν ἤδη καρπόν, βλέποντες ἀφ᾿ ἑαυτῶν γινώσκετε ὅτι ἤδη ἐγγὺς τὸ θέρος ἐστίν·

verses.english: So also you, when you see these things happening, know that the kingdom of God is near.
verses.greek: οὕτως καὶ ὑμεῖς, ὅταν ἴδητε ταῦτα γινόμενα, γινώσκετε ὅτι ἐγγὺς ἐστιν ἡ βασιλεία τοῦ θεοῦ.

verses.english: The heaven and the earth shall pass away, but my words shall not pass away.
verses.greek: ὁ οὐρανὸς καὶ ἡ γῆ παρελεύσονται, οἱ δὲ λόγοι μου οὐ μὴ παρελεύσονται.

verses.english: But take heed to yourselves, lest your hearts be weighed down with debauchery and drunkenness and the anxieties of this life, and that day come upon you suddenly as a snare.
verses.greek: Προσέχετε δὲ ἑαυτοῖς μήποτε βαρηθῶσιν ὑμῶν αἱ καρδίαι ἐν κραιπάλῃ καὶ μέθῃ καὶ μερίμναις βιωτικαῖς καὶ ἐπιστῇ ἐφ᾽ ὑμᾶς αἰφνίδιος ἡ ἡμέρα ἐκείνη.

verses.english: And during the days he was teaching in the Temple, and during the nights he went out and lodged on the mountain called Olives. And all the people came early in the morning to him in the Temple to listen to him.
verses.greek: ὧν δὲ τὰς ἡμέρας ἐν τῷ ἱερῷ διδάσκων, τὰς δὲ νύκτας ἐξερχόμενος ηὐλίζετο εἰς τὸ ὄρος τὸ καλούμενον Ἐλαιῶν.

notes.explanation: The term identifies the economic heart of the Temple establishment, which the Jamesian community viewed as the center of 'Mammon.'
The smallest Greek copper coin; retained to emphasize the clinical economic reality of the 'Poor' (Ebionim).
A forensic warning against the corruption of the pneumatic path by false claimants.

notes.term: I am the Christ (ἐγώ εἰμι ὁ Χριστός)
notes.explanation: This specific phrasing is found in the Marcionite layer, distancing the Messenger from those claiming localized, material messiahship.
The reconstruction follows the order found in the earliest witnesses (B, OL, sys), which was often inverted in later Byzantine manuscripts.

Not a legal defense, but a spiritual manifestation of the Truth against the 'Rulers of this Age.' In this context, the suffering of the community is viewed as a legal exhibit within the trial of the old aeon.
Per the translation philosophy, 'assemblies' is used to denote the local Judean administrative and gathering centers where the Jamesian community faced forensic inquiry.
A dry clinical term for Roman administrative officials, consistent with the historical timeframe of the early Jerusalem mission.
This term reflects the social and economic exclusion (Ebionite context) experienced by the community of the Poor in Jerusalem.
The promise that 'not a hair of your head shall perish' is omitted in this stratum, as it is a later harmonizing gloss that contradicts the forensic reality of martyrdom mentioned in verse 16.
Better rendered as 'patient endurance.' The singular reading 'save yourselves' is attested in the Marcionite layer, focusing on the preservation of the pneumatic self.

CRITICAL FORENSIC RESTORATION. The term βδέλυγμα (bdelygma) refers to something ritually detestable, while ἐρήμωσις (erēmōseōs) denotes a clinical laying-waste. Tertullian (Adv. Marc. 4.39.9) actually attests the canonical reading 'surrounded by armies' (vallari exercitibus), indicating his Latin copy had already been updated to conform to historical events. However, forensic stratigraphy identifies the 'armies' detail as a vaticinium ex eventu—a prophecy written after the fact to match the Roman siege of Titus. The 'Abomination' warning (matching Mark 13:14, Matthew 24:15) provided the pre-emptive signal required for the Jerusalem Church to flee to Pella, as mentioned by Eusebius. A warning of 'armies surrounding the city' is clinically useless for flight since the city would already be sealed. This restoration identifies the Jamesian Protograph as a document drafted before 70 CE.
Denotes a 'constriction' or being hemmed in by the collapse of the old order.
Refers to the pneumatic structures of the celestial realm.
Tertullian attests the plural 'heavens,' a variant that emphasizes the cosmic origin of the Son of Man.
The clinical 'loosing' or 'releasing' of the community from the material debris of the age.
The inclusion of 'fruit' (rather than just 'leaves') is a characteristic of the Western and Marcionite text, signifying the maturation of the work.
In the Jamesian Protograph, the permanence of Jesus's specific words replaces the canonical emphasis on the 'Law' (nomos), reflecting the transition to the new covenant of the Spirit.
Specifically refers to the nausea or 'hangover' of material indulgence; the text treats sensory excess as a weight on the heart.

additional_explanation.title: The Abomination and the Pella Oracle
additional_explanation.content: Chapter 19 of the Protograph is the Manual of the Great Transition.

points.title: The Chronometer of Flight
points.explanation: The most significant forensic detail is the restoration of v. 20. Canonical Luke was edited after 70 CE to make the prophecy conform to the Roman circumvallation ('surrounded by armies'). The Protograph, however, contains the 'Abomination of Desolation'—the cryptic signal that allowed the Jerusalem community to flee to Pella BEFORE the city was locked. A prophecy given while the city is already surrounded would be clinically useless for flight.

points.title: The Supersession of Debris
points.explanation: In v. 33, the Messenger asserts that his 'words' are more permanent than the physical universe. This reflects a High Pneumatic Christology where the Spirit (the Word) is the only objective reality, and the material 'heaven and earth' are merely temporary vessels.

points.title: The Law of Sobriety
points.explanation: The warning against 'kraipalē' (debauchery) and 'anxieties of life' is a typical Jamesian exhortation. Discipleship in the Protograph requires an 'unweighted' heart, free from the sensory debris of the world, to perceive the coming redemption.

chapters.title: Proto-Luke Chapter 20
chapters.preamble: This stratum corresponds to canonical Luke 22 and comprises the 'Passion Narrative' of the Jamesian Protograph. Stripped of 'Atonement' theology and physicalist interpolations, this text reveals a narrative of eschatological transition and martyr's resolve.

verses.english: And the feast of unleavened bread, the one called Passover, was drawing near. And the chief priests and the scribes were seeking how they might kill him; for they feared the people.
verses.greek: Ἤγγιζεν δὲ ἡ ἑορτὴ τῶν ἀζύμων ἡ λεγομένη πάσχα. καὶ ἐζήτουν οἱ ἀρχιερεῖς καὶ οἱ γραμματεῖς τὸ πῶς ἀνέλωσιν αὐτόν, ἐφοβοῦντο γὰρ τὸν λαόν.

verses.english: And Judas went away and spoke with the commanders how he might deliver him to them. And they were glad and agreed to give him silver.
verses.greek: καὶ ἀπελθὼν συνελάλησεν τοῖς ἀρχιερεῦσιν καὶ στρατηγοῖς τὸ πῶς αὐτοῖς παραδῷ αὐτόν. καὶ ἐχάρησαν καὶ συνέθεντο αὐτῷ ἀργύριον δοῦναι.

verses.english: And the day of unleavened bread came... And he sent Peter and the rest, saying, 'Go and prepare the Passover for us, that we may eat.'
verses.greek: καὶ εἶπεν τῷ Πέτρῳ καὶ τοῖς λοιποῖς· ἀπελθόντες ἑτοιμάσατε ἵνα φάγωμεν τὸ πάσχα.

verses.english: And when the hour came, he lay down, and the twelve were with him. And he said to them: 'With desire I have desired to eat this Passover with you before I suffer.'
verses.greek: Καὶ ὅτε ἐγένετο ἡ ὥρα, ἀνέπεσεν καὶ οἱ δώδεκα σὺν αὐτῷ. καὶ εἶπεν πρὸς αὐτούς· ἐπιθυμίᾳ ἐπεθύμησα τοῦτο τὸ πάσχα φαγεῖν μεθ' ὑμῶν πρὸ τοῦ με παθεῖν·

verses.english: And receiving a cup, having given thanks, he said: 'Take this and divide it among yourselves. For I say to you, I will not drink from the fruit of the vine until the kingdom of God comes.'
verses.greek: καὶ δεξάμενος ποτήριον εὐχαριστήσας εἶπεν· λάβετε τοῦτο καὶ διαμερίσατε εἰς ἑαυτούς· λέγω γὰρ ὑμῖν, οὐ μὴ πίω ἀπὸ τοῦ γενήματος τῆς ἀμπέλου ἕως οὗ ἡ βασιλεία τοῦ θεοῦ ἔλθῃ.

verses.english: And taking bread, having given thanks, he broke it and gave it to them, saying: 'This is my body.'
verses.greek: καὶ λαβὼν ἄρτον εὐχαριστήσας ἔκλασεν καὶ ἔδωκεν αὐτοῖς λέγων· τοῦτό ἐστιν τὸ σῶμά μου.

verses.english: But behold, the hand of the one delivering me up is with mine on the table. For the son of man goes... but woe to that man through whom he is delivered up.
verses.greek: πλὴν ἰδοὺ ἡ χεὶρ τοῦ παραδιδόντος με μετ᾿ ἐμοῦ ἐπὶ τῆς τραπέζης. οὐαὶ δὲ τῷ ἀνθρώπῳ ἐκείνῳ δι᾿ οὗ παραδίδοται ὁ υἱὸς τοῦ ἀνθρώπου.

verses.english: There arose also a dispute among them, as to which of them was thought to be greatest. But he said to them: 'The kings of the nations exercise authority over them, and those exercising authority over them are called benefactors. But you are not so; instead, let the greatest among you become as the younger, and the leader as the one who serves. For who is greater, the one reclining or the one who serves? Is it not the one reclining? But I am in your midst as the one who serves.'
verses.greek: Ἐγένετο δὲ καὶ φιλονεικία ἐν αὐτοῖς, τὸ τίς αὐτῶν δοκεῖ εἶναι μείζων. ὁ δὲ εἶπεν αὐτοῖς· οἱ βασιλεῖς τῶν ἐθνῶν κυριεύουσιν αὐτῶν καὶ οἱ ἐξουσιάζοντες αὐτῶν εὐεργέται καλοῦνται. ὑμεῖς δὲ οὐχ οὕτως, ἀλλ᾽ ὁ μείζων ἐν ὑμῖν γινέσθω ὡς ὁ νεώτερος, καὶ ὁ ἡγούμενος ὡς ὁ διακονῶν. τίς γὰρ μείζων, ὁ ἀνακείμενος ἢ ὁ διακονῶν; οὐχὶ ὁ ἀνακείμενος; ἐγὼ δὲ ἐν μέσῳ ὑμῶν εἰμι ὡς ὁ διακονῶν.

verses.english: You are those who have remained with me in my trials. And I assign to you, as my Father assigned to me, a kingdom, that you may eat and drink at my table in my kingdom, and sit on thrones judging the twelve tribes of Israel.
verses.greek: ὑμεῖς δέ ἐστε οἱ διαμεμενηκότες μετ᾿ ἐμοῦ ἐν τοῖς πειρασμοῖς μου· κἀγὼ διατίθεμαι ὑμῖν καθὼς διέθετό μοι ὁ πατήρ μου βασιλείαν, ἵνα ἔσθητε καὶ πίνητε ἐπὶ τῆς τραπέζης μου ἐν τῇ βασιλείᾳ μου, καὶ καθήσεσθε ἐπὶ θρόνων τὰς δώδεκα φυλὰς κρίνοντες τοῦ Ἰσραήλ.

verses.english: Simon, Simon, behold, the Adversary has demanded to sift you like wheat. But I have prayed for you that your faith may not fail; and you, when you have turned back, strengthen your brothers. But he said to him: 'Lord, I am ready to go with you both to prison and to death.' But he said: 'I say to you, Peter, a cock will not crow today until you have three times denied that you know me.'
verses.greek: Σίμων Σίμων, ἰδοὺ ὁ σατανᾶς ἐξῃτήσατο ὑμᾶς τοῦ σινιάσαι ὡς τὸν σῖτον· ἐγὼ δὲ ἐδεήθην περὶ σοῦ ἵνα μὴ ἐκλίπῃ ἡ πίστις σου· καὶ σύ ποτε ἐπιστρέψας στήρισον τοὺς ἀδελφούς σου. ὁ δὲ εἶπεν· λέγω σοι, Πέτρε, οὐ φωνήσει σήμερον ἀλέκτωρ ἕως τρίς με ἀπαρνήσῃ εἰδέναι.

verses.english: And going out, he went according to custom to the Mount of Olives; and the disciples also followed him. And coming to the place, he said to them: 'Pray not to enter into temptation.' And he was withdrawn from them about a stone's throw, and placing his knees, he prayed, saying: 'Father, if you are willing, remove this cup from me; yet not my will, but yours be done.'
verses.greek: καὶ αὐτὸς ἀπεσπάσθη ἀπ᾿ αὐτῶν ὡσεὶ λίθου βολὴν καὶ θεὶς τὰ γόνατα προσηύχετο λέγων· πάτερ, εἰ βούλει παρένεγκε τοῦτο τὸ ποτήριον ἀπ᾿ ἐμοῦ· πλὴν μὴ τὸ θέλημά μου ἀλλὰ τὸ σὸν γινέσθω.

verses.english: And rising from the prayer, coming to the disciples, he found them sleeping from the sorrow, and said to them: 'Why do you sleep? Rise and pray, that you may not enter into temptation.'
verses.greek: καὶ ἀναστὰς ἀπὸ τῆς προσευχῆς, ἐλθὼν πρὸς τοὺς μαθητὰς εὗρεν κοιμωμένους αὐτοὺς ἀπὸ τῆς λύπης, καὶ εἶπεν αὐτοῖς· τί καθεύδετε; ἀναστάντες προσεύχεσθε, ἵνα μὴ εἰσέλθητε εἰς πειρασμόν.

verses.english: While he was still speaking, behold a crowd, and the one called Judas, one of the twelve, was going before them and drew near to Jesus to kiss him. But Jesus said to him: 'Judas, do you deliver up the son of man with a kiss?'
verses.greek: ἔτι αὐτοῦ λαλοῦντος ἰδοὺ ὄχλος, καὶ ὁ λεγόμενος Ἰούδας, εἷς τῶν δώδεκα, προήρχετο αὐτοὺς καὶ ἤγγισεν τῷ Ἰησοῦ καταφιλῆσαι αὐτόν. Ἰησοῦς δὲ εἶπεν αὐτῷ· Ἰούδα, φιλήματι τὸν υἱὸν τοῦ ἀνθρώπου παραδίδως;

verses.english: Then Jesus said to the chief priests and commanders of the temple and elders who had come out against him: 'Have you come out as against a robber with swords and clubs? While I was with you daily in the temple, you did not stretch out your hands against me; but this is your hour and the authority of darkness.'
verses.greek: εἶπεν δὲ Ἰησοῦς πρὸς τοὺς παραγενομένους ἐπ᾿ αὐτὸν ἀρχιερεῖς καὶ στρατηγοὺς τοῦ ἱεροῦ καὶ πρεσβυτέρους· ὡς ἐπὶ λῃστὴν ἐξήλθατε μετὰ μαχαιρῶν καὶ ξύλων; καθ᾿ ἡμέραν ὄντος μου μεθ᾿ ὑμῶν ἐν τῷ ἱερῷ οὐκ ἐξετείνατε τὰς χεῖρας ἐπ᾿ ἐμέ, ἀλλ᾿ αὕτη ἐστὶν ὑμῶν ἡ ὥρα καὶ ἡ ἐξουσία τοῦ σκότους.

verses.english: And the men who were holding him were mocking him, beating him. And having blindfolded him, they were asking, saying: 'Prophesy! Who is the one who struck you?'
verses.greek: Καὶ οἱ ἄνδρες οἱ συνέχοντες αὐτὸν ἐνέπαιζον αὐτῷ δέροντες, καὶ περικαλύψαντες αὐτὸν ἐπηρώτων λέγοντες· προφήτευσον, τίς ἐστιν ὁ παίσας σε;

verses.english: And as it became day, the assembly of the elders of the people was gathered... and they led him away into their council, saying: 'If you are the Christ, tell us.' But he said to them: 'If I tell you, you will not believe.'
verses.greek: Καὶ ὡς ἐγένετο ἡμέρα, συνήχθη τὸ πρεσβυτέριον τοῦ λαοῦ, ἀρχιερεῖς τε καὶ γραμματεῖς, καὶ ἀπήγαγον αὐτὸν εἰς τὸ συνέδριον αὐτῶν λέγοντες· εἰ σὺ εἶ ὁ χριστός, εἰπὸν ἡμῖν. εἶπεν δὲ αὐτοῖς· ἐὰν ὑμῖν εἴπω, οὐ μὴ πιστεύσητε.

verses.english: But from now on the son of man shall be seated at the right hand of the power of God.
verses.greek: ἀπὸ τοῦ νῦν δὲ ἔσται ὁ υἱὸς τοῦ ἀνθρώπου καθήμενος ἐκ δεξιῶν τῆς δυνάμεως τοῦ θεοῦ.

verses.english: And they all said: 'Are you then the Son of God?' And he said to them: 'You say it.'
verses.greek: εἶπαν δὲ πάντες· σὺ οὖν εἶ ὁ υἱὸς τοῦ θεοῦ; ὁ δὲ πρὸς αὐτοὺς ἔφη· ὑμεῖς λέγετε ὅτι ἐγώ εἰμι.

notes.explanation: Dry forensic markers of the Judean festival cycle, establishing the legal timeframe of the narrative.
The phrase 'And Satan entered into Judas' is entirely absent from this stratum. The betrayal is recorded as a clinical legal and economic transaction, not a supernatural possession.
Literally 'commanders'—denotes the specific military-police authority of the Temple guard rather than generic officials.
Highlights the economic substrate of the betrayal, consistent with the Jamesian focus on the corrupting nature of material ultimates.
The reconstruction follows the primitive variant omitting 'apostles,' focusing on the functional unit rather than the later ecclesiastical title.

CONTESTED. The forensic reconstruction follows the Western/Marcionite layer (D, Old Latin), which omits the second cup with 'blood of the new covenant poured out for you.' However, Tertullian (Adv. Marc. 4.40.4) alludes to 'blood sealing,' suggesting conflicting witnesses. Epiphanius omits the second cup entirely. In the primitive stratum, the meal was an eschatological anticipation for the 'Poor' (Ebionim), not a Pauline mystery cult centered on vicarious atonement. The evidence is genuinely divided between witnesses.
Emphasizes the communal distribution of resources, a hallmark of the Ebionite social order.

In the context of the Jamesian 'Opposition Priesthood,' this defines authority as a function of communal labor rather than institutional rank. In the Jamesian stratum, this denotes a functional role within the assembly rather than a religious office.
A specific socio-political title of the Greco-Roman world. The Messenger uses it here to critique the 'Old Aeon' logic of patronage and hierarchy.
This term emphasizes the dissolution of status based on age or biological seniority, replacing it with the pneumatic equality of the community of use.
The reconstruction specifies a 'crowd,' likely representing the temple police or administrative assistants of the elite.

'Deliver up' is used to reflect the forensic nature of the transaction. Following the excision of 22:3 (the entry of Satan), the act of Judas is presented as a clinical legal betrayal within the Ultimates of the social order.

notes.term: Commanders of the Temple (στρατηγοὺς τοῦ ἱεροῦ - stratēgous tou hierou)
notes.explanation: Specifically refers to the captains of the temple guard, identifying the arrest as an institutional Judean action.
The term used for an insurrectionist or social bandit, highlighting the Temple elite's attempt to categorize the movement as a political threat.

Rendered as 'the Adversary' to reflect the functional role of the prosecutor in the transition between aeons. The verb ἐξῃτήσατο (exētēsato) is a forensic term meaning 'to demand for trial' or 'to claim by legal suit,' reinforcing the identity of this entity as a celestial prosecutor rather than a mythological demon.
Its removal eliminates the later attempt to portray the disciples as armed or to justify subsequent defensive violence.

The narrative of the 'angel from heaven' and the 'sweat like drops of blood' is a later interpolation (absent in P75, א, and B). Its removal restores the Jamesian Christ of stoic resolve, facing death with spiritual confidence.

notes.term: Sleeping from sorrow (κοιμωμένους... ἀπὸ τῆς λύπης) in 22:45
notes.explanation: The reconstruction includes the causal phrase 'from the sorrow,' attested in the primitive witnesses. This details the pneumatic weight on the disciples during the eschatological transition.
In the Protograph, the focus remains on the community's internal vigilance and the clinical rejection of material anxiety during the eschatological transition.
Denotes the legal or delegated power permitted to the old order in its final hour.

notes.term: Right hand of the power of God (22:69)
notes.explanation: The definitive Jamesian/Pauline confession of spiritual resurrection and exaltation, occurring without the need for an empty tomb.
The ambiguous, non-committal response by which Jesus accepts the titles through the mouth of his accusers.

additional_explanation.title: The Anatomy of the Transition
additional_explanation.content: Chapter 20 of the Protograph provides the Anatomy of the Transition.

points.title: The Non-Atoning Meal
points.explanation: By excising the 'Atonement' additions (vv. 19b-20), the text reveals a meal where the focus is 'divide among yourselves' (v. 17). It is a ritual of communal solidarity and a 'Kingdom Banquet' in miniature, rather than a mystery cult centered on blood sacrifice.

points.title: The Stoic Christ
points.explanation: The removal of the 'bloody sweat' (vv. 43-44) is essential. The Jamesian Jesus does not collapse in biological terror; he undergoes a 'final separation' from the maternal/finite self with a resolve that models the conduct of the future martyrs of the Jerusalem church.

points.title: Spiritual Enthronement
points.explanation: Verse 69 provides the climax of the chapter. The 'Resurrection' is presented here not as a physical return to the old life, but as an immediate transition to the 'Right Hand of Power.' The forensic reality of the cross is the mechanism by which the Son of Man enters his spiritual state.

chapters.title: Proto-Luke Chapter 21
chapters.preamble: This stratum corresponds to canonical Luke 23 and comprises the Trial before Pilate and Crucifixion narrative. A defining forensic marker is the unique charge 'destroying the law and the prophets' attested by Epiphanius.

verses.english: And the whole multitude of them arose and led him to Pilate.
verses.greek: Καὶ ἀναστὰν ἅπαν τὸ πλῆθος αὐτῶν ἤγαγον αὐτὸν ἐπὶ τὸν Πιλᾶτον.

verses.english: And they began to accuse him, saying: 'We found this man perverting our nation, and destroying the law and the prophets, and forbidding to give tribute to Caesar, saying that he himself is the Christ, a king.'
verses.greek: ἤρξαντο δὲ κατηγορεῖν αὐτοῦ λέγοντες· Τοῦτον εὕρομεν διαστρέφοντα τὸ ἔθνος ἡμῶν καὶ καταλύοντα τὸν νόμον καὶ τοὺς προφήτας καὶ κωλύοντα φόρους Καίσαρι διδόναι καὶ λέγοντα ἑαυτὸν Χριστὸν βασιλέα εἶναι.

verses.english: And Pilate questioned him, saying: 'Are you the Christ?' And he answering him said: 'You say it.'
verses.greek: ὁ δὲ Πιλᾶτος ἠρώτησεν αὐτόν λέγων· Σὺ εἶ ὁ Χριστός; ὁ δὲ ἀποκριθεὶς αὐτῷ ἔφη· Σὺ λέγεις.

verses.english: And Pilate said to the chief priests and the crowds: 'I find nothing blameworthy in this man.' But they were insisting, saying that he stirs up the people teaching throughout all Judea, and beginning from Galilee to here.
verses.greek: Ὁ δὲ Πιλᾶτος εἶπεν πρὸς τοὺς ἀρχιερεῖς καὶ τοὺς ὄχλους· Οὐδὲν εὑρίσκω αἴτιον ἐν τῷ ἀνθρώπῳ τούτῳ. οἱ δὲ ἐπίσχυον λέγοντες ὅτι ἀνασείει τὸν λαὸν διδάσκων καθ᾿ ὅλης τῆς Ἰουδαίας, καὶ ἀρξάμενος ἀπὸ τῆς Γαλιλαίας ἕως ὧδε.

verses.english: And Pilate, having heard, asked if the man was a Galilean. And knowing that he was from the jurisdiction of Herod, he sent him to Herod, who was himself in Jerusalem in those days. And Herod, seeing Jesus, was very glad, for he had for a long time desired to see him. And he questioned him in many words, but he answered him nothing. And Herod with his soldiers, having treated him with contempt and mocked him, having thrown a shining robe around him, sent him back to Pilate.
verses.greek: Πιλᾶτος δὲ ἀκούσας ἐπηρώτησεν εἰ ὁ ἄνθρωπος Γαλιλαῖός ἐστιν. καὶ ἐπιγνοὺς ὅτι ἐκ τῆς ἐξουσίας Ἡρῴδου ἐστὶν ἀνέπεμψεν αὐτὸν πρὸς Ἡρῴδην, ὄντα καὶ αὐτὸν ἐν Ἱεροσολύμοις ἐν ταύταις ταῖς ἡμέραις. ὁ δὲ Ἡρῴδης ἰδὼν τὸν Ἰησοῦν ἐχάρη λίαν, ἦν γὰρ ἐξ ἱκανῶν χρόνων θέλων ἰδεῖν αὐτόν. ἐπηρώτα δὲ αὐτὸν ἐν λόγοις ἱκανοῖς, αὐτὸς δὲ οὐδὲν ἀπεκρίνατο αὐτῷ. ἐξουθενήσας δὲ αὐτὸν [καὶ] ὁ Ἡρῴδης σὺν τοῖς στρατεύμασιν αὐτοῦ καὶ ἐμπαίξας περιβαλὼν ἐσθῆτα λαμπρὰν ἀνέπεμψεν αὐτὸν τῷ Πιλάτῳ.

verses.english: Pilate, having called together the chief priests and the rulers and the people, said to them: 'You brought me this man as one perverting the people, and behold, I, having examined him before you, found nothing blameworthy in this man regarding the charges you bring against him. No, nor did Herod, for he sent him back to us; and behold, nothing worthy of death has been done by him. Having disciplined him, therefore, I will release him.'
verses.greek: Πιλᾶτος δὲ συγκαλεσάμενος τοὺς ἀρχιερεῖς καὶ τοὺς ἄρχοντας καὶ τὸν λαὸν εἶπεν πρὸς αὐτούς· προσηνέγκατέ μοι τὸν ἄνθρωπον τοῦτον ὡς ἀποστρέφοντα τὸν λαόν, καὶ ἰδοὺ ἐγὼ ἐνώπιον ὑμῶν ἀνακρίνας οὐθὲν εὗρον ἐν τῷ ἀνθρώπῳ τούτῳ αἴτιον ὧν κατηγορεῖτε κατ᾽ αὐτοῦ· ἀλλ᾽ οὐδὲ Ἡρῴδης, ἀνέπεμψεν γὰρ αὐτὸν πρὸς ἡμᾶς, καὶ ἰδοὺ οὐδὲν ἄξιον θανάτου ἐστὶν πεπραγμένον αὐτῷ· παιδεύσας οὖν αὐτὸν ἀπολύσω.

verses.english: And they cried out all at once, saying: 'Away with this man, and release to us Barabbas!' (Who for a certain sedition made in the city, and for murder, was cast into prison.)
verses.greek: ἀνέκραγον δὲ παμπληθεὶ λέγοντες· Αἶρε τοῦτον, ἀπόλυσον δὲ ἡμῖν τὸν Βαραββᾶν.

verses.english: But they cried out, saying: 'Crucify, crucify him!'
verses.greek: οἱ δὲ ἐπεφώνουν λέγοντες· Σταύρου σταύρου αὐτόν.

verses.english: And he released to them him that for sedition and murder was cast into prison... but he delivered Jesus to their will.
verses.greek: ἀπέλυσεν δὲ τὸν διὰ στάσιν καὶ φόνον βεβλημένον εἰς φυλακὴν ὃν ᾐτοῦντο, τὸν δὲ Ἰησοῦν παρέδωκεν τῷ θελήματι αὐτῶν.

verses.english: And as they led him away, having seized Simon, a certain Cyrenian coming from the country, they laid upon him the cross to carry behind Jesus.
verses.greek: Καὶ ὡς ἀπήγαγον αὐτόν, ἐπιλαβόμενοι Σίμωνά τινα Κυρηναῖον ἐρχόμενον ἀπ᾿ ἀγροῦ ἐπέθηκαν αὐτῷ τὸν σταυρὸν φέρειν ὄπισθεν τοῦ Ἰησοῦ.

verses.english: And there were also two others, criminals, led with him to be put to death. And when they were come to the place, which is called Skull, there they crucified him, and the criminals, one on the right hand, and the other on the left.
verses.greek: ἤγοντο δὲ καὶ ἕτεροι δύο κακοῦργοι σὺν αὐτῷ ἀναιρεθῆναι. Καὶ ὅτε ἀπῆλθον ἐπὶ τὸν τόπον τὸν καλούμενον Κρανίον, ἐκεῖ ἐσταύρωσαν αὐτὸν καὶ τοὺς κακούργους.

verses.english: And the people stood watching. And the rulers also were mocking, saying: 'He saved others, let him save himself, if this is the Christ of God, the Chosen One.'
verses.greek: Καὶ εἱστήκει ὁ λαὸς θεωρῶν. ἐξεμυκτήριζον δὲ καὶ οἱ ἄρχοντες λέγοντες· Ἄλλους ἔσωσεν, σωσάτω ἑαυτόν, εἰ οὗτός ἐστιν ὁ χριστὸς τοῦ θεοῦ ὁ ἐκλεκτός.

verses.english: And there was also an inscription over him: 'This is the king of the Jews.'
verses.greek: ἦν δὲ καὶ ἐπιγραφὴ ἐπ᾿ αὐτῷ· Οὗτός ἐστιν ὁ βασιλεὺς τῶν Ἰουδαίων.

verses.english: And one of the criminals who were hanged railed on him, saying: 'If you are the Christ, save yourself and us!' But the other answering rebuked him, saying: 'Do you not fear God, seeing you are in the same condemnation?'
verses.greek: εἷς δὲ τῶν κρεμασθέντων κακούργων ἐβλασφήμει αὐτὸν λέγων· οὐχὶ σὺ εἶ ὁ χριστός; σῶσον σεαυτὸν καὶ ἡμᾶς. ἀποκριθεὶς δὲ ὁ ἕτερος ἐπιτιμῶν αὐτῷ ἔφη· οὐδὲ φοβῇ σὺ τὸν θεόν, ὅτι ἐν τῷ αὐτῷ κρίματι εἶ;

verses.english: And he said to Jesus: 'Lord, remember me when you come into your kingdom.' And Jesus said to him: 'Verily I say to you, today you shall be with me in Paradise.'
verses.greek: καὶ ἔλεγεν· Ἰησοῦ, μνήσθητί μου ὅταν ἔλθῃς εἰς τὴν βασιλείαν σου. καὶ εἶπεν αὐτῷ· ἀμήν σοι λέγω, σήμερον μετ᾿ ἐμοῦ ἔσῃ ἐν τῷ παραδείσῳ.

verses.english: And it was about the sixth hour, and there was a darkness over all the earth until the ninth hour. And the sun was darkened, and the veil of the temple was rent in the midst.
verses.greek: Καὶ ἦν ἤδη ὡσεὶ ὥρα ἕκτη καὶ σκότος ἐγένετο ἐφ᾿ ὅλην τὴν γῆν ἕως ὥρας ἐνάτης τοῦ ἡλίου ἐκλιπόντος, ἐσχίσθη δὲ τὸ καταπέτασμα τοῦ ναοῦ μέσον.

verses.english: And when Jesus had cried with a loud voice, he said: 'Father, into your hands I commend my spirit'; and having said thus, he expired.
verses.greek: καὶ φωνήσας φωνῇ μεγάλῃ ὁ Ἰησοῦς εἶπεν· Πάτερ, εἰς χεῖράς σου παρατίθεμαι τὸ πνεῦμά μου· τοῦτο δὲ εἰπὼν ἐξέπνευσεν.

verses.english: And, behold, there was a man named Joseph, a counselor... (The same had not consented to the counsel and deed of them)... This man went to Pilate, and begged the body of Jesus. And he took it down, and wrapped it in linen, and laid it in a sepulchre that was hewn in stone, where never man before was laid.
verses.greek: Καὶ ἰδοὺ ἀνὴρ ὀνόματι Ἰωσὴφ βουλευτὴς ὑπάρχων, ἀνὴρ ἀγαθὸς καὶ δίκαιος — οὗτος οὐκ ἦν συγκατατεθειμένος τῇ βουλῇ καὶ τῇ πράξει αὐτῶν — οὗτος προσελθὼν τῷ Πιλάτῳ ᾐτήσατο τὸ σῶμα τοῦ Ἰησοῦ, καὶ καθελὼν ἐνετύλιξεν αὐτὸ σινδόνι καὶ ἔθηκεν αὐτὸν ἐν μνήματι λαξευτῷ οὗ οὐκ ἦν οὐδεὶς οὔπω κείμενος.

notes.term: Destroying the law and the prophets (καταλύοντα τὸν νόμον καὶ τοὺς προφήτας)
notes.explanation: This specific charge is explicitly attested by Epiphanius as a diagnostic marker of this stratum. It confirms the clinical nature of the Messenger's mission: the total abrogation of the old legal and prophetic debris rather than a mere internal reform.
The reconstruction follows the variant where 'The Christ' is prioritized over the Roman political category 'King of the Jews,' centering the trial on the pneumatic function of the Messenger.
The elite view the spread of the Word as a forensic disturbance. The geographic scope (Galilee to Judea) marks the clinical progression of the Spirit's descent.

RETAINED. Tertullian (Adv. Marc. 4.42.3) provides detailed attestation: Jesus is sent to Herod as a 'munus' (gift), Herod is 'delectatus' (delighted), 'exspectaverat' (had long expected), 'interrogavit' (questioned him), and 'nec vocem ullam ab eo audivit' (heard no voice from him). Epiphanius confirms without flagging as interpolation. The vocabulary ἐξουθενήσας (treated with contempt) represents forensic nullification of Jesus's status; ἐσθῆτα λαμπρὰν (shining robe) functions as mockery of the pneumatic claim. The sequence provides a dual judicial rejection (Herod/Pilate) essential to the trial narrative.
This reflects a dry forensic finding of innocence within the Roman/Judean legal debris.
'Disciplined' is used rather than the more emotive 'scourged' to maintain the administrative clinicality of the text.
The 'custom of the feast' is absent in this stratum, as it is a later harmonizing gloss used to explain the release of Barabbas.
A dry forensic term for the nullification of Jesus's status as a biological or political threat.
The 'shining' or 'bright' robe is used clinically to mock the pneumatic claim of divine radiance, casting it as a farce within the material world.
The exchange of the 'Just One' for a 'murderer' is a forensic demonstration of the inverted values of the current age.
The use of this term maintains a focus on the clinical reality of the execution.
Literally 'evil-doers' or 'workers of bad.' The reconstruction maintains this dry forensic descriptor.
The Jamesian layer uses this dialogue to highlight the judgment between the 'powerful/arrogant' and the 'poor/humble' at the moment of death.
This is a core Jamesian marker. It emphasizes an immediate pneumatic transition (exaltation) rather than a delayed material resuscitation.
The reconstruction preserves the verse as found in the Marcionite/Tertullian stratum, representing the immediate spiritual enthronement of the Messenger.
Translated literally rather than using the Latinized 'Calvary,' preserving the dry topographic fact of the execution site.
The earliest witnesses and the forensic reconstruction protocol excise this phrase as a secondary interpolation intended to soften the Messenger's resolve.
Tertullian explicitly identifies this as an interpolation intended to force a fulfillment of Psalm 22:18.

notes.term: Today in Paradise (σήμερον ἐν τῷ παραδείσῳ)
notes.explanation: While some versions excised this to deny immediate transition, Tertullian preserves it. It represents the core Jamesian theme of immediate pneumatic transition rather than delayed material resuscitation.
A forensic deposit. The spirit is clinically returned to its source as the material vessel is exhausted.
The prayer 'Father, into your hands...' contrasts with the Markan cry of abandonment, depicting the Messenger as one whose spiritual sight remains open during physical vastation.
The emphasis on the stone tomb provides the forensic baseline for the subsequent spiritual manifestations; the physical body remains interred according to Second Temple custom.

additional_explanation.title: The Trial and the Abrogation
additional_explanation.content: Chapter 21 of the Protograph presents the legal culmination of the Messenger's mission.

points.title: The Unique Charge
points.explanation: The accusation of 'destroying the law and the prophets' (23:2) is the forensic confession of the Jerusalem elite. They correctly identify the Messenger's purpose: not reform, but the complete abrogation of the old legal and prophetic order. This charge is absent from the canonical text but preserved in Epiphanius.

points.title: The Paradise Promise
points.explanation: The promise to the criminal—'today you shall be with me in Paradise' (23:43)—encapsulates the Jamesian soteriology. Salvation is immediate pneumatic transition, not a future bodily resurrection. The criminal enters the spiritual realm through faith, bypassing all biological requirements.

points.title: The Final Commendation
points.explanation: The cry 'Father, into your hands I commend my spirit' (23:46) is the inverse of the Markan cry of abandonment. The Jamesian Christ maintains spiritual communion throughout the vastation, modeling the death of the martyr as a conscious return of the pneuma to its Divine source.

chapters.title: Proto-Luke Chapter 22
chapters.preamble: This concluding chapter of the Jamesian Protograph (Proto-Luke) represents the primitive record of the spiritual manifestation (Soma Pneumatikon) of the Messenger. Unlike the later canonical expansion, this stratum is defined by the 'Western Non-Interpolations'—shorter readings that lack the secondary physicalist 'proofs' (flesh, bones, and eating) added in the second century to combat Gnosticism. The narrative emphasizes the ambiguity of the tomb and the restoration of the community's internal sight through the opening of the mind (nous).

verses.english: On the first day of the Sabbaths, at deep dawn, they came to the tomb bringing the spices they had prepared. They found the stone rolled away from the tomb. Entering, they did not find the body.
verses.greek: Τῇ δὲ μιᾷ τῶν σαββάτων ὄρθρου βαθέως ἐπὶ τὸ μνῆμα ἦλθον φέρουσαι ἃ ἡτοίμασαν ἀρώματα. εὗρον δὲ τὸν λίθον ἀποκεκυλισμένον ἀπὸ τοῦ μνημείου, εἰσελθοῦσαι δὲ οὐχ εὗρον τὸ σῶμα.

verses.english: It happened while they were perplexed about this, behold, two men stood by them in flashing clothes. As they were afraid and bowed their faces to the ground, they said to them, "Why do you seek the living with the dead?"
verses.greek: καὶ ἐγένετο ἐν τῷ ἀπορεῖσθαι αὐτὰς περὶ τούτου καὶ ἰδοὺ ἄνδρες δύο ἐπέστησαν αὐταῖς ἐν ἐσθῆτι ἀστραπτούσῃ. ἐμφόβων δὲ γενομένων αὐτῶν καὶ κλινουσῶν τὰ πρόσωπα εἰς τὴν γῆν εἶπαν πρὸς αὐτάς· Τί ζητεῖτε τὸν ζῶντα μετὰ τῶν νεκρῶν;

verses.english: [He is not here, but has been raised — Omitted in this stratum] Remember how he spoke to you while still in Galilee, saying that it is necessary for the son of man to be delivered into the hands of sinful men and be crucified and on the third day to rise. And they remembered his words.
verses.greek: μνήσθητε ὡς ἐλάλησεν ὑμῖν ἔτι ὢν ἐν τῇ Γαλιλαίᾳ, λέγων τὸν υἱὸν τοῦ ἀνθρώπου ὅτι δεῖ παραδοθῆναι εἰς χεῖρας ἀνθρώπων ἁμαρτωλῶν καὶ σταυρωθῆναι καὶ τῇ τρίτῃ ἡμέρᾳ ἀναστῆναι. καὶ ἐμνήσθησαν τῶν ῥημάτων αὐτοῦ.

verses.english: Returning from the tomb, they reported all these things to the eleven and to all the rest. These words seemed to them as nonsense, and they did not believe them.
verses.greek: καὶ ὑποστρέψασαι ἀπὸ τοῦ μνημείου ἀπήγγειλαν ταῦτα πάντα τοῖς ἕνδεκα καὶ πᾶσιν τοῖς λοιποῖς. καὶ ἐφάνησαν ἐνώπιον αὐτῶν ὡσεὶ λῆρος τὰ ῥήματα ταῦτα, καὶ ἠπίστουν αὐταῖς.

verses.english: And behold, two of them on that same day were going to a village sixty stadia from Jerusalem, whose name was Emmaus, and they were talking to each other about all these things that had happened. And it happened that while they were talking and debating, Jesus himself drew near and went with them. But their eyes were held so they did not recognize him.
verses.greek: Καὶ ἰδοὺ δύο ἐξ αὐτῶν ἐν αὐτῇ τῇ ἡμέρᾳ ἦσαν πορευόμενοι εἰς κώμην ἀπέχουσαν σταδίους ἑξήκοντα ἀπὸ Ἰερουσαλήμ, ᾗ ὄνομα Ἐμμαοῦς, καὶ αὐτοὶ ὡμίλουν πρὸς ἀλλήλους περὶ πάντων τῶν συμβεβηκότων τούτων. καὶ ἐγένετο ἐν τῷ ὁμιλεῖν αὐτοὺς καὶ συζητεῖν καὶ αὐτὸς Ἰησοῦς ἐγγίσας συνεπορεύετο αὐτοῖς, οἱ δὲ ὀφθαλμοὶ αὐτῶν ἐκρατοῦντο τοῦ μὴ ἐπιγνῶναι αὐτόν.

verses.english: And he said to them: 'What things?' And they said to him: 'The things concerning Jesus the Nazarene, who was a man, a prophet mighty in deed and word before God and all the people.'
verses.greek: καὶ εἶπεν αὐτοῖς· Ποῖα; οἱ δὲ εἶπαν αὐτῷ· τὰ περὶ Ἰησοῦ τοῦ Ναζωραίου, ὃς ἐγένετο ἀνὴρ προφήτης δυνατὸς ἐν ἔργῳ καὶ λόγῳ ἐναντίον τοῦ θεοῦ καὶ παντὸς τοῦ λαοῦ.

verses.english: And it happened that when he reclined with them, taking the bread, he blessed and, breaking it, he gave it to them. Their eyes were opened, and they recognized him; and he became invisible to them.
verses.greek: καὶ ἐγένετο ἐν τῷ κατακλιθῆναι αὐτὸν μετ' αὐτῶν λαβὼν τὸν ἄρτον εὐλόγησεν καὶ κλάσας ἐπεδίδου αὐτοῖς· αὐτῶν δὲ διηνοίχθησαν οἱ ὀφθαλμοὶ καὶ ἐπέγνωσαν αὐτόν· καὶ αὐτὸς ἄφαντος ἐγένετο ἀπ' αὐτῶν.

verses.english: And they said to one another: 'Was not our heart burning within us while he spoke to us on the road, as he opened the scriptures to us?'
verses.greek: καὶ εἶπαν πρὸς ἀλλήλους· Οὐχὶ ἡ καρδία ἡμῶν καιομένη ἦν ἐν ἡμῖν ὡς ἐλάλει ἡμῖν ἐν τῇ ὁδῷ, ὡς διήνοιγεν ἡμῖν τὰς γραφάς;

verses.english: While they were saying these things, he himself stood in the midst of them and said: 'Peace to you.' But being terrified and afraid, they thought they were seeing a spirit. And he said to them: 'Why are you troubled, and why do debates arise in your hearts?' 'See my hands and my feet, that it is I myself.'
verses.greek: Ταῦτα δὲ αὐτῶν λαλούντων αὐτὸς ἔστη ἐν μέσῳ αὐτῶν καὶ λέγει αὐτοῖς· Εἰρήνη ὑμῖν. πτοηθέντες δὲ καὶ ἔμφοβοι γενόμενοι ἐδόκουν πνεῦμα θεωρεῖν. καὶ εἶπεν αὐτοῖς· Τί τεταραγμένοι ἐστὲ καὶ διὰ τί διαλογισμοὶ ἀναβαίνουσιν ἐν τῇ καρδίᾳ ὑμῶν; ἴδετε τὰς χεῖράς μου καὶ τοὺς πόδας μου ὅτι ἐγώ εἰμι αὐτός.

verses.english: And he said to them: "These are my words which I spoke to you while I was still with you, that it is necessary for all things written in the law of Moses and the prophets and psalms about me to be fulfilled." Then he opened their mind to understand the scriptures.
verses.greek: Εἶπεν δὲ πρὸς αὐτούς· Οὗτοι οἱ λόγοι μου οὓς ἐλάλησα πρὸς ὑμᾶς ἔτι ὢν σὺν ὑμῖν, ὅτι δεῖ πληρωθῆναι πάντα τὰ γεγραμμένα ἐν τῷ νόμῳ Μωϋσέως καὶ τοῖς προφήταις καὶ ψαλμοῖς περὶ ἐμοῦ. τότε διήνοιξεν αὐτῶν τὸν νοῦν τοῦ συνιέναι τὰς γραφάς.

verses.english: ...and that repentance into forgiveness of sins should be proclaimed in his name to all the nations. You are witnesses of these things.
verses.greek: ...κηρυχθῆναι ἐπὶ τῷ ὀνόματι αὐτοῦ μετάνοιαν εἰς ἄφεσιν ἁμαρτιῶν εἰς πάντα τὰ ἔθνη. ὑμεῖς μάρτυρες τούτων.

verses.english: And it happened while he was blessing them, he parted from them.
verses.greek: καὶ ἐγένετο ἐν τῷ εὐλογεῖν αὐτὸν αὐτοὺς διέστη ἀπ' αὐτῶν.

verses.english: ...they returned to Jerusalem with great joy, and they were continually in the Temple praising and blessing God.
verses.greek: ...ὑπέστρεψαν εἰς Ἰερουσαλήμ μετὰ χαρᾶς μεγάλης, καὶ ἦσαν διὰ παντὸς ἐν τῷ ἱερῷ αἰνοῦντες καὶ εὐλογοῦντες τὸν θεόν.

notes.explanation: The primitive stratum omits 'of the Lord Jesus' (found in canonical Luke). This is a 'Western Non-Interpolation' where the shorter text reflects the original clinical observation of a missing corpse.
This denotes a radiance characteristic of pneumatic manifestations rather than a material person. It aligns with the visionary sensory overload found in the prophets.

The specific proclamation 'He is not here, but has been raised' is absent in the Western text (Codex Bezae) and the Marcionite witnesses. In Proto-Luke, the tomb remains an ambiguous sign of absence, prompting memory (anamnesis) rather than offering forensic proof.

notes.term: Son of Man (τὸν υἱὸν τοῦ ἀνθρώπου)
notes.explanation: Used here as the clinical referent for the Messenger's eschatological role.
The report of the women is dismissed as an 'idle tale' or 'delirium,' emphasizing that the empty tomb did not generate faith in the earliest community.
The account of Peter running to the tomb is a secondary interpolation found in the Alexandrian tradition but absent in the Western and Marcionite layers.

This implies a psychological or pneumatic constraint. The 'Resurrected' one is only recognizable through spiritual volition. The manifestation of the 'Spiritual Body' (Soma Pneumatikon) is perceived through spiritual volition rather than material physics.

The explicit proclamation of resurrection at the tomb is clinically absent in the Western (D) and Marcionite witnesses; Proto-Luke focuses on the memory (anamnesis) of the Messenger's teaching rather than a kerygmatic proof.
The Greek uses a passive voice, denoting an external action of the Divine upon the subject.
The identification is grounded in the prophetic human status of the teacher as he was known in the Galilean stratum.
The core Jamesian identity of Jesus is that of a prophet of the restored order rather than the post-70 CE biological Messiah.
In Proto-Luke, faith is generated by the revelation of the Word ('opening the scriptures') rather than the forensic inspection of a resuscitated corpse.
Literally 'vanishing' or 'becoming un-manifest.' This is the technical term for the cessation of a pneumatic manifestation, proving that the body did not adhere to material laws.
Faith in the Jamesian Protograph is generated through the 'Opening of the Word' rather than the inspection of a body.
The text records the default perception of the witnesses—that they were seeing a non-corporeal entity.

The claims of 'flesh and bones' and the act of eating fish are omitted as late anti-Docetic additions. They were designed to materialize the resurrection in direct contradiction to the earlier Jamesian/Pauline teaching that 'flesh and blood cannot inherit the kingdom.'
Jesus provides identity markers (the wounds) to confirm personhood without implying a resuscitated corpse.
The climax of the Protograph is intellectual and pneumatic enlightenment—the transition from sensory debris to internal understanding.
The original text lacks the physical levitation/ascension into the sky ('carried up into heaven' is a Western Non-Interpolation). The vision simply ceases.
The narrative ends in the Temple, anchoring the movement as a legitimate Judean institution (the 'Opposition Priesthood') in Jerusalem.

additional_explanation.title: Summary of the Jamesian Protograph
additional_explanation.content: This concluding chapter of the Jamesian Protograph (Proto-Luke) represents the primitive record of the spiritual manifestation (Soma Pneumatikon) of the Messenger. Unlike the later canonical expansion, this stratum is defined by the 'Western Non-Interpolations'—shorter readings that lack the secondary physicalist 'proofs' (flesh, bones, and eating) added in the second century to combat Gnosticism.

points.title: The Tomb as Ambiguous Sign
points.explanation: The primitive stratum omits 'of the Lord Jesus' and the proclamation 'He is not here, but has been raised' (Western text). The empty tomb remains an ambiguous sign prompting memory (anamnesis) rather than forensic proof. The women's report is dismissed as 'nonsense' (lēros)—the empty tomb did not generate faith.

points.title: The Road Manifestation
points.explanation: The 'Resurrected' one is only recognizable through spiritual volition—eyes 'were held' (ekratounto). Recognition comes through the ritual breaking of bread and the internal burning of hearts, not physical inspection. The manifestation ceases with the technical term 'invisible' (aphantos)—becoming un-manifest.

points.title: The Final Manifestation and Mind
points.explanation: The witnesses' default perception is that they were seeing a 'spirit' (pneuma). The claims of 'flesh and bones' and eating fish are excised as anti-Docetic interpolations. The climax is the opening of the 'mind' (nous) to understand the scriptures—intellectual and pneumatic enlightenment. The narrative ends in the Temple, anchoring the movement as the 'Opposition Priesthood' in Jerusalem.
